**NON-GAAP FINANCIAL MEASURES**

In addition to financial information presented in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles
in the United States (“GAAP”), such as net income, our management uses EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Free Cash
Flow, Pro Forma EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Free
Cash Flow, Pro Forma Revenue, Pro Forma Operating Expenses, Pro Forma Net Income, Pro Forma Net Sales, Pro
Forma Adjusted Gross Profit, and Pro Forma Capital Expenditures, each of which is a non-GAAP measure.

EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Free Cash Flow, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Adjusted Gross Profit, Pro Forma
EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, Pro
Forma Revenue, Pro Forma Operating Expenses, Pro Forma Net Income, Pro Forma Net Sales, Pro Forma Adjusted
Gross Profit, and Pro Forma Capital Expenditures, as presented in this offering memorandum, are supplemental
measures of our performance that are not required by, and are not presented in accordance with, GAAP. EBITDA,
Adjusted EBITDA, Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Gross Profit are measures commonly used by financial analysts in
evaluating a company’s performance and/or ability to service and/or incur indebtedness. We present Pro Forma
EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, Pro
Forma Revenue, Pro Forma Operating Expenses, Pro Forma Net Income, Pro Forma Net Sales, Pro Forma Adjusted
Gross Profit, and Pro Forma Capital Expenditures as EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Free
Cash Flow, Adjusted Gross Profit and capital expenditures, in each case, as adjusted or further adjusted for (i) the
Chewy Distribution and (ii) in the case of the twelve months ended November 1, 2020, the Transactions as if such
transactions had occurred and were fully reflected throughout and at the end of such periods, and are adjusted to reflect
such transactions based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable.
Accordingly, we believe that Pro Forma EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
Margin, Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, Pro Forma Revenue, Pro Forma Operating Expenses, Pro Forma Net Income,
Pro Forma Net Sales, Pro Forma Adjusted Gross Profit and Pro Forma Capital Expenditures may be useful for potential
purchasers of the notes in assessing our operating performance and our ability to meet our debt service requirements.
These non-GAAP financial measures, as used herein, are not necessarily comparable to similarly titled measures of
other companies. The items excluded from such non-GAAP financial measures are significant in assessing our
operating results and liquidity.

These non-GAAP measures have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in
isolation, or as a substitute for analysis of our results as reported under GAAP. For instance, some of the limitations
associated with EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Free Cash Flow, Pro Forma EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA,
Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, Pro Forma Revenue, Pro Forma Operating
Expenses, Pro Forma Net Income and Pro Forma Net Sales, are:

  - EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect costs or
cash outlays for capital expenditures or contractual commitments;

  - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

  - they do not reflect the interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal
payments, on our debt;

  - they do not reflect period-to-period changes in taxes, income tax expense or the cash necessary to pay income
taxes;

  - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative
of our ongoing operations;

  - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will
often have to be replaced in the future, and they do not reflect cash requirements for such replacements; and

vi


-----

  - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness
as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, the non-GAAP financial measures presented in this offering memorandum and
the related ratios should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to invest in business growth or
to reduce indebtedness.

**PetSmart Overview**

PetSmart is North America’s leading specialty provider of products, services and solutions for the lifetime
needs of pets. Since opening its first store in 1987, the Company has grown to operate 1,650 stores in the United States,
Puerto Rico and Canada as of November 1, 2020. PetSmart serves a large group of pet owners it calls “pet parents,”
customers who are passionately committed to their pets and consider them members of the family. The Company is
committed to developing moment-making products, services and experiences for pet parents, including inviting pet
parents to shop with their pets, which the Company believes creates an enjoyable and memorable shopping experience.

PetSmart stores carry a broad assortment of high-quality pet supplies for all the life stages of pets, including
nationally recognized brand names as well as an extensive selection of private brands, across a range of product
categories. The Company complements its extensive product assortment with a wide selection of services, including
professional grooming and boarding for cats and dogs, as well as training and day camp for dogs. Most stores feature
pet styling salons that provide high-quality grooming services for dogs, and many of the pet styling salons provide
services for cats. The business generated $7.6 billion in pro forma net sales and $1,269.0 million in pro forma Adjusted
EBITDA for the twelve months ended November 1, 2020.

**_PetSmart at a Glance [(1) ]_**

1


-----

(1) “Market share in specialty pet retail” includes only pet specialty channel per third-party estimates. “Mature stores” is defined as
locations that are three or more years old. Pro forma Free Cash Flow is a Non-GAAP Financial Measure; see “—Summary Historical
and Pro Forma Financial and Other Data” for a reconciliation of this non-GAAP financial measure.

**_Retail Footprint_**

PetSmart has an extensive retail footprint with significant presence across the core U.S. market. Of its 1,650
stores, 91% are located in the U.S., with the remaining 9% in Canada and Puerto Rico. Stores are strategically located,
with a geographically diversified presence across favorable demographic profiles. For example, stores are in regions
with 1.5x the average U.S. household income and where population growth is expected to be 1.5x larger than recent
historical rates in the U.S., based on U.S. census data. Furthermore, as of the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, more
than 60% of PetSmart’s revenue was generated from stores with strong co-tenancy (a major retailer such as Target,
Walmart, Costco, Home Depot, Lowe’s or a grocer), which serves to enhance customer traffic in the area. Very few
stores are located in enclosed malls.

**_Recent Focus_**

The Company’s portfolio of stores generates strong margins and cash flows. Following acceleration of online
growth from Chewy and Amazon in 2016 and movement of two of the largest channel-exclusive brands into the Food,
Drug and Mass (“FDM”) channel in 2016 and 2017, PetSmart has shifted its strategy to focus on services, private
brands and specialty products as well as improved merchandising strategy to bring in new and growing brands to
enhance its value proposition to pet parents, which have provided PetSmart with a path to recovery and further growth.
As such, comparable sales have seen continuous sequential improvement over the last two years, reaching positive
comparable sales in the second half of fiscal year 2019 and accelerating through the COVID-19 pandemic. Over the
long-term, comparable sales continue to benefit from positive trends around new pet ownership, increased consumer
spending and continued humanization of pets.

PetSmart leverages growing omni-channel capabilities to enhance its leading brick and mortar position and
to meet the changing needs of customers. The omni-channel offering consists of Buy-Online-Pick-Up-in Store
(“BOPIS”) including curbside pickup, Ship-to-Home (“STH”), and Ship-from-Store (“SFS”). PetSmart also has a
partnership with DoorDash Inc., a digital delivery service provider, where the Company partners to provide ondemand, same-day delivery service to customers across 1,618 retail locations. Despite a number of e-commerce
options available for pet parents throughout the pandemic, customers have continued shopping at PetSmart whether
in-store or through omni-channel offerings. The omni-channel strategy is focused on complementing the core brick
and mortar business, positioning PetSmart to continue to gain market share in the growing brick and mortar pet retail
category.

2


-----

With over 40 million member profiles, the Treats™ loyalty program provides rich customer data to better
understand consumer preferences and purchasing trends. This large customer database gives PetSmart a competitive
edge in data intelligence over smaller competitors.

**_Merchandise_**

(1) Pro forma Adjusted Gross Margin is calculated based on PetSmart’s Pro Forma Gross Profit for a given period and division, as
adjusted to add back certain items, over PetSmart’s net sales for such period and division. Pro forma Adjusted Gross Margin and Pro
Forma Gross Profit are non-GAAP financial measures. See “—Summary Historical and Pro Forma Financial and Other Data” for a
reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures.
(2) Services revenue includes fees paid to PetSmart from Banfield, a veterinary services provider partnered with PetSmart that operates
most of the Company’s in-store veterinary clinics, and does not include POS fees.

The merchandise offering generally falls into three main categories: consumables, which includes dog and
cat food and treats as well as cat litter products; hardgoods, which includes dog and cat supplies ranging from “fun &
fashion” items (toys, apparel, beds, collars, leashes, etc.) to “problem & solution” items (grooming and beauty,
healthcare and supplements, flea and tick, travel, containment, waste management, etc.); and specialty, which includes
fresh-water fish, small birds, reptiles and other small pets as well as the consumables and hard goods for them.
Merchandise accounted for 87% of the Company’s total net sales for the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, with
consumables, hardgoods and specialty contributing 46%, 27% and 13%, respectively. PetSmart carries the largest pet
merchandise assortment among pet specialty, mass, grocery or other discount retailers, with over 19,500 SKUs and
more than 700 unique brands offered in retail locations and on petsmart.com and onlynaturalpet.com, including
nationally recognized brands as well as an extensive selection of private brands across a wide range of product
categories. The product portfolio is also well-diversified, with no third-party brand representing more than 5% of pro
forma total merchandise sales.

3


-----

Within consumables, PetSmart emphasizes channel-exclusive natural, science-based and therapeutic pet
foods, many of which are not available in grocery stores, warehouse clubs or other mass and general merchandise
retailers. In addition to channel-exclusive products described below, PetSmart offers private brands as well as widely
distributed quality brands in order to provide pet parents with a broad selection of consumables products.

The hardgoods offering is differentiated due to its broad value range, its curated selection and extensive
private and exclusive offerings driven by innovation generated by in-house product development and direct sourcing
capabilities. PetSmart designs and sources a significant portion of hardgoods and specialty items through its product
development office in Phoenix, Arizona, and two sourcing offices in Shanghai and Hong Kong. PetSmart has the
largest selection of products within the brick and mortar pet retail segment.

The specialty offering is a key differentiator against competitors who do not offer live animals or products
for specialty pets, which PetSmart believes serve as an entry point to pet ownership for many younger pet parents.
Also, the in-store fish wall and habitats with reptiles, birds and small and furry pets create a theater to drive traffic.

The Company’s position as the #1 pet care destination, strong relationships with leading product vendors and
educated, passionate and highly trained in-store employees (“associates”) allow PetSmart to offer products that are
exclusively sold (“channel-exclusive”) by pet specialty retailers and not through other retail channels. PetSmart also

4


-----

offers a selection of private brands across consumables, hardgoods and specialty, which represented approximately
30% of merchandise sales for the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, reflecting an approximately 700 basis points
increase in penetration over the last five years. The private consumables offering includes products exclusively sold
at PetSmart and Chewy, such as the Simply Nourish®, Authority® and Only Natural Pet® brands, which generally
carry higher margins than similar branded product. Customers purchasing widely distributed consumables brands
often purchase higher margin hardgoods and specialty products as well, resulting in a positive ticket and creating an
opportunity to upsell these customers to channel exclusive consumables.

**_Services_**

PetSmart is the #1 pet services provider in North America. In substantially all stores, the Company offers
both professional grooming in dedicated salons and specialized training services. It also offers boarding through 207
PetsHotels and veterinary care through 809 third-party pet hospitals which are co-located within stores. The services
offering allows the Company to build trust and loyalty with customers, driving increased traffic to stores and
differentiating the Company from competitors across channels, including specialty retailers, mass, grocery, and online.
Importantly, services cannot be offered online, thus shielding PetSmart from e-commerce competitors. Over the last
five years through fiscal year 2019, services penetration as a percentage of overall PetSmart sales has increased
approximately 120 basis points to 12.4%. Internal data suggests that customers who purchase services transact 1.7x
more regularly and spend 2.1x more annually than non-services customers, and PetSmart estimates that more than
half of services customers also purchase goods. The Company believes that no competitor comes close to its breadth
of services and physical coverage.

**Our Strategy**

PetSmart is committed to developing differentiated, moment-making products, services and experiences that
will attract and retain pet parents as loyal PetSmart customers. The Company has significant opportunities to further
enhance its leadership position in the pet care industry and improve the productivity of stores.

PetSmart believes it has a competitive advantage through unique in-store and omni-channel solutions for pet
parents, including differentiated products and services for pets and exceptional customer service. The Company’s
stores and websites (petsmart.com and onlynaturalpet.com) carry a broad assortment of high-quality pet merchandise
across consumables, hardgoods and what the Company refers to as the “specialty” category. The comprehensive
merchandise offering, with over 19,500 SKUs and more than 700 unique brands offered in retail locations and on

5


-----

petsmart.com, caters to a wide range of pet parents and provides nearly every item needed to satisfy the lifetime needs
of their pets. In addition, the growing assortment and selection of private and exclusive brands enhance customer
loyalty. PetSmart is also the leading provider of pet services (e.g., professional grooming, boarding, training, day
camp, etc.) in the U.S., Canada and Puerto Rico, further strengthening the Company’s value proposition to customers
and differentiating from others in the pet space. PetSmart maintains a content website to further engage with customers.

PetSmart will continue to focus on driving comparable sales, expanding margins and generating Free Cash
Flow through the following key business strategies:

**_Winning through a disciplined approach to growth_**

PetSmart’s business is anchored by four key management principles: be efficient, be margin-focused, be
consumer-insight driven and be an aggressive competitor through continued share gains in brick and mortar. PetSmart
has been able to generate cost savings through increased labor efficiencies within stores and rent savings, both of
which have become particularly important during the COVID-19 pandemic. These four principles have informed the
Company’s over-arching strategy since BC Partners took ownership. PetSmart has dedicated significant time and
resources to increasing efficiency, improving its margin profile, refining its customer analytics and competing
aggressively with competitors across channels.

**_Enhancing value proposition by complementing our competitive advantages in brick and mortar with omni-_**
**_channel capabilities_**

PetSmart continues to focus on winning market share in the growing brick and mortar pet retail category by
providing best-in-class in-store merchandise and service offerings complemented by convenient omni-channel
capabilities. Brick and mortar pet retail category has demonstrated resilience despite industry shift to online, growing
by a CAGR of 0.3% from 2015 to 2019, while online penetration increased from just 7% to 22% during that same
time period. Outside of online, brick and mortar is still expected to represent approximately 65% of pet products in
2024, which implies a future expected growth of 1.5%-2.0% per annum. We believe PetSmart is uniquely positioned
to benefit from this growth with its nationwide reach, unmatched merchandise portfolio, which includes new emerging
brands, private brands and specialty, and its robust service offerings, creating a preferred destination for pet parents
and their pets’ everyday needs. PetSmart’s omni-channel capabilities complement the Company’s in-store offering by
providing multiple avenues for customers to interact with PetSmart, driving loyalty and traffic to stores. PetSmart
focuses its efforts on building capabilities designed to drive value through the store base as evidenced by recent
investments made in BOPIS, the preferred omni-channel option for customers, representing 75% of pro forma omnichannel sales for the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020, and the PRISM scheduling system, an online and
app-based scheduling tool for services. These investments are designed to enhance the store base profitability and
provide an omni-channel experience for customers while not impacting free cash flow generation. PetSmart also offers
STH and SFS at select locations, as well as a same-day delivery service through its new partnership with DoorDash
Inc., providing an on-demand option to customers.

In addition, PetSmart engages with customers through its leading websites, petsmart.com (one of the most
visited pet websites in the U.S.) and onlynaturalpet.com, and its PetSmart app. Pet education resources available on
these digital channels enhance brand value and drive in-store visits and services sales.

PetSmart will continue to leverage omni-channel capabilities to connect with customers, enhance the in-store
experience and drive store traffic to execute on its core strategy to continue being the leading brick and mortar pet
retailer.

**_Providing pet parents with the largest assortment of pet products with a focus on new and growing brands, private_**
**_brands and specialty products_**

PetSmart carries the widest assortment of products across pet merchandise categories, from the value end to
premium end of the product spectrum, and from widely distributed to private or exclusive. Furthermore, the Company
makes it a priority to focus on offering a curated and unique assortment of products that is not widely available for pet
parents by competitors. PetSmart believes in diversifying its brand exposure and enhancing its merchandise offering

6

with new and growing brands, private brands and specialty. Channel-exclusive brands further drive customer loyalty.
The strategic focus is to continue to execute on and expand merchandising capabilities in key areas including:

     - _Newness to the store: PetSmart is constantly looking to capitalize on new trends, find emerging_
product categories and add new brands to the portfolio, whether from existing vendors or new
entrants to the industry. Introducing newness to the store and pursuing innovative brands and
products remains a key strategic priority, and PetSmart plans to continue to add differentiated and
innovative brands to its product assortment each year. PetSmart also offers a large assortment of
private brands which further drives innovation and new experiences in-store. PetSmart will continue
to work closely with vendors in order to deliver a diverse and relevant product offering at
competitive prices.

     - _Private brands: Private brands are only sold by PetSmart and in limited cases, Chewy, and generate_
significant value for the platform. Private brands guarantee exclusivity, have more attractive
margins than non-private brand products and have protected pricing given the absence of a direct
price comparison. Private brand customers are significantly more valuable than the overall
population, spending more on non-private brand products and shopping more frequently, while also
having a longer overall tenure. Through introducing new brands and improving upon existing
brands, PetSmart, excluding Chewy, has grown private and exclusive penetration from 20% of pro
forma merchandise sales in fiscal year 2011 to over 33% of pro forma merchandise sales during the
twelve month period ended November 1, 2020. The private brand portfolio includes brands such as
Authority, Only Natural Pet and Simply Nourish in Consumables, Top Paw, Arcadia Trail and
Whisker City in hardgoods, and Thrive, All Living Things and Top Fin in specialty. PetSmart
expects to further build on the success of the Company’s private brands and incorporate new
PetSmart-exclusive formulations and sub-brands.

     - _Specialty: The specialty category is an area of differentiation for PetSmart as many of its brick and_
mortar competitors cannot match the Company’s breadth in specialty products or customer service
expertise. Further, as customers cannot easily buy live pets online, specialty is partially insulated
from e-commerce competition. Specialty customers are more likely to be repeat visitors and also
tend to shop more frequently on average than the overall population, presenting incremental upside
for cross-sell opportunities. Over the last five years, PetSmart has increased its specialty category
penetration by approximately 130 basis points while expanding category market share in both brick
and mortar and pet specialty retail by approximately 200 basis points. PetSmart’s differentiated
capabilities in specialty uniquely position the Company to further capitalize on this attractive pet
category.

**_Growing and expanding on our comprehensive service offerings to improve the pet parent experience_**

Over the past twenty years, PetSmart has built from the ground up the leading services offering in the pet
industry, and continues to grow this integral part of the business which serves as a key differentiator versus competitors
across brick and mortar and e-commerce. Services include professional grooming, boarding, training, day camp and
other offerings. Unable to be replicated online, the services business drives store traffic, builds customer loyalty, and
shields PetSmart from e-commerce competitors. It also allows for cross-selling and upselling opportunities as
PetSmart acts as a “one stop shop” for customers. Services customers are significantly more valuable than the overall
population, spending more on merchandise, shopping more frequently and having a longer average tenure.

PetSmart made important investments in the services business over the past two years, which helped increase
productivity and improve customer experience. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic and the suspension of certain
services offerings, the services segment performed well with 3.8% comparable sales growth during the third fiscal
quarter of 2019 and 6.4% during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2019. Technological improvements around customer
booking, appointment management, and payment process enabled by the new PRISM scheduling system provides for
a seamless customer experience and drove an increase in appointment capacity of approximately 15%. Other digital
innovations support marketing efforts to drive demand, reduce inefficiencies in administrative tasks, and improve
cancellation rates via automated appointment reminders. The Company also allocated additional staffing to the

services business, increasing the number of groomers to improve productivity, enabling salons to support their
projections. PetSmart remains focused on improving the quality and consistency of services through extensive,
structured training of employees in all pet services areas. There is an opportunity to further enhance average

The non-medical pet services category represents the fastest growing retail category based on three-year

**_Continuing to support pet-related charitable works, including adoptions, which drive pet ownership and creates_**
**_goodwill for the brand_**

Customer analytics show that charitable endeavors are among the top drivers of customer loyalty and buying
intent for PetSmart stores. PetSmart provides space in most stores for pet adoptions through a partnership with
PetSmart Charities (an independent non-profit organization). PetSmart Charities facilitates more pet adoptions than
any other organization with approximately 20% of all pets adopted in the United States in 2019 through PetSmart
stores in partnership with 4,000 animal welfare organizations. In March 2020, PetSmart Charities marked its most
successful national adoption weekend event in its 25-year history, facilitating the adoption of nearly 33,000 pets. This
event brought total pets adopted through PetSmart Charities to 9.2 million. PetSmart Charities is the leading funder
of animal welfare in North America.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Large and Attractive Industry Growing at Approximately 5% Historically_**

The pet care industry is a large and highly attractive category. Supported by secular tailwinds including
increased pet ownership, the continued humanization of pets and the premiumization of pet food, the category reached
$95 billion in total sales in 2019. The sector has also demonstrated higher growth than any other category within retail,
growing at a CAGR of approximately 5% from 2014 to 2019. This growth trajectory is anticipated to continue, as the
forecasted CAGR from 2020 through 2024 is 5.7%.

The pet care industry is also one of the most recessionary resistant categories, as increased adoption rates and
effects of pet humanization more than offset any decreases in household spending during economic downturns. During
the last recession, total category CAGR of approximately 6% was driven by an increase in pet ownership, partially
offset by a slight decrease in average household spending on pet products according to the American Pet Products

recessionary events, and this trend has continued during the COVID pandemic.

**_Secular Industry Tailwinds Accelerating with COVID-19 Pandemic_**

The COVID-19 pandemic has further accelerated tailwinds supporting the sector, including increased pet
ownership, the continued humanization of pets and the premiumization of pet food. Pet adoption rates have increased
through the COVID-19 pandemic as the U.S. population has turned to pets to support mental and physical well-being
during periods of self-isolation. In addition, stay-at-home orders and flexible work schedules have given households
the freedom to care for new pets as people spend more time at home. In 2020, the number of pet-owning households
in the United States is expected to increase by 4% year-over-year, reaching approximately 71 million.

consumers are spending more money on their pets, with a lower percentage of Millennials (ages 19-36) reporting that
they are “budget-conscious” with regards to pet care spending as compared to older pet parents. The “premiumization”
of pet food has also increased customer’s ticket size, and the longer average lives of pets has increased the number of
purchases over the duration of a pet’s life.

is expected to translate to an increase of 4% year-over-year of pet owning households in fiscal year 2020 and we
believe should offset any trade-down as a result of economic challenges.

Both medical and non-medical pet services (e.g., grooming, trainings, hotel, etc.) have been affected by the
COVID-19 pandemic as they were forced to close or operate at reduced capacity due to social distancing requirements.
Collectively, vet services and non-medical pet services are expected to be down (13%) in fiscal year 2020. Both are
expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels and return to approximately 5% growth as the situation normalizes and the

**_Leading Pet Specialty Brick and Mortar Retailer Gaining Share in Its Channel_**

The pet specialty brick and mortar channel has demonstrated resiliency as the broader retail industry has
shifted online. Although the total pet specialty brick and mortar channel has experienced a 1.0% annual decline since
2015 due to the shift to online and FDM, there has been a clear divergence of performance within the category.
Independent pet specialty players have decreased by almost 40% since 2015, while the larger pet specialty chains have
grown at 2.8% per year, with PetSmart gaining 3 points of share of the pet specialty and other brick and mortar channel.
These trends are likely to continue, as: (i) additional independent pet specialty channels are forced to close due to
performance and liquidity constraints; (ii) customers demand an increase in BOPIS and omni-channel solutions which
require significant investments and scale; (iii) larger stores offer broader product selection and cover the greatest
number of pet species; and (iv) services offerings continue to drive revenue.

The specialty category sells live animals, habitats, food, and accessories related to fish, reptiles, birds, and

on average than the overall population, presenting incremental upside for cross-selling opportunities. Over the last 5
years through the end of fiscal year 2019, penetration has increased approximately 130 basis points to approximately

**_Acceleration of Growth in Pre-COVID Period Following Shift of Blue Buffalo to FDM_**

PetSmart’s long term historical performance can be divided into five distinct phases:

1. **Early Growth: PetSmart experienced strong historical performance from 2007 to 2012, including growing**

through the recession and experiencing an average of approximately 4% comparable sales. This growth was
supported by an acceleration in net new store openings of approximately 95 annually from 2005 to 2008.

2. **Slowdown Pre-Investment: The Company’s growth began to slow meaningfully beginning in 2013 and**

entered negative territory in the first quarter of 2014, resulting in traffic declines – which were exacerbated
by mismanagement and a failed consumables reset.

3. **Early Investment Wins: BC Partners acquired PetSmart in 2015. As a result of cost savings and pricing**

strategies implemented by BC Partners, on a pro forma basis Adjusted EBITDA margins improved
approximately 240 basis points from 14.5% in 2014 to 16.9% in 2016, despite flat comparable sales.

4. **Channel Shifts Mid-Investment: Traffic declines began to accelerate beginning in the third quarter of 2016**

as a result of: (i) acceleration of online growth from Chewy and Amazon; and (ii) movement of two of the
largest channel-exclusive brands into the FDM space, including Blue Buffalo in 2017. As a result,
comparable sales declines reached (4.5%) in 2017. Despite these challenges, PetSmart was able to hold pro
forma Adjusted EBITDA margins at approximately 14% (i.e., pre-deal margins) through aggressive expense
management and promotion optimization strategies.

5. **Return to Positive Growth: A shift in strategy to embrace the Company’s “moats” against online as well as**

a merchandising strategy to bring in new and growing brands provided early shoots in a path to recovery.

**Fiscal Year 2020 YTD Update**

During the thirty-nine week period ended November 1, 2020, much of which was affected by the COVID19 pandemic, PetSmart not only benefitted from the resilience of the broader pet retail industry, but also experienced
further performance uplift that was more unique to PetSmart, driving market share gains. PetSmart’s wide assortment
offering allowed the Company to capitalize during the COVID-19 pandemic and offset a loss of services that will
rebound as the sub-category opens up. In addition, pet adoption increases during the pandemic have provided a secular
tailwind for PetSmart’s growth.

     - _Industry tailwinds: Pet supply and food retailers were deemed “essential services” during the_
government mandated shut-downs, allowing PetSmart and other similar businesses to remain open
for merchandise sales. In addition, pet adoptions and ownership increased during lockdowns,
expanding PetSmart’s customer base and generating higher demand for pet products.

     - _Competitive dynamics: Supply chain and fulfillment challenges faced by certain online competitors_
resulted in further uptick in demand for PetSmart. Strong relationships with key suppliers allowed
the Company to maintain sufficient inventory levels and satisfy the elevated demand from
customers.

     - _PetSmart actions: PetSmart took swift action to actively manage costs and drive up profitability_
through (i) optimizing its labor model, (ii) renegotiating store lease agreements and (iii) reevaluating in-store operational practices to identify long term efficiencies. In support of the top line,
the Company accelerated the roll-out of omni-channel capabilities that promoted social distancing,
namely curbside pickup, allowing customers the comfort and flexibility to shop safely.

Comparable sales in the thirteen-weeks ended May 3, 2020, August 2, 2020 and November 1, 2020 were 1.0%, 10.6%
and 13.8%, respectively, combining for 8.4% for the thirty-nine week period ended November 1, 2020. Merchandise
comparable sales for the same quarters were 6.9%, 17.6%, and 18.1%, respectively. While omni-channel penetration
has normalized down from its peak during the government mandated stay-at-home orders, by the end of the third fiscal
quarter of 2020, it remained significantly higher than pre-COVID levels. In the United States, approximately 4% of
pro forma merchandise sales in the third fiscal quarter of 2020 were through BOPIS, compared to approximately 1%
prior to COVID. Furthermore, in the thirty-nine week period ended November 1, 2020, omni-channel pro forma net
sales rose by 239% year-over-year to $360 million.

**Industry Overview**

The pet care industry serves a large, growing, and recession-resilient market. In the U.S., the pet care category
market size was approximately $95.0 billion in calendar year 2019, and included the following sub-segments: (i) pet
food ($36.6 billion); (ii) pet supplies ($18.0 billion); (iii) non-medical pet services ($10.3 billion); and (iv) veterinary
services ($30.1 billion). Approximately 56% of households in the United States owned a pet in calendar year 2020,
which equates to approximately 71 million households. In total, it is estimated that approximately 41.0% (or 51.3
million) of households owned dogs and 25.0% (or 31.4 million) of households owned cats as pets in the United States
in calendar year 2020.

**U.S. Household Pet Ownership**

Supported by secular tailwinds, the pet care category is the fastest growing category within all of retail; the
total category has consistently grown by approximately 5% to approximately 6% in each of the last five years. Pets
are increasingly viewed as members of the family, which has helped drive relatively inelastic demand for pet care
products and services. The “premiumization” of pet food has increased customer’s ticket size, and the longer average
lives of pets has increased the number of purchases over the duration of a pet’s life. Additionally, millennials have
tended to prioritize pet ownership over having children as they enter young adulthood. Pet ownership also boasts
mental and physical health benefits, with 90% of U.S. pet parents believing that their pets have a beneficial impact on
their physical and emotional health. Researchers have tied human health benefits to pet ownership and interaction in
areas including stress, depression, anxiety and PTSD amongst others. Growth trends in pet care are expected to
continue, as the forecasted CAGR from 2019 to 2024 is approximately 5%.

**Historical Segment Growth (2017 to 2019 CAGR)**

-----

**U.S. Pet Retail Sales (dollars in billions)**

The pet care industry has a track record of resiliency during economic downturns. During the last recession,
from 2007 to 2009, total category CAGR of approximately 6% was driven by an increase in pet ownership, partially
offset by a slight decrease in average household spending on pet products. Pet parents have consistently reduced
spending on their pets less than on themselves during recessionary event, and this trend has continued during the
COVID pandemic.

**Pet Care Performance through the “Great Recession”**

Source: RSP sales estimates per Euromonitor and household penetration per packaged facts

_Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on the U.S. Pet Industry_

The pet industry has historically proven to be recession-resilient. However, projected U.S. pet retail sales are
expected to decline by 1.2% in 2020 – compared with 5% growth forecasted prior to the COVID-19 pandemic –
resulting in a decrease from $95 billion in 2019 to $94 billion projected in 2020. This forecast factors in sales declines
in 2020 for services which have been impacted by stay-at home and social distancing orders, with the largest decline

24


-----

expected for non-medical pet services. The decline in services was partially offset by an increase in pet food and pet
products, driven by an increase in pet ownership.

Pet product sales are expected to be up 7.7% in 2020 due to increased pet ownership rates – reflecting overall
resilience in the category, partially impacted by some level of trading down to value and store brands. Pet adoption
rates have increased through the COVID-19 pandemic as the U.S. population has turned to pets to support mental and
physical well-being during periods of self-isolation. In the United States, the approximately 4% projected growth in
pet ownership households in 2020 would increase the number of pet-owning households in the U.S. to nearly 71
million by year-end.

Following the COVID-19 pandemic, we believe the pet industry is expected to rebound to pre-pandemic
levels and accelerate with tailwinds created by the increased pet adoption rates during the lock-down period. These
factors contribute to the attractiveness of the growing pet care category, of which PetSmart is the only comprehensive
provider of both pet products and services in the United States.

(6) We define EBITDA as net income, plus income tax expense, interest expense, net and depreciation and amortization. We
define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA, as further adjusted to exclude certain adjustment items. We describe these
adjustments reconciling net income to Adjusted EBITDA in the table below. The indentures that will govern the notes
and the credit agreements that will govern the new senior secured credit facilities will permit us to make all of the above
adjustments in calculating “EBITDA” as defined in and pursuant to such agreements and may permit us to exclude other
charges and expenses and make other or different adjustments in calculating “EBITDA” as defined in and pursuant to
such agreements in future periods. Certain of the material covenants in the indentures that will govern the notes and the
credit agreements that govern the new senior secured credit facilities are described in “Description of Other
Indebtedness,” “Description of Senior First Lien Notes” and “Description of Senior Unsecured Notes.”

We define Free Cash Flow as Adjusted EBITDA, less capital expenditures and cash payment for finance leases
(comprised of finance lease obligation payments and related interest).

We present EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow because we believe that investors consider them to be
important supplemental measures of our performance and believe these measures are frequently used by securities
analysts, investors and other interested parties in the evaluation of companies in our industry. EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA and Free Cash Flow are not required by, and are not presented in accordance with, GAAP. The items excluded
from EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow are significant in assessing our operating results and liquidity.

Our EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA measures have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in
isolation, or as a substitute for analysis of our results as reported under GAAP. Some of these limitations are:

     - they do not reflect costs or cash outlays for capital expenditures or contractual commitments;

     - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

     - they do not reflect the interest expense or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments
on our debt;

     - they do not reflect period to period changes in taxes, income tax expense or the cash necessary to pay income taxes;

     - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our
ongoing operations;

     - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often
have to be replaced in the future, and EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect cash requirements for such
replacements; and

38

     - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as
comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow should not be considered as measures
of discretionary cash available to invest in business growth or to reduce indebtedness. See “Non-GAAP Financial
Measures.”

**RISK FACTORS**

_Investing in the notes involves risks. You should carefully consider the risk factors set forth below, as well as_
_the other information included in this offering memorandum, before deciding to purchase any notes. The risks_
_described below are not the only risks that we face. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or_
_that we currently deem to be immaterial may also impair our business operations. Any of these risks may have a_
_material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. In such a case, you_
_may lose all or part of your investment in the notes._

**Risks Related to Our Business**

**_Uncertainties in economic conditions, including those caused by the impact of the novel coronavirus known as_**
**_COVID-19, and any related impact on consumer spending on pet products and services, could adversely impact_**
**_our business and results of operations._**

The outbreak of COVID-19 has been declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization and continues
to spread in the United States, Canada, and in many other countries globally. Related government responsive actions
have adversely affected, and may continue to adversely affect our business operations. It is impossible to predict the
effect and ultimate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic as the pandemic remains ongoing. The COVID-19 pandemic
has disrupted the global supply chain, including some of our suppliers, and has caused and may continue to cause
disruptions to our operations. While the sale of pet food and supplies has generally been viewed as essential business
throughout the pandemic, pet related services have sometimes been classified by state and local authorities as nonessential business requiring us to temporarily halt or limit our services offerings and social distancing guidelines have
continued to negatively impact our services business. Any worsening of the COVID-19 pandemic, and any future
actions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic by federal, state or local authorities, including those that limit the
operation of our stores, grooming salons and other services or otherwise limit the ability of our associates to work in
our stores, distribution centers, or other locations, could result in partial or complete closures for unknown duration in
certain jurisdictions, which would adversely impact our business and results of operations.

We temporarily reduced our hours of operations in April for all of our stores; however, during the thirteen
weeks ended August 2, 2020, we began adding back these hours with most of our stores returning to normal hours of
operations as of November 1, 2020. Beginning on April 5, 2020, approximately half of our Canadian stores were only
open for online orders shipped from stores and curbside pickup. On May 19, 2020, these Canadian stores reopened
for in-store transactions. These stores were again limited to online orders shipped from stores and curbside pickup
beginning on December 26, 2020 under an order that remains in place as of the date hereof. In addition, effective
March 21, 2020, we elected to temporarily suspend all grooming services for approximately two weeks in response to
the pandemic. After this period, and following an evaluation of our grooming business and several changes to our
processes, we began to reopen our grooming operations where allowable under state and local orders. As of
November 1, 2020, nearly all of our grooming salons had reopened, however, a small percentage have been required
to close under local orders, mostly in California and Canada, since that time. Our pet training services were closed
from the start of the pandemic until June 8, 2020 when these services began to reopen where allowable under state
and local orders. However, class sizes were reduced to allow for social distancing. As of November 1, 2020, pet
training services had resumed in most of our stores. Substantially all of our PetsHotels were closed from the start of
the pandemic through May 20, 2020 when these services began to reopen where allowable under state and local orders
and in markets with sufficient demand. The majority of PetsHotels had re-opened as of November 1, 2020. The
Company may in the future experience similar closures, reduction in hours of operations, suspension of services and
PetsHotel closures as a result of any worsening of the COVID-19 pandemic.

In addition, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, many of our personnel are working remotely and it is
possible that this could have a negative impact on the execution of our business plans and operations. If a natural
disaster, power outage, connectivity issue, or other event occurred that impacted our associates ability to work
remotely, it may be difficult or, in certain cases, impossible, for us to continue our business for a substantial period of
time. The increase in remote working may also result in consumer privacy, IT security and fraud concerns.

We continue to actively monitor the situation and may take further actions that alter our operations as may
be required by federal, state or local authorities or that we determine are in the best interests of our associates,

customers, suppliers, vendors and the overall business. The uncertainty around the duration of business disruptions,
including uncertainty around consumer demand, and the extent of the spread of the virus in the United States and to
other areas of the world will likely continue to adversely impact the national or global economy and negatively impact
consumer spending. Any of these outcomes could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition,

**_A decline in consumer spending, an inability to anticipate and respond to changes in consumer preferences with_**
**_respect to product and services offerings and customer experience, or failure to successfully manage and execute_**
**_our marketing initiatives could reduce our sales or profitability and harm our business._**

Our sales depend on consumer spending, which is influenced by factors beyond our control, including general
economic conditions, the availability of discretionary income and credit, consumer confidence, tax or interest rate
fluctuations, fuel and other energy costs, healthcare costs, weather, and unemployment levels. Global or national
political unrest or uncertainty may also impact the price paid by consumers for goods, services and commodities and
reduce consumer spending and confidence, and reduce our sales or profitability. We may experience declines in sales
or changes in the types of products and services sold during economic downturns. Any material decline in the amount
of consumer spending could reduce our sales, and a decrease in the sales of higher-margin products and services could
reduce profitability and, in each case, harm our business.

The success of our business depends in part on our ability to identify and respond to evolving trends in
demographics and consumer preferences, and thereby cultivate a growing, loyal customer base, improve customer
traffic, and increase the average transaction amount. Failure to timely identify or effectively respond to changing
consumer tastes and preferences with respect to product and services offerings and customer experience, spending
patterns, and pet ownership trends and pet care needs could adversely affect our business and financial results. In
addition, our business depends in part on the effectiveness of our marketing initiatives. We may not be able to
successfully execute such initiatives to realize the intended benefits and growth prospects due to factors outside of our
control, such as increased competition or deterioration of general economic conditions, thus limiting our ability to
capitalize on business opportunities and expand our business. Also, if we are unable to accurately predict our
customers’ preferred method of communication or their acceptance of our marketing initiatives, we could fail to drive
sales growth, thereby impacting our business and financial performance.

**_The pet products and services retail industry is very competitive and continued competitive forces may adversely_**
**_impact our business and financial results._**

The pet products and services retail industry is very competitive. We compete with supermarkets, warehouse
clubs and other mass and general retailers, many of which are larger and have significantly greater resources than we
have. We also compete with a number of specialty pet supply stores, grocery stores, farm and feed stores, veterinarians,
independent grooming, boarding, and training service providers, catalog retailers and e-commerce retailers. See
“Business—Competition.” The pet products and services retail industry has become increasingly competitive due to
the expansion of pet-related product offerings by certain supermarkets, warehouse clubs and other mass and general
retailers, and the entrance of other specialty retailers into the pet food and pet supply market, some of which have
developed store formats similar to ours. We may face greater competition from these or other retailers in the future,
and changes in their merchandising and operational strategies could impact our sales and profitability. In particular, if
supermarket, warehouse club or other mass and retail merchandise competitors seek to gain or retain market share by
reducing prices, we may reduce our prices on similar product offerings in order to remain competitive, which may
result in a decrease in our market share, sales, operating results and profitability and require a change in our operating
strategies.

43


-----

We also have been able to compete successfully by differentiating ourselves from our competitors through
providing a careful combination of merchandise assortment, competitive pricing, service offerings and unique
customer experience. If changes in consumer preferences decrease the competitive advantage attributable to these
factors, or if we fail to otherwise positively differentiate our customer experience from our competitors, our business
and results of operations could be adversely affected. In particular, a key component of our business strategy is to rely
on our reputation for exceptional customer service. This is done, in part, by recruiting, hiring, training, and retaining
associates who share our core values of delivering superior service to our customers and caring about pet parents and
their needs. If our reputation is negatively affected by the actions of our associates, by our inability to conduct our
operations in a manner that is appealing to current or prospective customers, or otherwise, our business, financial
condition, and results of operations may be materially and adversely affected. In addition, if we are unable to maintain
our current levels of customer service and our reputation for customer service as we grow or otherwise, our net sales
may not continue to grow or may decline, and our business, financial condition, and results of operations may be
materially and adversely affected.

We expect competition in the pet products and services retail industry, in particular Internet-based
competition, generally to continue to increase. If we fail to compete successfully and acquire new customers or retain
existing customers, or fail to do so in a cost-effective manner, our business, financial condition, and results of
operations could be materially and adversely affected.

**_We may be unable to continue to open new stores and enter new markets successfully. If we are unable to_**
**_successfully refurbish existing stores and open new stores, our results of operations could be harmed, and_**
**_comparable sales at our existing stores may decrease due to age or the impact of opening new stores in the same_**
**_area, which could adversely impact our results of operations._**

We currently operate stores in most of the major market areas of the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada.
Our ability to be successful with our store development efforts is dependent on various factors, some of which are
outside our control, including:

  - identifying store sites that offer attractive returns on our investment notwithstanding the impact of
cannibalization of our existing stores;

  - competition for those sites;

  - successfully negotiating with landlords to achieve acceptable lease terms and obtaining any necessary
governmental, regulatory or private approvals;

  - construction costs and/or building material costs;

  - timely construction or remodels of stores;

  - our ability to attract and retain qualified store personnel; and

  - our ability to timely refurbish existing stores in a manner that achieves appropriate returns on our
investment.

To the extent we are unable to accomplish any of the above, our ability to open new stores or refurbish
existing ones may be harmed and our future sales and profits may be adversely affected. In addition, we can make no
assurances that we will be able to meet the forecasted level of sales or new store openings or operate our new stores
or PetsHotels profitably.

As a result of new store openings in existing markets, and because older stores will represent an increasing
proportion of our store base over time, our comparable sales performance may be materially impacted in future
periods. In addition, opening new stores in a market will attract some customers away from other stores already
operated by us in that market and diminish their sales.

44


-----

Our leases are typically signed approximately nine to twelve months before a store opens. As a result, we
may be unable to timely adjust our store opening schedule to new economic conditions or a change in strategy.

**_A disruption, malfunction or increased costs in the operation of our supply chain due to serious disruptions could_**
**_impact our ability to manage our inventory, deliver products to our stores or leverage our expenses. Our inability_**
**_to successfully manage inventory levels could lead to excess inventory or inventory shortages, which could harm_**
**_our sales and results of operations._**

Our vendors generally ship merchandise to our distribution centers, which then allocate the merchandise to
our stores or third-party fulfilment sites. Any interruption or malfunction in our distribution operations, including, but
not limited to, disruptions to the transportation infrastructure, disruptions caused by geopolitical events, such as war
or civil unrest in a country in which our vendors are located, or terrorist or military activities that disrupt transportation,
communication, or utility systems, local protests, and natural disasters, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, floods,
earthquakes, and other adverse weather and climate conditions, whether occurring in the United States or abroad, other
catastrophic events, disease (such as COVID-19), port or other strikes, contamination or trade barriers, the loss of a
key vendor that provides transportation of merchandise within our distribution network, the failure of a key vendor to
deliver on its commitments, or a material increase in our transportation and distribution costs, including, but not
limited to, costs resulting from increases in the price of fuel and other energy costs or other commodities, could cause
inventory shortages and harm our sales and results of operations, particularly during peak periods.

We seek to optimize inventory levels to operate our business successfully. Nonetheless, we are exposed to
inventory risks that may adversely affect our operating results as a result of seasonality, new product launches, vendor
reliability, changes in customer preferences or demand, and changes in consumer spending patterns with respect to
our products. We endeavor to accurately predict these trends and avoid over or under stocking products that we sell.
Demand for products, however, can change between the time inventory is ordered and the date of sale and we may be
unable to accurately forecast such changes. Any of the events above could result in out-of-stock or excess merchandise
inventory levels requiring markdowns that could harm our sales and the results of operations.

We operate fish distribution centers within certain of our distribution centers. Operating the fish distribution
centers is a very complex process involving the intake and sorting of hundreds of different species of fish, housing,
feeding and caring for the fish within an integrated tanks system until shipment, and safely shipping live fish directly
to stores. An interruption or malfunction in these operations or in the fulfillment of fish orders could result in the loss
of live fish or harm our sales and results of operations.

**_If our information systems fail to perform as designed or are interrupted for a significant period of time, our_**
**_business could be harmed._**

The efficient operation of our business is dependent on our information systems. In particular, we rely on our
information systems to effectively manage our financial and operational data, process payroll, manage the supply
chain, maintain our in-stock positions, process customer transactions, and operate our services business. We possess
disaster recovery and business continuity capabilities for our key information systems and take measures intended to
prevent security breaches, unauthorized intrusions and computer viruses. However, these capabilities and measures
may not be effective, and the failure of our information systems to perform as designed due to failure to manage
disasters, security breaches, computer viruses or any other intrusion or interruption of our information systems for a
significant period of time could significantly disrupt our business.

We continue to invest in our information systems. Enhancing or replacing our major financial or operational
information systems could result in disruption of normal operating processes and procedures and have a significant
impact on our ability to conduct our core business operations. We can make no assurances that enhancing or replacing
our information systems will remain within estimated costs, that the systems will be implemented without material
disruption, or that the systems will be as beneficial as predicted. If our predictions or estimates are inaccurate, the
results of our operations could be harmed.

**_We are subject to cyber security risks and may incur increasing costs in an effort to minimize those risks. If we fail_**
**_to protect the integrity and security of customer and associate information, our business could be adversely_**
**_impacted._**

Our business employs systems and websites designed for the secure storage and transmission of proprietary
or confidential information regarding our customers, associates, suppliers and others, including personal identification
information. For instance, we receive, retain and transmit certain sensitive personal information that our customers
provide to purchase products or services, enroll in promotional programs, participate in our customer loyalty program
or register on our websites or mobile application, or otherwise communicate to us. The increasing costs associated
with the implementation and on-going operation of our information security systems, such as increased investments
in technology (including data privacy and data security technology), and the costs of compliance with privacy and
information security laws, policies and standards could adversely impact our business.

Security breaches and similar incidents could expose us to a risk of loss or misuse of this information,
litigation and potential liability, require us to expend additional resources related to the security of information
systems, divert the attention of our management and disrupt our business. As the techniques used to obtain
unauthorized access, disable or degrade service, or sabotage systems change frequently and may not immediately
produce signs of intrusion, we may be unable to anticipate these attacks or to implement adequate preventative or
remedial measures. Any such breach or unauthorized access could result in significant legal and financial exposure,
damage to our reputation, and potentially have an adverse effect on our business. We may not have the resources or
technical sophistication to anticipate or prevent rapidly-evolving types of cyber-attacks. Attacks may be targeted at
us, our customers and suppliers, or others who have entrusted us with information or who are storing information
entrusted with us. Actual, suspected or anticipated attacks may cause us to incur increasing costs, including costs to
deploy additional personnel and protection technologies, train associates, and engage third-party experts and
consultants. Advances in computer capabilities, new technological discoveries or other developments may result in
the technology used by us to protect transaction or other data being breached or compromised. In addition, data and
security breaches can also occur as a result of non-technical issues, including breach by us or by persons with whom
we have commercial relationships that result in the unauthorized release of personal or confidential information.

Our websites, which are increasingly important to our business, and the computer systems and operating
systems on which they run may also be subject to cyber-attacks or intrusions. Those attacks could involve attempts to
gain access to our websites to obtain and make unauthorized use of customers’ or members’ payment information and
related risks discussed below. Such attacks, if successful, can also create denials of service or otherwise disable,
degrade or sabotage one or more of our websites and otherwise significantly disrupt our customers’ and members’
shopping experience on any of our websites. If we are unable to maintain the security of our websites and keep them
operating within acceptable parameters, we could suffer loss of sales, reductions in traffic, reputational damage and
deterioration of our competitive position and incur liability for the same, including for any damage to customers whose
personal information is unlawfully obtained, any of which events could have a material adverse impact on our business
and results of operations and impede the execution of our strategy for the growth of our business.

A compromise of our data security systems or those of businesses we interact with that results in information
related to our customers, associates or business being obtained by unauthorized persons could disrupt our operations,
harm our brand and reputation, result in a loss of consumer confidence in us, and expose us to regulatory actions and
claims from customers, financial institutions, payment card associations, government entities and other persons, any
of which could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we may incur
significant costs and operational consequences in connection with investigating, mitigating, remediating, eliminating
and putting in place additional tools and devices designed to prevent future actual or perceived security incidents, as
well as in connection with complying with any notification or other obligations resulting from any security incidents.
Because we do not control our third-party vendors, or the processing of data by our third-party vendors, our ability to
monitor our third-party vendors’ data security is limited and we cannot ensure the integrity or security of the measures
they take to protect and prevent the loss of our or our consumers’ data. As a result, we are subject to the risk that
cyber-attacks on, or other security incidents affecting, our third-party vendors may adversely affect our business even
if an attack or breach does not directly impact our systems.

**_Failure to comply with international, federal and state laws and regulations relating to privacy, data protection,_**
**_advertising and consumer protection, or the expansion of current or the enactment of new laws or regulations_**

46


-----

**_relating to privacy, data protection, advertising and consumer protection, could adversely affect our business,_**
**_financial condition, and results of operations._**

We rely on a variety of marketing techniques, including email and social media marketing and postal
mailings, and we are subject to various laws and regulations that govern such marketing and advertising practices. A
variety of international, federal and state laws and regulations govern the collection, use, retention, sharing and
security of consumer data, particularly in the context of online advertising which we rely upon to attract new
customers.

Laws and regulations relating to privacy, data protection, marketing and advertising, and consumer protection
are evolving and subject to potentially differing interpretations. These requirements may be interpreted and applied in
a manner that is inconsistent from one jurisdiction to another or may conflict with other rules or our practices. As a
result, our practices may not have complied or may not comply in the future with all such laws, regulations,
requirements and obligations. Any failure, or perceived failure, by us to comply with our posted privacy policies or
with any international, federal or state privacy or consumer protection-related laws, regulations, industry selfregulatory principles, industry standards or codes of conduct, regulatory guidance, orders to which we may be subject
or other legal obligations relating to privacy or consumer protection could adversely affect our reputation, brand and
business, and may result in claims, liabilities, proceedings or actions against us by governmental entities, customers,
suppliers or others, or may require us to change our operations and/or cease using certain data sets. Any such claims,
proceedings or actions could hurt our reputation, brand and business, force us to incur significant expenses in defense
of such proceedings or actions, distract our management, increase our costs of doing business, result in a loss of
customers and suppliers and result in the imposition of monetary penalties. We may also be contractually required to
indemnify and hold harmless third parties from the costs or consequences of non-compliance with any laws,
regulations or other legal obligations relating to privacy or consumer protection or any inadvertent or unauthorized
use or disclosure of data that we store or handle as part of operating our business.

Federal and state governmental authorities continue to evaluate the privacy implications inherent in the use
of third-party “cookies” and other methods of online tracking for behavioral advertising and other purposes. The U.S.
government has enacted, has considered or is considering legislation or regulations that could significantly restrict the
ability of companies and individuals to engage in these activities, such as by regulating the level of consumer notice
and consent required before a company can employ cookies or other electronic tracking tools or the use of data
gathered with such tools. Additionally, some providers of consumer devices and web browsers have implemented, or
announced plans to implement, means to make it easier for Internet users to prevent the placement of cookies or to
block other tracking technologies, which could if widely adopted result in the use of third-party cookies and other
methods of online tracking becoming significantly less effective. The regulation of the use of these cookies and other
current online tracking and advertising practices or a loss in our ability to make effective use of services that employ
such technologies could increase our costs of operations and limit our ability to acquire new customers on costeffective terms and consequently, materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of
operations.

In addition, various international, federal and state legislative and regulatory bodies, or self-regulatory
organizations, may expand current laws or regulations, enact new laws or regulations or issue revised rules or guidance
regarding privacy, data protection, consumer protection, and advertising. For example, in June, 2018 the State of
California enacted the California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 (the “CCPA”), which became effective on January
1, 2020. Among other things, the CCPA requires companies that process information on California residents to make
new disclosures to individuals about their data collection, use and sharing practices, allows individuals to opt out of
certain data sharing with third parties and provides a new cause of action for data breaches. In addition, laws in all 50
U.S. states require businesses to provide notice to consumers whose personal information has been disclosed as a
result of a data breach. Additionally, the Federal Trade Commission and many state attorneys general are interpreting
federal and state consumer protection laws to impose standards for the online collection, use, dissemination and
security of data. Each of these privacy, security, and data protection laws and regulations, and any other such changes
or new laws or regulations, could impose significant limitations, require changes to our business, impose fines and
other penalties or restrict our use or storage of personal information, which may increase our compliance expenses
and make our business more costly or less efficient to conduct. Any such changes could compromise our ability to
develop an adequate marketing strategy and pursue our growth strategy effectively, which, in turn, could adversely
affect our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

**_The disruption of the relationship with or the loss of any of our key vendors or third-party service providers, in_**
**_particular any vendors or service providers with whom we have exclusive relationships, a decision by our vendors_**
**_to make their products available in supermarkets or through warehouse clubs and other mass and general retailers,_**
**_the inability of our vendors to provide quality products in a timely or cost-effective manner, or risks associated with_**
**_the suppliers from whom products are sourced, could harm our business._**

We offer a differentiated product assortment. If more pet food or pet supply vendors were to make their
products available in supermarkets, warehouse clubs and other mass or general retailers, our business could be harmed.
In addition, if the grocery brands currently available to such retailers were to gain market share at the expense of the
differentiated brands sold through specialty pet food and pet supply outlets, our business could be harmed.

We purchase a substantial amount of pet supplies from a number of vendors with limited supply capabilities,
and a small number of our largest vendors account for a material amount of products sold. We can make no assurances
that we will be able to find new qualified vendors who meet our standards, or that our current pet supply vendors will
be able to accommodate our anticipated needs or comply with new or existing regulatory requirements. Further, the
COVID-19 pandemic has caused, and may continue to cause, some of our supplies to experience delays, which could
adversely impact our business. If increases in consumer demand outpace our ability to supply products, we may fail
to exploit market opportunity, which could harm our business. In addition, we purchase a substantial amount of our
private-branded pet supplies from vendors outside of the United States. Effective global sourcing of many of the
products we sell is an important factor in our financial performance. We can make no assurances that our international
vendors will be able to satisfy our requirements including, but not limited to, timeliness of delivery, acceptable product
quality and accurate packaging and labeling. Any inability of our existing vendors to provide products meeting such
requirements in a timely or cost-effective manner could harm our business. In addition, we have no material long-term
supply commitments from our vendors and any vendor could discontinue selling to us at any time.

Many factors relating to our vendors and the countries in which they are located are beyond our control,
including the stability of their political, economic and financial environments, their abilities to operate in challenging
economic environments or meet our standards and applicable U.S. and local legal requirements, the availability of
labor and raw materials, natural disasters and epidemics, labor unrest, merchandise quality issues, currency exchange
rates, trade restrictions, transport availability and cost, inflation and other factors. For example, in addition to the
potential direct effects on us of COVID-19 or any similar epidemic or pandemic, we could be materially adversely
impacted from any disruption to critical vendor services or losses of business, if any of our suppliers face significant
business disruptions as a result of COVID-19 or any similar outbreak. We have suppliers around the world, including
in China, the U.S. and other countries where cases of COVID-19 have been reported and may be spreading in the
community. If the spread of COVID-19 were to worsen in the U.S. or in any other country or region where we have a
significant employee presence, facilities or critical operations, it could impair our ability to manage day-to-day
operations and service our customers, increase our costs of operations and also result in, among other things, losses
of revenue.

In addition, Canadian and U.S. foreign trade policies, tariffs and other impositions on imported goods, trade
sanctions imposed on certain countries, limitations on the import of certain types of goods or of goods containing
certain materials from other countries, and other factors relating to foreign trade are beyond our control. For example,
certain policies and statements of the President of the U.S. and senior administration officials have given rise to
uncertainty regarding the future of international trade agreements and the U.S.’ position on international trade. The
U.S. government has previously raised tariffs, and imposed new tariffs, on a wide range of imports of Chinese products.
The U.S. federal government may also withdraw from or materially modify international trade agreements. Additional
trade restrictions, including tariffs, quotas, embargoes, safeguards and customs restrictions, could increase could lead
to additional costs, delays in shipments, embargos and other uncertainties that could negatively impact our
relationships with our international vendors, our access to products, our operations and financial performance.

We also use and rely on services from third parties, such as fulfillment & transportation services providers
and credit card processors, financial management services providers, supply chain services providers and data storage
services providers. If any of these services become unavailable due to extended outages or interruptions or because
they are no longer available on commercially reasonable terms or prices, or for any other reason, our expenses could
increase and our processes for managing sales of our offerings and supporting our customers could be impaired, any
of which could harm our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

48
