security interest in such collateral or the priority of the security interest in favor of the senior first lien notes and the
guarantees against third parties.

**_Any future pledge of collateral or issuance of a guarantee might be avoidable by a trustee in bankruptcy._**

Any future pledge of collateral or guarantee in favor of the holders of the senior first lien notes might be
avoidable by the pledgor (as debtor-in-possession), guarantor or by its trustee in bankruptcy as a preferential transfer
or otherwise if certain events or circumstances exist or occur, including, among others, if the pledgor or guarantor is
insolvent at the time of the pledge or guarantee, that pledge or issuance of that guarantee permits the holders of the
senior first lien notes to receive a greater recovery in a bankruptcy case of the pledgor under Chapter 7 of the U.S.
Bankruptcy Code than if such pledge or guarantee had not been given, and a bankruptcy proceeding in respect of the
pledgor or guarantor is commenced within 90 days following the pledge or the perfection thereof or the issuance of
the guarantee (as applicable), or, in certain circumstances, a longer period. To the extent that the grant of any such
security interest and/or guarantee is avoided as a preference or otherwise, you would lose the benefit of the security
interest and/or guarantee (as applicable).

In addition, the guarantee and pledge agreement that will govern the Chewy Stock Collateral Pledge will
include provisions that allow the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor to substitute Pledged Chewy Stock with an
equivalent number of shares of Class A and/or Class B common stock, and/or to assign its obligations under the
guarantee and pledge agreement to an affiliate. See “Description of Senior First Lien Notes— Security for the Notes—
Pledge of Chewy Stock.” Under any of such circumstances, there is a risk that such substitution of Pledged Chewy
Stock and/or guarantee assignment of such guarantee and pledge agreement might be avoidable as a preferential
transfer or otherwise.

72


-----

**_Lien searches may not reveal all liens on the collateral._**

We cannot guarantee that the lien searches on the collateral that will secure the notes and guarantees thereof
will reveal any or all existing liens on such collateral. Any such existing lien, including undiscovered liens, could be
significant, could be prior in ranking to the liens securing the notes and guarantees thereof and could have an adverse
effect on the ability of the senior first lien notes collateral Agent to realize or foreclose upon the collateral securing
the notes and guarantees thereof.

**_The collateral is subject to casualty risks._**

We intend to maintain insurance or otherwise insure against hazards in a manner appropriate and customary
for our business. There are, however, certain losses, including those relating to environmental conditions, that may be
either uninsurable or not economically insurable, in whole or in part. Insurance proceeds may not compensate us fully
for our losses. If there is a complete or partial loss or impairment in value of any of the pledged collateral, the insurance
proceeds may not be sufficient to satisfy all of the secured obligations, including the senior first lien notes and the
related guarantees.

**_The imposition of certain permitted liens will, under certain circumstances, permit the liens on the related assets_**
**_securing the senior first lien notes and the guarantees to be either subordinated to such permitted liens or released._**
**_There are also certain other assets that are also excluded from the collateral._**

The indentures that will govern the senior first lien notes, and the guarantee and pledge agreement that will
govern the Chewy Stock Collateral Pledge, in each case will permit liens in favor of third parties to secure additional
debt and, in the case of certain of such liens, the liens on the related assets securing the senior first lien notes and the
subsidiary guarantees or the affiliate guarantee, as applicable, may, under certain circumstances, be either subordinated
to such permitted liens or released. Our ability, and the ability of the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor, to incur
additional debt and liens on such additional debt in favor of third parties is subject to limitations as described herein
under “Description of Senior First Lien Notes.” However, such limitations are subject to important exceptions and
qualifications. As a result, we and the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor may incur substantial amounts of additional
debt secured by liens and other encumbrances in favor of third parties, and the security interest in the collateral
securing the senior first lien notes and the affiliate guarantee may, under certain circumstances, rank on parity with or
subordinate to such permitted liens or encumbrances.

In addition, certain assets are excluded from the collateral securing the senior first lien notes and the
subsidiary guarantees, as discussed under “Description of Senior First Lien Notes—Security for the Notes.” For
example, we are not obligated to pledge any leasehold interest in real estate so none of our stores are pledged. If an
event of default occurs and the maturity of the senior first lien notes is accelerated, the senior first lien notes and the
related subsidiary guarantees will rank pari passu with the holders of other unsecured or senior indebtedness of the
relevant obligor with respect to such excluded assets.

As a result, if the value of the assets pledged as security for the senior first lien notes is less than the value of
the claims of the holders of the senior first lien notes, those claims may not be satisfied in full before the claims of our
unsecured creditors are paid.

**Risks Related to the Senior Notes**

**_The senior notes will not be secured by any of the collateral that secures the senior first lien notes and will be_**
**_effectively subordinated to our secured indebtedness, including the senior first lien notes and borrowings under_**
**_the new senior secured credit facilities, to the extent of the value of the collateral securing such secured_**
**_indebtedness._**

Our obligations under the senior notes and the related note guarantees (including the affiliate guarantee) will
be unsecured and will be effectively subordinated to our secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of the collateral
securing such secured indebtedness (with such collateral including the Pledged Chewy Stock). Borrowings under the
new senior secured credit facilities and the senior first lien notes will be secured by substantially all of the assets of

73


-----

the Issuers, the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor and any existing and future subsidiary guarantors, including all of
the capital stock of the Issuers and each restricted subsidiary (which, in the case of foreign subsidiaries, will be limited
to 65% of the voting capital stock of each direct foreign subsidiary owned by us or our domestic subsidiaries). The
senior notes will be effectively subordinated to all such secured indebtedness to the extent of the value of such
collateral. If we become insolvent or are liquidated, or if payment under the new senior secured credit facilities or
under the senior first lien notes offered hereby are accelerated, the lenders under the respective indebtedness will be
entitled to exercise the remedies available to a secured lender under applicable law (in addition to any remedies that
may be available under documents pertaining to such indebtedness). If an event of default occurs under the new senior
secured credit facilities or under the indenture that will govern the senior first lien notes, the holders of such senior
secured indebtedness will have a prior right to our assets, to the exclusion of the holders of the senior notes, even if
we are in default with respect to the senior notes. In that event, our assets would first be used to repay in full all
indebtedness and other obligations secured thereby (including all amounts outstanding under the new senior secured
credit facilities and the senior first lien notes), resulting in all or a portion of our assets being unavailable to satisfy the
claims of the holders of the senior notes and other unsecured indebtedness. Therefore, in the event of any distribution
or payment of our assets in any foreclosure, dissolution, winding-up, liquidation, reorganization or other bankruptcy
proceeding, holders of the senior notes will participate in our remaining assets ratably with each other and with all
holders of our unsecured indebtedness that is deemed to be of the same class as the senior notes, and potentially with
all of our other general creditors, based upon the respective amounts owed to each holder or creditor. In any of the
foregoing events, we cannot assure you that there will be sufficient assets to pay amounts due on the senior notes. As
a result, holders of the senior notes may receive less, ratably, than holders of our secured indebtedness.

As of November 1, 2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, the senior notes and
the related note guarantees would have ranked effectively junior to approximately $3,500 million of secured
indebtedness, and we would have an additional $750.0 million of anticipated availability under the new ABL facility
(without giving effect to the $62.0 million of letters of credit currently outstanding under the existing ABL facility
that are expected to remain outstanding under the new ABL facility), subject to a borrowing base. As of November 1,
2020, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor would have
had $4,650 million of indebtedness and $3,500 million of such indebtedness would have been secured. Under the
credit agreement that will govern the new ABL facility we may also request to increase the revolving commitments
by up to $500.0 million under the new ABL facility, subject to certain conditions being satisfied. The indentures that
will govern the notes and the credit agreements that will govern the new senior secured credit facilities will permit us
to incur additional secured indebtedness.

**_Federal and state fraudulent transfer laws may permit a court to void the notes and/or the note guarantees and, if_**
**_that occurs, you may not receive any payments on the notes._**

Our creditors and the creditors of the guarantors of the notes could challenge the issuance of the notes or the
guarantors’ issuance of their note guarantees, respectively, as fraudulent conveyances or on other grounds. In addition,
the incurrence of the affiliate guarantee by the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor may be subject to review under U.S.
federal bankruptcy law or relevant state fraudulent conveyance laws if a bankruptcy case or lawsuit is commenced by
or on behalf of the affiliate guarantors or its unpaid creditors, or by or on behalf of PetSmart or its unpaid creditors
(including as a result of the Chewy Equity Distribution) or the transferee of any Chewy common stock that is
substituted for Pledged Chewy Stock.

Under U.S. bankruptcy law and comparable provisions of state fraudulent transfer laws, a court could void
the issuance of the notes and/or a note guarantee or claims related to the notes or subordinate a note guarantee to all
of our other debts or to all other debts of a guarantor if, among other things, we or a guarantor, at the time we or such
guarantor incurred the indebtedness:

    - intended to hinder, delay or defraud any present or future creditor; or

    - received less than reasonably equivalent value or fair consideration for the delivery of the notes or
the guarantee, as the case may be, and if any Issuer or guarantor:

        - was insolvent or rendered insolvent by reason of such incurrence;

74


-----

        - was engaged in a business or transaction for which any Issuer’s or guarantor’s remaining
assets constituted unreasonably small capital; or

        - intended to incur, or believed that it would incur, debts beyond its ability to pay such debts
as they mature.

In addition, a court could void any payment by a guarantor pursuant to the notes or a note guarantee and
require that payment be returned to such guarantor or to a fund for the benefit of the creditors of the guarantor. If the
notes or note guarantees were avoided or limited under fraudulent transfer or other laws, any claim you may make
against the Issuers or the guarantors for amounts payable on the notes would be unenforceable to the extent of such
avoidance or limitation. Moreover, the court could order you to return any payments previously made by the Issuers
or the guarantors.

The measures of insolvency for purposes of fraudulent transfer laws will vary depending upon the governing
law in any proceeding to determine whether a fraudulent transfer has occurred. Generally, however, a party would be
considered insolvent if:

    - the sum of its debts, including contingent liabilities, was greater than the fair saleable value of all of
its assets;

    - the present fair saleable value of all of its assets was less than the amount that would be required to
pay its probable liability on its existing debts, including contingent liabilities, as they become
absolute and mature; or

    - it could not pay its debts as they become due.

We cannot be certain what standard a court would apply in making these determinations or, regardless of the
standard, that a court would not avoid the notes or note guarantees. It may be asserted (and a court may consequently
determine) that the guarantors incurred their note guarantees for the Issuers’ benefit and did not themselves receive a
direct or indirect benefit from the issuance of the senior notes or the senior first lien notes, as the case may be, such
that they incurred the obligations under the note guarantees for less than reasonably equivalent value or fair
consideration.

The indentures that will govern the notes will contain a “savings clause” intended to limit each guarantor’s
liability under its guarantee to the maximum amount that it could incur without causing the guarantee to be a fraudulent
transfer under applicable law. There can be no assurance that this provision will be upheld as intended.

**USE OF PROCEEDS**

We expect to use the net proceeds from this offering, together with the net proceeds of the equity contribution,
borrowings under the new term loan facility and cash on hand, to fund the early redemption, repurchase or
repayment (including by satisfaction and discharge) in full of the following outstanding debt, and to pay related fees,
costs, premiums and expenses in connection therewith:

(i) $2,716.1 million aggregate borrowings outstanding under PetSmart’s existing term loan facility.

(ii) $1,900.0 million aggregate principal amount outstanding due under PetSmart’s 7.125% senior notes
due 2023.

(iii) $1,141.6 million aggregate principal amount outstanding due under PetSmart’s 5.875% senior first
lien notes due 2025.

(iv) $650.0 million aggregate principal amount outstanding due under PetSmart’s 8.875% senior notes
due 2025.

Any remaining net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. This offering memorandum shall not
constitute a notice of redemption with respect to any of the foregoing series of notes or a notice of repayment with
respect to the existing term loan facility, and any redemption of our existing notes or repayment of our existing term
loan facility will be made in accordance with the terms and conditions of the relevant indenture or such existing term
loan facility, respectively.

Certain of the initial purchasers or their affiliates may be holders of our existing notes and/or lenders under our
existing term loan facility and will receive a pro rata portion of the net proceeds from this offering used to refinance
such indebtedness. In addition, certain of the initial purchasers or their affiliates are lenders and/or agents under our
existing ABL facility, new ABL facility, and new term loan facility and have received, or may in the future receive,
customary fees and commissions for transactions under such facilities. See “Plan of Distribution.”

**Overview**

PetSmart is North America’s leading specialty provider of products, services and solutions for the lifetime
needs of pets. Since opening its first store in 1987, the Company has grown to operate 1,650 stores in the United States,
Puerto Rico and Canada as of November 1, 2020. PetSmart serves a large group of pet owners it calls “pet parents,”
customers who are passionately committed to their pets and consider them members of the family. The Company is
committed to developing moment-making products, services and experiences for pet parents, including inviting pet
parents to shop with their pets, which the Company believes creates an enjoyable and memorable shopping experience.
PetSmart stores carry a broad assortment of high-quality pet supplies for all the life stages of pets, including nationally
recognized brand names as well as an extensive selection of private brands, across a range of product categories. The
Company complements its extensive product assortment with a wide selection of services, including professional
grooming and boarding for cats and dogs, as well as training and day camp for dogs. Most stores feature pet styling
salons that provide high-quality grooming services for dogs, and many of the pet styling salons provide services for
cats.

We intend (i) to distribute substantially concurrently with consummation of this offering in connection with
the Refinancing Transactions, directly or indirectly, to Holdings and Holdings intends to distribute to its parent or one
of such parent’s subsidiaries all shares of Chewy common stock currently directly held by us and (ii) to distribute or
otherwise transfer substantially concurrently with or at any time following consummation of this offering, directly or
indirectly, to Holdings and Holdings intends to distribute or otherwise transfer to its parent or one of such parent’s
subsidiaries the equity interests of one or more of our wholly owned subsidiaries that operate a portion of Chewy’s
online pet pharmacy business and/or the assets of any such subsidiary. Following completion of the Chewy
Distribution, we will not own any shares of Chewy common stock. Accordingly, neither Chewy nor any subsidiary of
Chewy will be a subsidiary of PetSmart. See “Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information of PetSmart.” This
management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operation includes the historical results of
operations of PetSmart on a consolidated basis (inclusive of Chewy), as well as the historical results of operations of
PetSmart excluding Chewy. Any discussion of PetSmart excluding Chewy does not purport to represent the results of
operations or financial position that PetSmart would actually obtain on a standalone basis if the Chewy Distribution
occurred at any date, nor does such discussion purport to project the results of operations for any future period.

A portion of the online pet pharmacy activity of Chewy.com legally resides within a wholly-owned subsidiary
of PetSmart, Inc. (the “Pharmacy Subsidiary”) outside of Chewy, Inc. We have combined the financial results of the
Pharmacy Subsidiary with the financial results of Chewy, Inc. since Chewy, Inc. operates the entire online pet
pharmacy business of Chewy.com, including the Pharmacy Subsidiary. We refer to Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries
plus the Pharmacy Subsidiary, collectively as “Chewy.” The Pharmacy Subsidiary and Chewy, Inc. are also parties to
a services agreement that provides for the payment of a management fee by the Pharmacy Subsidiary to Chewy, Inc.

is entitled to receive an amount equal to 25% of the Pharmacy Subsidiary’s net sales as fees for the services that it

stock and following the Pharmacy Distribution we will not own or have any economic or other interest in the Pharmacy

We complement our extensive product assortment with a wide selection of services, including professional
grooming and boarding for cats and dogs, as well as training and day camp for dogs. All of our stores feature pet
styling salons that provide high-quality grooming services for dogs, and many of our pet styling salons provide
services for cats. Several of our stores feature self-serve dog washes, and most of our stores offer comprehensive dog
training services. Our PetsHotels provide boarding for dogs and most of our PetsHotels provide boarding for cats.
This includes 24-hour supervision by caregivers who are trained to provide personalized pet care, temperaturecontrolled rooms and suites, air purification systems, daily specialty treats and play time, as well as day camp for
dogs. As of November 1, 2020 and February 2, 2020, we operated 207 and 208 PetsHotels, respectively.

We make full-service veterinary care available through strategic relationships with third-party operators. As
of November 1, 2020 and February 2, 2020, we had full-service veterinary hospitals in 809 and 848 of our stores,
respectively, of which 799 and 839, respectively, were operated by Medical Management International, Inc., which
does business as Banfield, The Pet Hospital. The remaining hospitals were operated by other third-parties. In addition,
we offer low cost vaccination and microchipping for dogs and cats through a third-party vaccination clinic provider
in many of our stores on a periodic basis.

The principal challenges we face as a business include the highly competitive market in which we operate
and volatility in the macro-economy. However, we believe we have a competitive advantage through our in-store and
online solutions for pet parents, which cannot be easily duplicated, including differentiated products and services for
pets, merchandising capabilities, omni-channel experience, and exceptional customer service as well as a growing
assortment and selection of private and exclusive brands and services. The recent outbreak of COVID-19, which was
declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on March 11, 2020 (the “Pandemic”), has led to adverse
impacts on the U.S. and global economies. While the sale of pet food and other merchandise for pets has generally
been considered essential, the Pandemic has created some supply chain challenges, including inventory shortages of
certain items and longer delivery times for online customers, as well as operational challenges, including those related
to accommodating social distancing guidelines required by various government orders. In particular, our services
business has been adversely impacted by government orders that prohibit or limit services we can provide, social
distancing guidelines that limit our capacity, and less demand for certain services due to reduced travel and more time
being spent at home. These and other effects of the Pandemic, including uncertainty in consumer demand, could
adversely impact our business in the future.

Nearly all of our stores remained opened during the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020. We
temporarily reduced our hours of operations in April for all of our stores; however, during the thirteen weeks ended
August 2, 2020, we began adding back these hours with most of our stores returning to normal hours of operations as
of November 1, 2020. Beginning on April 5, 2020 approximately half of our Canada stores were only open for online
orders shipped from stores and curbside pickup. On May 19, 2020, these Canadian stores reopened for in-store
transactions. These stores were again limited to online orders shipped from stores and curbside pickup beginning on
December 26, 2020 under an order that remains in place as of the date hereof. In addition, effective March 21, 2020,
we elected to temporarily suspend all grooming services for approximately two weeks in response to the Pandemic.
After this period, and following an evaluation of our grooming business and several changes to our processes, we
began to reopen our grooming operations where allowable under state and local orders. As of November 1, 2020,
nearly all of our grooming salons had reopened, however, a small percentage have been required to close under local

84


-----

orders, mostly in California and Canada, since that time. Our pet training services were closed from the start of the
Pandemic until June 8, 2020 when these services began to reopen where allowable under state and local orders.
However, class sizes were reduced to allow for social distancing. As of November 1, 2020, pet training services had
resumed in most of our stores. Substantially all of our PetsHotels were closed from the start of the Pandemic through
May 20, 2020 when these services began to reopen where allowable under state and local orders and in markets with
sufficient demand. The majority of PetsHotels had re-opened as of November 1, 2020.

We continue to actively monitor the situation and may take further actions that alter our operations as may
be required by federal, state or local authorities or that we determine are in the best interests of our associates,
customers, suppliers, vendors and the overall business. While the disruption is currently expected to be temporary,
there is uncertainty regarding its duration, and it is possible that the Pandemic could worsen. Any such disruptions or
worsening of the Pandemic could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

**Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates**

The discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based on our consolidated
financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with GAAP. The preparation of these consolidated
financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities,
revenues, and expenses. We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions we believe
to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying
values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Although we believe that the judgments
and estimates discussed herein are reasonable, actual results may deviate from our expectations under different
assumptions or conditions, which could expose us to material gains or losses.

Unless specifically indicated below, we have not significantly changed accounting methodologies or
assumptions applied in calculating our estimates during the last three years. We do not believe there are any specific
sensitivities of our estimates and assumptions that are reasonably likely to cause a material difference between
expected results and actual results.

We determined that the following accounting policies and estimates require significant judgment and are
critical in preparing our consolidated financial statements. Further, as of November 1, 2020, we have not made any
significant changes to our critical accounting policies since February 2, 2020.

**_Inventory Valuation Reserves_**

Merchandise inventories represent finished goods and are recorded at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
We use a combination of the moving average cost method and the first-in first-out (FIFO) method when determining
the value of inventory. Inventory balances include inbound freight and customs fees on imported products.

We have established reserves for estimated inventory shrinkage between physical inventories. Physical
inventory counts are taken on a regular basis in our stores and inventory is adjusted accordingly. Stores generally
perform physical inventories at least once per year and count certain inventory items between physical inventories.
Distribution and fulfillment centers perform cycle counts on a regular basis. For each reporting period presented, we
estimate the inventory shrinkage based on historical trends. Changes in shrink results or market conditions could cause
actual results to vary from estimates used to establish the reserves.

We also have reserves for estimated inventory obsolescence and to reduce merchandise inventory to the lower
of cost or net realizable value. We evaluate inventory for excess, obsolescence, or other factors that may render
inventories unmarketable at historical cost. Factors used in determining obsolescence reserves, which are recorded to
reflect approximate net realizable value of our inventories, include current and anticipated demand, customer
preferences, age of merchandise, seasonal trends, and decisions to discontinue certain products. If assumptions about
future demand change, or actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, we may
require additional reserves.

As of November 1, 2020 and November 3, 2019, our inventory valuation reserves were $18.7 million and
$22.9 million, respectively.

**_Impairment of Goodwill and Indefinite-lived Intangible Assets_**

Goodwill consists of the excess of the consideration transferred to the acquired enterprises over the sum of
the amounts assigned to identifiable assets acquired less liabilities assumed. Goodwill is reviewed for impairment
annually during the fourth quarter, or more frequently if impairment indicators arise. We have determined the
consolidated reporting entity to have the following two operating units which also represent two separate reporting
units for the purpose of testing goodwill for impairment: PetSmart and Chewy.

We may elect to assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value
of our reporting units is less than the carrying amount prior to performing a quantitative impairment test. If this is the
case, a quantitative impairment test is required. If it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of the reporting unit is

88


-----

not less than its carrying amount, a quantitative impairment test is not required. If a quantitative impairment test is
required, or if we choose to bypass the optional qualitative assessment, the fair value of the reporting unit is compared
to its carrying amount (including goodwill). If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then
a goodwill impairment charge is recognized for the amount by which the reporting unit’s carrying amount exceeds its
fair value. The fair value of a reporting unit under the quantitative impairment test is determined using a combination
of valuation methodologies, including a discounted cash flow analysis, a guideline public company analysis, and a
guideline transaction analysis. No goodwill impairments were identified for 2019, 2018, or 2017.

When evaluating indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment, we may first perform a qualitative
assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that an intangible asset group is impaired. In performing
this qualitative assessment, we evaluate if changes in events or circumstances have occurred that indicate that
impairment may exist. If we do not perform a qualitative impairment assessment or if changes in events and
circumstances indicate that a quantitative assessment should be performed, we are required to calculate the fair value
of the intangible asset group.

Our impairment analyses contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and
to apply judgment to qualitative factors as well as estimate future cash flows and asset fair values, including forecasting
prospective financial information and selecting a discount rate that reflects the risk inherent in future cash flows.

No impairments of indefinite-lived intangible assets were identified in 2019. For 2018, we recognized
impairment charges totaling $269.4 million related to the indefinite-lived trade name of PetSmart. For 2017, we
recognized impairment charges totaling $405.5 million related to the indefinite-lived trade names of PetSmart and our
wholly-owned subsidiary, Pet360.

**_Long-lived Asset Impairments_**

We review property and equipment for impairment based on undiscounted cash flows on a quarterly basis
and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be
recoverable. If this review indicates that the carrying amount of the property and equipment is not recoverable, we
recognize an impairment loss, which is determined by calculating the fair value of the assets using estimated
discounted cash flows. We recognized impairment charges for property and equipment of $13.0 million, $4.8 million,
and $5.5 million related to under-performing stores, stores that were scheduled to be closed, and natural disasters for
2019, 2018, and 2017, respectively.

We review definite-lived intangible assets for impairment on a quarterly basis and whenever events or
changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. If this review
indicates that the carrying amount of the definite-lived intangible assets is not recoverable, we recognize an
impairment loss, which is measured at fair value using estimated discounted cash flows. Our impairment analyses
contain uncertainties because they require management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimated
future cash flows and asset fair values.

No material impairments of our definite-lived intangible assets were identified in 2019 or 2018. For 2017,
we recognized an impairment charge of $6.3 million primarily related to the definite-lived intangible assets of Pet360.

**_Customer Loyalty Program_**

During the third quarter of 2018, we completed the implementation of a customer loyalty program, PetSmart
Treats, in which members earn points primarily based on purchases in our stores and on PetSmart.com. The points
earned are a distinct promise from the original purchase that can be exchanged for future goods or services, which
creates a performance obligation for the Company to provide goods or services until those points are redeemed or
expire.

The Company allocates revenue to points earned on qualifying purchases and defers recognition until the
points are redeemed. The amount of revenue deferred is based on the relative stand-alone selling price method, which
includes an estimate for points not expected to be redeemed. The estimated redemption rate is based on historical

89


-----

experience and other assumptions. The estimates are evaluated on an on-going basis. The Company defers the value
of points earned that are estimated to be redeemed at the time of the initial purchase in other current liabilities on the
Consolidated Balance Sheets until the points are redeemed. As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, deferred
revenue related to the PetSmart Treats program was $29.5 million and $19.9 million, respectively.

**_Insurance Liabilities and Reserves_**

We maintain workers’ compensation, general liability, product liability, property insurance and other types
of insurance policies related to our operations, properties, and leasehold interests. For some associates, we maintain
full coverage health insurance plans. For all other eligible associates, we maintain self-insured health plans. Workers’
compensation policies generally carry a $1.0 million per occurrence deductible exposure. Our general liability policies
specify a $1.0 million per occurrence self-insured retention. We establish reserves for claims under workers’
compensation and general liability plans based on periodic actuarial estimates of the amount of loss for all pending
claims, including estimates for claims that have been incurred but not reported. Our loss estimates rely on actuarial
observations of ultimate loss experience for similar historical events, and changes in such assumptions could result in
an adjustment, favorable or adverse, to our reserves. As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, we had
approximately $81.7 million and $79.6 million, respectively, in reserves related to workers’ compensation, general
liability, and self-insured health plans, of which $46.9 million and $48.1 million were classified as other noncurrent
liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets. A 10% change in our insurance reserves would have affected net
income by approximately $6.7 million for 2019.

**_Income Taxes_**

Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized for temporary differences between the financial
statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their corresponding tax bases. Deferred taxes are
measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the assets or liabilities are expected to be realized.
Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance for any portion that is not more likely than not to be realized.

The Company records a liability for unrecognized tax benefits resulting from uncertain tax positions taken
or expected to be taken in a tax return. The Company records interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits
as income tax expense.

As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, our unrecognized tax benefits were approximately $31.9
million and $31.7 million, respectively.

**_Leases_**

We adopted the new Lease Standard under ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842), as of the first day of fiscal
year 2019. Under the Lease Standard, our accounting for leases may involve significant assumptions and judgments
to identify the underlying real estate space or equipment subject to the lease and the incremental borrowing rate used
to discount the lease obligation over the lease term. We record operating and finance lease right of use, or ROU, assets
based on the sum of the initial measurement of the lease liability adjusted for initial direct costs and lease incentives.
We measure the operating and finance lease obligations based on the present value of the future lease payments over
the lease term at the commencement date. The initial measurement of the ROU assets and lease obligations include
fixed payments included in our lease agreements. We elected the practical expedient to account for each separate lease
component and non-lease component associated with our leases as a single lease component for real estate leases.
Rental payments are recognized as a reduction of the operating and finance lease obligations. Operating lease expense
is recorded on a straight-line basis over the lease term. We depreciate finance lease ROU assets over the term of the
lease and recognize the related interest expense. We recognize lease payments of short-term leases on a straight-line
basis over the lease term. Adjustments to lease payments due to inflation subsequent to lease commencement are
recognized in the period in which the obligation for those payments is incurred.

**_Gross Profit_**

Gross profit as a percentage of net sales decreased 20 basis points to 25.7% in 2019, compared to 25.9% in
2018. Beginning in fiscal year 2018, in connection with our annual vendor negotiations, PetSmart made changes to
certain merchandise vendor contracts which allow us greater flexibility in the way we use certain vendor allowances.
As a result of these changes, these vendor allowances are recorded as a reduction to the carrying value of our inventory
and, therefore, are ultimately recognized as a reduction to cost of merchandise sales on our Consolidated Statements
of Operations and Comprehensive Loss when the inventory is sold. Under our vendor contracts prior to fiscal year
2018, these vendor allowances were recognized as a direct reduction to either cost of merchandise sales or operating,
general, and administrative expense on our Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss,
depending on the nature of the underlying activities. As a result, we experienced a lag in the timing of recognizing
vendor funding during fiscal year 2018 as we sold through inventory purchased prior to fiscal year 2018. The estimated
impact of this timing lag was $77.1 million for 2018 when comparing to 2019.

Excluding Chewy and the $77.1 million timing lag in 2018 as a result of the change in our vendor allowances
terms, PetSmart’s gross profit as a percentage of net sales decreased 110 basis points to 32.9% for 2019 compared to
34.0% for 2018. The decrease was primarily driven by merchandise cost increases. PetSmart’s gross profit as a
percentage of net sales in 2018 included a favorable 20 basis points attributable to the extra week in 2018.

Chewy’s gross profit as a percentage of net sales increased 350 basis points to 15.2% for 2019 compared to
11.7% for 2018. The increase was primarily driven by margin expansion across all verticals, including improvements
in margin profits of pharmacy and private brands. The extra week in 2018 was not material to Chewy’s gross profit.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Cash Flow_**

As part of our new senior secured credit facilities, PetSmart expects to have access to a $750.0 million
revolving credit facility (without giving effect to the $62.0 million of letters of credit currently outstanding under the
existing ABL facility that are expected to remain outstanding under the new ABL facility), subject to a borrowing
base.

Our new senior secured credit facilities will contain customary representations, warranties, affirmative and
negative covenants, and events of default and cross-default. The negative covenants will include restrictions on our
ability to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay dividends, create liens, make investments, give
guarantees, sell assets, merge, or consolidate. See “Description of Other Indebtedness.”

We believe that our operating cash flow and cash on hand will be adequate to meet our recurring operating,
investing, and financing needs in the foreseeable future. However, on March 18, 2020, after the end of fiscal year
2019, we borrowed $300.0 million under the existing ABL facility as a precautionary action due to the risks and
uncertainty caused by the Pandemic. We did not use any of these funds, and as such we repaid the $300.0 million in
full during the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020. PetSmart has significant cash on hand and has access to
the remaining borrowing capacity under the existing ABL facility through December 2021, subject to a borrowing
base. There can be no assurance of our ability to access credit markets after the consummation of this offering on
commercially acceptable terms in the future. We continuously assess the economic environment and market conditions
to guide our decisions regarding our uses of cash, including capital expenditures, investments, dividends, and longterm debt requirements. Additionally, we continue to actively monitor the Pandemic and may take further actions that
alter our operations as may be required by federal, state or local authorities or that we determine are in the best interests
of our associates, customers, suppliers, vendors and shareholders. As a result, the Pandemic may continue to have an
impact on our results of operations, which could include decreases to our Adjusted EBITDA and Free Cash Flow in
fiscal year 2021.

We typically fund our operations, new stores, distribution and fulfillment centers, PetsHotel openings, store

fulfillment centers, and the subsequent payment for that inventory. Cash is primarily used in operating activities to
fund procurement of merchandise inventories and other assets, net of accounts payable and other accrued liabilities,
as well as service interest on our indebtedness.

**_Seasonality and Inflation_**

Our business is subject to moderate seasonal fluctuations, notwithstanding the impact of the Pandemic. We
typically realize a slightly higher portion of net sales and operating profits during our fourth quarter, as compared to
our other quarters, due to increased holiday traffic. As a result of this seasonality, we believe that quarter-to-quarter
comparisons of our operating results are not necessarily meaningful and that these comparisons cannot be relied upon
as indicators of future performance. Because our stores typically draw customers from a large trade area, sales may
also be impacted by adverse weather or travel conditions, which are more prevalent for certain seasons of the year.
The timing of new store, PetsHotel, distribution or fulfillment center, and customer service center openings and related
preopening costs, the amount of revenue contributed by new and existing stores and PetsHotels, and the timing and
estimated obligations of facility closures, may cause our quarterly results of operations to fluctuate. Controllable
expenses could fluctuate from quarter-to-quarter in a year. Finally, because new stores tend to experience higher

101


-----

payroll, advertising, and other store level expenses as a percentage of net sales as compared to mature stores, new
store openings also contribute to lower store operating margins until these stores become established.

While we cannot determine the full effect of inflation and deflation on our operations, we believe our sales
and results of operations are affected by both. We have been able to largely mitigate the effect by adjusting retail
prices accordingly. We can make no assurance that our business will not be affected by inflation or deflation in the
future.

**BUSINESS**

**PetSmart Overview**

PetSmart is North America’s leading specialty provider of products, services and solutions for the lifetime
needs of pets. Since opening its first store in 1987, the Company has grown to operate 1,650 stores in the United
States, Puerto Rico and Canada as of November 1, 2020. PetSmart serves a large group of pet owners it calls “pet
parents,” customers who are passionately committed to their pets and consider them members of the family. The
Company is committed to developing moment-making products, services and experiences for pet parents, including
inviting pet parents to shop with their pets, which the Company believes creates an enjoyable and memorable shopping
experience.

PetSmart stores carry a broad assortment of high-quality pet supplies for all the life stages of pets, including
nationally recognized brand names as well as an extensive selection of private brands, across a range of product
categories. The Company complements its extensive product assortment with a wide selection of services, including
professional grooming and boarding for cats and dogs, as well as training and day camp for dogs. Most stores feature
pet styling salons that provide high-quality grooming services for dogs, and many of the pet styling salons provide
services for cats. The business generated $7.6 billion in pro forma net sales and $1,269.0 million in pro forma Adjusted
EBITDA for the twelve months ended November 1, 2020.

**_PetSmart at a Glance [(1) ]_**

**_Retail Footprint_**

PetSmart has an extensive retail footprint with significant presence across the core U.S. market. Of its 1,650
stores, 91% are located in the U.S., with the remaining 9% in Canada and Puerto Rico. Stores are strategically located,
with a geographically diversified presence across favorable demographic profiles. For example, stores are in regions
with 1.5x the average U.S. household income and where population growth is expected to be 1.5x larger than recent

103


-----

historical rates in the U.S., based on U.S. census data. Furthermore, as of the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, more
than 60% of PetSmart’s revenue was generated from stores with strong co-tenancy (a major retailer such as Target,
Walmart, Costco, Home Depot, Lowe’s or a grocer), which serves to enhance customer traffic in the area. Very few
stores are located in enclosed malls.

**_Recent Focus_**

The Company’s portfolio of stores generates strong margins and cash flows. Following acceleration of online
growth from Chewy and Amazon in 2016 and movement of two of the largest channel-exclusive brands into the Food,
Drug and Mass (“FDM”) channel in 2016 and 2017, PetSmart has shifted its strategy to focus on services, private
brands and specialty products as well as improved merchandising strategy to bring in new and growing brands to
enhance its value proposition to pet parents, which have provided PetSmart with a path to recovery and further growth.
As such, comparable sales have seen continuous sequential improvement over the last two years, reaching positive
comparable sales in the second half of fiscal year 2019 and accelerating through the COVID-19 pandemic. Over the
long-term, comparable sales continue to benefit from positive trends around new pet ownership, increased consumer
spending and continued humanization of pets.

PetSmart leverages growing omni-channel capabilities to enhance its leading brick and mortar position and
to meet the changing needs of customers. The omni-channel offering consists of BOPIS including curbside pickup,
STH, and SFS. PetSmart also has a partnership with DoorDash Inc., a digital delivery service provider, where the
Company partners to provide on-demand, same-day delivery service to customers across 1,618 retail locations.
Despite a number of e-commerce options available for pet parents throughout the pandemic, customers have continued
shopping at PetSmart whether in-store or through omni-channel offerings. The omni-channel strategy is focused on
complementing the core brick and mortar business, positioning PetSmart to continue to gain market share in the
growing brick and mortar pet retail category.

With over 40 million member profiles, the Treats™ loyalty program provides rich customer data to better
understand consumer preferences and purchasing trends. This large customer database gives PetSmart a competitive
edge in data intelligence over smaller competitors.

**_Merchandise_**

healthcare and supplements, flea and tick, travel, containment, waste management, etc.); and specialty, which includes
fresh-water fish, small birds, reptiles and other small pets as well as the consumables and hard goods for them.
Merchandise accounted for 87% of the Company’s total net sales for the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, with
consumables, hardgoods and specialty contributing 46%, 27% and 13%, respectively. PetSmart carries the largest pet
merchandise assortment among pet specialty, mass, grocery or other discount retailers, with over 19,500 SKUs and
more than 700 unique brands offered in retail locations and on petsmart.com and onlynaturalpet.com, including
nationally recognized brands as well as an extensive selection of private brands across a wide range of product
categories. The product portfolio is also well-diversified, with no third-party brand representing more than 5% of pro
forma total merchandise sales.

105


-----

Within consumables, PetSmart emphasizes channel-exclusive natural, science-based and therapeutic pet
foods, many of which are not available in grocery stores, warehouse clubs or other mass and general merchandise
retailers. In addition to channel-exclusive products described below, PetSmart offers private brands as well as widely
distributed quality brands in order to provide pet parents with a broad selection of consumables products.

The hardgoods offering is differentiated due to its broad value range, its curated selection and extensive
private and exclusive offerings driven by innovation generated by in-house product development and direct sourcing
capabilities. PetSmart designs and sources a significant portion of hardgoods and specialty items through its product
development office in Phoenix, Arizona, and two sourcing offices in Shanghai and Hong Kong. PetSmart has the
largest selection of products within the brick and mortar pet retail segment.

The specialty offering is a key differentiator against competitors who do not offer live animals or products
for specialty pets, which PetSmart believes serve as an entry point to pet ownership for many younger pet parents.
Also, the in-store fish wall and habitats with reptiles, birds and small and furry pets create a theater to drive traffic.

The Company’s position as the #1 pet care destination, strong relationships with leading product vendors and
educated, passionate and highly trained in-store employees (“associates”) allow PetSmart to offer products that are
exclusively sold (“channel-exclusive”) by pet specialty retailers and not through other retail channels. PetSmart also
offers a selection of private brands across consumables, hardgoods and specialty, which represented approximately
30% of merchandise sales for the fiscal year ended February 2, 2020, reflecting an approximately 700 basis points

106


-----

increase in penetration over the last five years. The private consumables offering includes products exclusively sold
at PetSmart and Chewy, such as the Simply Nourish®, Authority® and Only Natural Pet® brands, which generally
carry higher margins than similar branded product. Customers purchasing widely distributed consumables brands
often purchase higher margin hardgoods and specialty products as well, resulting in a positive ticket and creating an
opportunity to upsell these customers to channel exclusive consumables.

**_Services_**

PetSmart is the #1 pet services provider in North America. In substantially all stores, the Company offers
both professional grooming in dedicated salons and specialized training services. It also offers boarding through 207
PetsHotels and veterinary care through 809 third-party pet hospitals which are co-located within stores. The services
offering allows the Company to build trust and loyalty with customers, driving increased traffic to stores and
differentiating the Company from competitors across channels, including specialty retailers, mass, grocery, and online.
Importantly, services cannot be offered online, thus shielding PetSmart from e-commerce competitors. Over the last
five years through fiscal year 2019, services penetration as a percentage of overall PetSmart sales has increased
approximately 120 basis points to 12.4%. Internal data suggests that customers who purchase services transact 1.7x
more regularly and spend 2.1x more annually than non-services customers, and PetSmart estimates that more than
half of services customers also purchase goods. The Company believes that no competitor comes close to its breadth
of services and physical coverage.

**Our Strategy**

PetSmart is committed to developing differentiated, moment-making products, services and experiences that
will attract and retain pet parents as loyal PetSmart customers. The Company has significant opportunities to further
enhance its leadership position in the pet care industry and improve the productivity of stores.

PetSmart believes it has a competitive advantage through unique in-store and omnnichannel solutions for pet
parents, including differentiated products and services for pets and exceptional customer service. The Company’s

107


-----

stores and websites (petsmart.com and onlynaturalpet.com) carry a broad assortment of high-quality pet merchandise
across consumables, hardgoods and what the Company refers to as the “specialty” category. The comprehensive
merchandise offering, with over 19,500 SKUs and more than 700 unique brands offered in retail locations and on
petsmart.com, caters to a wide range of pet parents and provides nearly every item needed to satisfy the lifetime needs
of their pets. In addition, the growing assortment and selection of private and exclusive brands enhance customer
loyalty. PetSmart is also the leading provider of pet services (e.g., professional grooming, boarding, training, day
camp, etc.) in the U.S., Canada and Puerto Rico, further strengthening the Company’s value proposition to customers
and differentiating from others in the pet space. PetSmart maintains a content website to further engage with
customers.

PetSmart will continue to focus on driving comparable sales, expanding margins and generating Free Cash
Flow through the following key business strategies:

**_Winning through a disciplined approach to growth_**

PetSmart’s business is anchored by four key management principles: be efficient, be margin-focused, be
consumer-insight driven and be an aggressive competitor through continued share gains in brick and mortar. PetSmart
has been able to generate cost savings through increased labor efficiencies within stores and rent savings, both of
which have become particularly important during the COVID-19 pandemic. These four principles have informed the
Company’s overarching strategy since BC Partners took ownership. PetSmart has dedicated significant time and
resources to increasing efficiency, improving its margin profile, refining its customer analytics and competing
aggressively with competitors across channels.

**_Enhancing value proposition by complementing our competitive advantages in brick and mortar with omni-_**
**_channel capabilities_**

PetSmart continues to focus on winning market share in the growing brick and mortar pet retail category by
providing best-in-class in-store merchandise and service offerings complemented by convenient omni-channel
capabilities. Brick and mortar pet retail category has demonstrated resilience despite industry shift to online, growing
by a CAGR of 0.3% from 2015 to 2019, while online penetration increased from just 7% to 22% during that same
time period. Outside of online, brick and mortar is still expected to represent approximately 65% of pet products in
2024, which implies a future expected growth of 1.5%-2.0% per annum. We believe PetSmart is uniquely positioned
to benefit from this growth with its nationwide reach, unmatched merchandise portfolio, which includes new emerging
brands, private brands and specialty, and its robust service offerings, creating a preferred destination for pet parents
and their pets’ everyday needs. PetSmart’s omni-channel capabilities complement the Company’s in-store offering by
providing multiple avenues for customers to interact with PetSmart, driving loyalty and traffic to stores. PetSmart
focuses its efforts on building capabilities designed to drive value through the store base as evidenced by recent
investments made in BOPIS, the preferred omni-channel option for customers, representing 75% of pro forma omnichannel sales for the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020, and the PRISM scheduling system, an online and
app-based scheduling tool for services. These investments are designed to enhance the store base profitability and
provide an omni-channel experience for customers while not impacting free cash flow generation. PetSmart also offers
STH and SFS at select locations, as well as a same-day delivery service through its new partnership with DoorDash
Inc., providing an on-demand option to customers.

In addition, PetSmart engages with customers through its leading websites, petsmart.com (one of the most
visited pet websites in the U.S.) and onlynaturalpet.com, and its PetSmart app. Pet education resources available on
these digital channels enhance brand value and drive in-store visits and services sales.

PetSmart will continue to leverage omni-channel capabilities to connect with customers, enhance the in-store
experience and drive store traffic to execute on its core strategy to continue being the leading brick and mortar pet
retailer.

**_Providing pet parents with the largest assortment of pet products with a focus on new and growing brands, private_**
**_brands and specialty products_**

108


-----

PetSmart carries the widest assortment of products across pet merchandise categories, from the value end to
premium end of the product spectrum, and from widely distributed to private or exclusive. Furthermore, the Company
makes it a priority to focus on offering a curated and unique assortment of products that is not widely available for pet
parents by competitors. PetSmart believes in diversifying its brand exposure and enhancing its merchandise offering
with new and growing brands, private brands and specialty. Channel-exclusive brands further drive customer loyalty.
The strategic focus is to continue to execute on and expand merchandising capabilities in key areas including:

     - _Newness to the store: PetSmart is constantly looking to capitalize on new trends, find emerging_
product categories and add new brands to the portfolio, whether from existing vendors or new
entrants to the industry. Introducing newness to the store and pursuing innovative brands and
products remains a key strategic priority, and PetSmart plans to continue to add differentiated and
innovative brands to its product assortment each year. PetSmart also offers a large assortment of
private brands which further drives innovation and new experiences in-store. PetSmart will continue
to work closely with vendors in order to deliver a diverse and relevant product offering at
competitive prices.

     - _Private brands: Private brands are only sold by PetSmart and in limited cases, Chewy, and generate_
significant value for the platform. Private brands guarantee exclusivity, have more attractive
margins than non-private brand products and have protected pricing given the absence of a direct
price comparison. Private brand customers are significantly more valuable than the overall
population, spending more on non-private brand products and shopping more frequently, while also
having a longer overall tenure. Through introducing new brands and improving upon existing
brands, PetSmart, excluding Chewy, has grown private and exclusive penetration from 20% of pro
forma merchandise sales in fiscal year 2011 to over 33% of pro forma merchandise sales during the
twelve month period ended November 1, 2020. The private brand portfolio includes brands such as
Authority, Only Natural Pet and Simply Nourish in Consumables, Top Paw, Arcadia Trail and
Whisker City in hardgoods, and Thrive, All Living Things and Top Fin in specialty. PetSmart
expects to further build on the success of the Company’s private brands and incorporate new
PetSmart-exclusive formulations and sub-brands.

     - _Specialty: The specialty category is an area of differentiation for PetSmart as many of its brick and_
mortar competitors cannot match the Company’s breadth in specialty products or customer service
expertise. Further, as customers cannot easily buy live pets online, specialty is partially insulated
from e-commerce competition. Specialty customers are more likely to be repeat visitors and also
tend to shop more frequently on average than the overall population, presenting incremental upside
for cross-sell opportunities. Over the last five years, PetSmart has increased its specialty category
penetration by approximately 130 basis points while expanding category market share in both brick
and mortar and pet specialty retail by approximately 200 basis points. PetSmart’s differentiated
capabilities in specialty uniquely position the Company to further capitalize on this attractive pet
category.

**_Growing and expanding on our comprehensive service offerings to improve the pet parent experience_**

Over the past twenty years, PetSmart has built from the ground up the leading services offering in the pet
industry, and continues to grow this integral part of the business which serves as a key differentiator versus competitors
across brick and mortar and e-commerce. Services include professional grooming, boarding, training, day camp and
other offerings. Unable to be replicated online, the services business drives store traffic, builds customer loyalty, and
shields PetSmart from e-commerce competitors. It also allows for cross-selling and upselling opportunities as
PetSmart acts as a “one stop shop” for customers. Services customers are significantly more valuable than the overall
population, spending more on merchandise, shopping more frequently, and having a longer average tenure.

PetSmart made important investments in the services business over the past two years, which helped increase
productivity and improve customer experience. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic and the suspension of certain
services offerings, the services segment performed well with 3.8% comparable sales growth during the third fiscal
quarter of 2019 and 6.4% during the fourth fiscal quarter of 2019. Technological improvements around customer

109


-----

booking, appointment management, and payment process enabled by the new PRISM scheduling system provides for
a seamless customer experience and drove an increase in appointment capacity of approximately 15%. Other digital
innovations support marketing efforts to drive demand, reduce inefficiencies in administrative tasks, and improve
cancellation rates via automated appointment reminders. The Company also allocated additional staffing to the
services business, increasing the number of groomers to improve productivity, enabling salons to support their
projections. PetSmart remains focused on improving the quality and consistency of services through extensive,
structured training of employees in all pet services areas. There is an opportunity to further enhance average
transaction value by equipping store associates with tools that better enable them to identify pet parents’ needs and
provide appropriate solutions.

The non-medical pet services category represents the fastest growing retail category based on three-year
historical growth from 2017 to 2019, representing a CAGR of over 6%. Furthermore, spending on non-medical pet
services from 2014 to 2017 grew at over 7%. As the leading pet services provider in a highly fragmented market,
PetSmart is well-positioned to benefit from the strong market dynamics and remain focused on services as a key
strategic priority.

**_Continuing to support pet-related charitable works, including adoptions, which drive pet ownership and creates_**
**_goodwill for the brand_**

Customer analytics show that charitable endeavors are among the top drivers of customer loyalty and buying
intent for PetSmart stores. PetSmart provides space in most stores for pet adoptions through a partnership with
PetSmart Charities (an independent non-profit organization). PetSmart Charities facilitates more pet adoptions than
any other organization with approximately 20% of all pets adopted in the United States in 2019 through PetSmart
stores in partnership with 4,000 animal welfare organizations. In March 2020, PetSmart Charities marked its most
successful national adoption weekend event in its 25-year history, facilitating the adoption of nearly 33,000 pets. This
event brought total pets adopted through PetSmart Charities to 9.2 million. PetSmart Charities is the leading funder
of animal welfare in North America.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Large and Attractive Industry Growing at Approximately 5% Historically_**

The pet care industry is a large and highly attractive category. Supported by secular tailwinds including
increased pet ownership, the continued humanization of pets and the premiumization of pet food, the category reached
$95 billion in total sales in 2019. The sector has also demonstrated higher growth than any other category within retail,
growing at a CAGR of approximately 5% from 2014 to 2019. This growth trajectory is anticipated to continue, as the
forecasted CAGR from 2020 through 2024 is 5.7%.

110


-----

**U.S. Pet Retail Sales (dollars in billions)**

**Historical Segment Growth (2017-2019 CAGR)**

The pet care industry is also one of the most recessionary resistant categories, as increased adoption rates and
effects of pet humanization more than offset any decreases in household spending during economic downturns. During
the last recession, total category CAGR of approximately 6% was driven by an increase in pet ownership, partially
offset by a slight decrease in average household spending on pet products according to the American Pet Products
Association (“APPA”). Pet parents have consistently reduced spending on their pets less than on themselves during
recessionary events, and this trend has continued during the COVID pandemic.

111


-----

**Pet Care Performance through the “Great Recession” (dollars in billions)**

**_Secular Industry Tailwinds Accelerating with COVID-19 Pandemic_**

The COVID-19 pandemic has further accelerated tailwinds supporting the sector, including increased pet
ownership, the continued humanization of pets and the premiumization of pet food. Pet adoption rates have increased
through the COVID-19 pandemic as the U.S. population has turned to pets to support mental and physical well-being
during periods of self-isolation. In addition, stay-at-home orders and flexible work schedules have given households
the freedom to care for new pets as people spend more time at home. In 2020, the number of pet-owning households
in the United States is expected to increase by 4% year-over-year, reaching approximately 71 million.

In total, it is estimated that approximately 41.0% (or 51.3 million) of households owned dogs and 25.0% (or
31.4 million) of households owned cats as pets in the United States in calendar year 2020, representing a growth in
number of dog and cat owning households by 5% and 4% respectively compared to 2019. In addition, younger
consumers are spending more money on their pets, with a lower percentage of Millennials (ages 19-36) reporting that
they are “budget-conscious” with regards to pet care spending as compared to older pet parents. The “premiumization”
of pet food has also increased customer’s ticket size, and the longer average lives of pets has increased the number of
purchases over the duration of a pet’s life.

**U.S. Pet Households (in millions) and Approach to Spending**

**Humanization and Premiumization Trends Are Key Growth Drivers to the Industry**

Pet supply and pet food retailers are expected to collectively experience an acceleration of growth to 7.7%
(excluding services) in fiscal year 2020, supported by their classification as essential businesses during the COVID19 pandemic. Additionally, there is a positive tailwind coming from increased pet adoptions during quarantine, which
is expected to translate to an increase of 4% year-over-year of pet owning households in fiscal year 2020 and we
believe should offset any trade-down as a result of economic challenges.

Both medical and non-medical pet services (e.g., grooming, trainings, hotel, etc.) have been affected by the
COVID-19 pandemic as they were forced to close or operate at reduced capacity due to social distancing requirements.

**_Leading Pet Specialty Brick and Mortar Retailer Gaining Share in Its Channel_**

The pet specialty brick and mortar channel has demonstrated resiliency as the broader retail industry has
shifted online. Although the total pet specialty brick and mortar channel has experienced a 1.0% annual decline since
2015 due to the shift to online and FDM, there has been a clear divergence of performance within the category.
Independent pet specialty players have decreased by almost 40% since 2015, while the larger pet specialty chains have
grown at 2.8% per year, with PetSmart gaining 3 points of share of the pet specialty and other brick and mortar channel.
These trends are likely to continue, as: (i) additional independent pet specialty channels are forced to close due to
performance and liquidity constraints; (ii) customers demand an increase in BOPIS and omni-channel solutions which
require significant investments and scale; (iii) larger stores offer broader product selection and cover the greatest
number of pet species; and (iv) services offerings continue to drive revenue.

**_Services, Private Brands and Specialty Offerings Create a Competitive “Moat” and Support Leading Market_**
**_Position_**

PetSmart’s services, private brands and specialty products provide a protective “moat” against competitors,
as they are not available (or widely available) through other channels. These protective moats have a direct impact on
revenue, as 38% of the transactions in 2019 on a pro forma basis included services, private brands or specialty
products. Additionally, these unique capabilities help drive ancillary revenue, as 60% of total purchases in 2019 on a
pro forma basis were made by customers who have purchased at least one of these items.

PetSmart’s Full Suite of Service Offerings Drive Customer Traffic and Loyalty

**Value of Services Customers**

Private Brands Guarantee Exclusivity and Offer Higher Margins

PetSmart’s private brands presence generates value for the platform in two ways. First, the private brand
margins are more attractive than that of non-private brand products (and are generally priced competitively with
similar third-party brands). Second, as PetSmart’s private brands are only available in PetSmart stores, it provides a
good defensive mechanism as compared to both online and brick and mortar competitors and protects pricing given
the absence of a direct price comparison. Private brands customers are significantly more valuable than the overall
population, spending more outside of private brands, shopping more frequently, with longer overall tenure.

Over the last 5 years through the end of fiscal year 2019, PetSmart’s penetration of private brands has
increased 700 basis points to approximately 30% of merchandise, as it has introduced new selection (e.g., Tiny Tales
hamster habitats, Thrive Reptile brand) and improved upon existing brands (e.g., reformulation/rebranding of
Authority food and All Living Things small animal consumables).

**Value of Private Brand Customers**

Specialty Provides a Strong Moat against Online Competitors as Live Pets Cannot be Sold Online

The specialty category sells live animals, habitats, food, and accessories related to fish, reptiles, birds, and
small animals, and is an area of differentiation for PetSmart. As customers cannot buy live pets online, the segment is
partially insulated from e-commerce competition; beyond that, many of PetSmart’s brick and mortar competitors
cannot match PetSmart’s depth in specialty products.

This differentiation creates a stable book of business, as well as an opportunity to drive repeat business from
customers who initially buy an animal (often with a habitat and accessories), and return for various consumables (i.e.,
food, water filters, etc.). For the last twelve months ended November 1, 2020 versus the same prior year period,
PetSmart’s share of specialty has been up 407 basis points within the pet specialty channel and up 318 basis points
within brick and mortar, reaching 43.9% and 23.4%, respectively. Specialty customers tend to shop more frequently
on average than the overall population, presenting incremental upside for cross-selling opportunities. Over the last 5
years through the end of fiscal year 2019, penetration has increased approximately 130 basis points to approximately
11%.

**_Acceleration of Growth in Pre-COVID Period Following Shift of Blue Buffalo to FDM_**

PetSmart’s long term historical performance can be divided into five distinct phases:

1. **Early Growth: PetSmart experienced strong historical performance from 2007 to 2012, including growing**

through the recession and experiencing an average of approximately 4% comparable sales. This growth was
supported by an acceleration in net new store openings of approximately 95 annually from 2005 to 2008.

2. **Slowdown Pre-Investment: The Company’s growth began to slow meaningfully beginning in 2013 and**

entered negative territory in the first quarter of 2014, resulting in traffic declines – which were exacerbated
by mismanagement and a failed consumables reset.

3. **Early Investment Wins: BC Partners acquired PetSmart in 2015. As a result of cost savings and pricing**

strategies implemented by BC Partners, on a pro forma basis Adjusted EBITDA margins improved
approximately 240 basis points from 14.5% in 2014 to 16.9% in 2016, despite flat comparable sales.

4. **Channel Shifts Mid-Investment: Traffic declines began to accelerate beginning in the third quarter of 2016**

as a result of: (i) acceleration of online growth from Chewy and Amazon; and (ii) movement of two of the
largest channel-exclusive brands into the FDM space, including Blue Buffalo in 2017. As a result,
comparable sales declines reached (4.5%) in 2017. Despite these challenges, PetSmart was able to hold pro
forma Adjusted EBITDA margins at approximately 14% (i.e., pre-deal margins) through aggressive expense
management and promotion optimization strategies.

5. **Return to Positive Growth: A shift in strategy to embrace the Company’s “moats” against online as well as**

a merchandising strategy to bring in new and growing brands provided early shoots in a path to recovery.

**Fiscal Year 2020 YTD Update**

During the thirty-nine week period ended November 1, 2020, much of which was affected by the COVID19 pandemic, PetSmart not only benefitted from the resilience of the broader pet retail industry, but also experienced
further performance uplift that was more unique to PetSmart, driving market share gains. PetSmart’s wide assortment
offering allowed the Company to capitalize during the COVID-19 pandemic and offset a loss of services that will
rebound as the sub-category opens up. In addition, pet adoption increases during the pandemic have provided a secular
tailwind for PetSmart’s growth.

     - _Industry tailwinds: Pet supply and food retailers were deemed “essential services” during the_
government mandated shut-downs, allowing PetSmart and other similar businesses to remain open
for merchandise sales. In addition, pet adoptions and ownership increased during lockdowns,
expanding PetSmart’s customer base and generating higher demand for pet products.

     - _Competitive dynamics: Supply chain and fulfillment challenges faced by certain online competitors_
resulted in further uptick in demand for PetSmart. Strong relationships with key suppliers allowed
the Company to maintain sufficient inventory levels and satisfy the elevated demand from
customers.

     - _PetSmart actions: PetSmart took swift action to actively manage costs and drive up profitability_
through (i) optimizing its labor model, (ii) renegotiating store lease agreements and (iii) reevaluating in-store operational practices to identify long term efficiencies. In support of the top line,
the Company accelerated the roll-out of omni-channel capabilities that promoted social distancing,
namely curbside pickup, allowing customers the comfort and flexibility to shop safely.

penetration has normalized down from its peak during the government mandated stay-at-home orders, by the end of

to approximately 1% prior to COVID. Furthermore, in the thirty-nine week period ended November 1, 2020, omnichannel pro forma net sales rose by 239% year-over-year to $360 million.

**Industry Overview**

The pet care industry serves a large, growing, and recession-resilient market. In the U.S., the pet care category
market size was approximately $95.0 billion in calendar year 2019, and included the following sub-segments: (i) pet
food ($36.6 billion); (ii) pet supplies ($18.0 billion); (iii) non-medical pet services ($10.3 billion); and (iv) veterinary
services ($30.1 billion). Approximately 56% of households in the United States owned a pet in calendar year 2020,
which equates to approximately 71 million households. In total, it is estimated that approximately 41.0% (or 51.3
million) of households owned dogs and 25.0% (or 31.4 million) of households owned cats as pets in the United States
in calendar year 2020.
