Supported by secular tailwinds, the pet care category is the fastest growing category within all of retail; the
total category has consistently grown by approximately 5% to approximately 6% in each of the last five years. Pets
are increasingly viewed as members of the family, which has helped drive relatively inelastic demand for pet care
products and services. The “premiumization” of pet food has increased customer’s ticket size, and the longer average
lives of pets has increased the number of purchases over the duration of a pet’s life. Additionally, millennials have
tended to prioritize pet ownership over having children as they enter young adulthood. Pet ownership also boasts
mental and physical health benefits, with 90% of U.S. pet parents believing that their pets have a beneficial impact on
their physical and emotional health. Researchers have tied human health benefits to pet ownership and interaction in
areas including stress, depression, anxiety and PTSD amongst others. Growth trends in pet care are expected to
continue, as the forecasted CAGR from 2019 to 2024 is approximately 5%.

**_Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on the U.S. Pet Industry_**

The pet industry has historically proven to be recession-resilient. However, projected U.S. pet retail sales are
expected to decline by 1.2% in 2020 – compared with 5% growth forecasted prior to the COVID-19 pandemic –
resulting in a decrease from $95 billion in 2019 to $94 billion projected in 2020. This forecast factors in sales declines
in 2020 for services which have been impacted by stay-at home and social distancing orders, with the largest decline
expected for non-medical pet services. The decline in services was partially offset by an increase in pet food and pet
products, driven by an increase in pet ownership.

Pet product sales are expected to be up 7.7% in 2020 due to increased pet ownership rates – reflecting overall
resilience in the category, partially impacted by some level of trading down to value and store brands. Pet adoption
rates have increased through the COVID-19 pandemic as the U.S. population has turned to pets to support mental and
physical well-being during periods of self-isolation. In the United States, the approximately 4% projected growth in
pet ownership households in 2020 would increase the number of pet-owning households in the U.S. to nearly 71
million by year-end.

Following the COVID-19 pandemic, we believe the pet industry is expected to rebound to pre-pandemic
levels and accelerate with tailwinds created by the increased pet adoption rates during the lock-down period. These
factors contribute to the attractiveness of the growing pet care category, of which PetSmart is the only comprehensive
provider of both pet products and services in the United States.

**Our Products and Services**

**_Merchandise_**

Pro forma merchandise sales represented approximately 91.4%, 86.9%, 87.2% and 87.3% of our net sales in
the thirty-nine week period ending November 1, 2020, fiscal year 2019, fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2017,
respectively. Our merchandise offering generally falls into three main categories:

- _Consumables, which includes dog and cat food and treats as well as cat litter products. We emphasize natural, science-_
based and therapeutic pet foods. We offer private brands as well as widely distributed quality national brands in order
to provide our pet parents with a broad selection of products. Pro forma consumables merchandise sales comprised
45.3%, 46.4%, 47.1% and 48.2% of our net sales in the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020, fiscal year 2019,
fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2017, respectively.

- _Hardgoods, which includes dog and cat supplies that address pet parents’ needs in the product categories “fun &_
fashion” (e.g., toys, apparel, beds, collars and leashes) and “problem & solution” (e.g., grooming and beauty,
healthcare and supplements, flea and tick, travel, containment and electronics, waste management). Pro forma
hardgoods merchandise sales comprised 30.1%, 27.2%, 27.5% and 27.3% of our net sales in the thirty-nine weeks
ended November 1, 2020, fiscal year 2019, fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2017, respectively.

- _Specialty, which includes fresh-water fish, small birds, reptiles and other small pets, as well as consumables and_
hardgoods associated for specialty pets, including food, bedding, treats, filtration, aquariums, light/heat, plants and
décor. We do not sell dogs or cats, but provide space in all our stores for pet adoptions. Pro forma specialty
merchandise sales comprised 16.0%, 13.3%, 12.6%, and 11.8% of our net sales in the thirty-nine weeks ended
November 1, 2020, fiscal year 2019, fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2017, respectively.

**_Services_**

Services, which include professional grooming, training, boarding and day camp as well as training and day
camp for dogs, represented 8.0%, 12.4%, 12.1% and 12.0% of our pro forma net sales in the thirty-nine weeks ended
November 1, 2020, fiscal year 2019, fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2017, respectively. All of our stores feature pet
styling salons that provide grooming services for dogs, and many of our pet styling salons provide services for cats.
Most of our stores offer comprehensive dog training services. Our groomers are educated as part of a comprehensive
program that teaches exceptional grooming skills, using safe and gentle techniques. Dog training services range from
puppy classes to advanced or private courses, led by our accredited dog training instructors.

PetsHotels provide boarding for dogs and cats, which includes 24-hour supervision by caregivers who are
PetSmart trained to provide personalized pet care, temperature controlled rooms and suites, daily specialty treats and
play time, as well as day camp for dogs. Our Services Reservation Center creates operational efficiencies in our hotels
and allows us to better serve our customers when making reservations. As of November 1, 2020, we operated 207
PetsHotels.

We make full-service veterinary care available through strategic relationships with third-party operators. As
of November 1, 2020, we had full-service veterinary hospitals in 809 of our stores, of which 799 were operated by
Medical Management International, Inc., which does business as Banfield, The Pet Hospital. The remaining 10
hospitals were operated by other third-parties.

**Merchandising**

Our merchandising team allows us to offer a broad spectrum of product offering across the full pricing
spectrum. Because of our brand strength and industry leadership, we have been able to develop preferred vendor
relationships and can offer channel-exclusive products to our customers. We also have a private brands and
international sourcing division that develops and sources our own proprietary assortments to drive exclusivity, loyalty
and profitability. We work closely and strategically with our vendor/manufacturing base to insure we carry the most
relevant products our customers are looking for at the competitive values.

**Marketing and Advertising**

Our marketing and advertising strategies play an important part in our efforts to acquire new customers and
retain and grow our relationships with current customers. We employ a wide range of channels in our marketing
programs, including traditional mass media efforts like TV advertising, radio advertising and digital circulars, as well
as more targeted techniques like personalized email and customer relationship management, organic and paid search,
digital display and digital retargeting. Our marketing and advertising efforts cover all of our brand channels, including
PetSmart retail stores, PetSmart.com, PetSmart.ca, the PetSmart app and Only Natural Pet. We also use our loyalty
program, PetSmart Treats®, to enhance our engagement with our customers. This program has over 40 million
members.

**Distribution**

Our distribution network and information systems are designed to optimize store inventory, drive efficiencies
in store labor, facilitate a high in-stock position, and promote high distribution center productivity. We currently
operate seven regional distribution centers in the U.S. We also utilize two third party operated distribution centers in
Canada to support our Canadian operations and two third party operated fulfillment sites in the U.S. to fulfill ship-tohome orders. Our suppliers generally ship merchandise to our distribution centers, which receive and allocate
merchandise to our stores or third-party fulfilment sites. We contract for the transportation of merchandise within our
supply chain, including the shipment of product to stores, through third-party vendors. We leverage our stores,
distribution centers, two third party e-commerce fulfilment sites as well as our ship from store capabilities in Canada
and our recently launched partnership with DoorDash to efficiently deliver our products to consumers.

**Government Regulation**

We are subject to various federal, state, provincial, international and local laws and regulations, including
those governing: consumer products and consumer protection, food and product safety, advertising and marketing,
labor and employment; data protection and privacy; the distribution, import/export and sale of products (including
live pets); the provision of grooming and other services; pharmacy operations; environmental regulation; and tax. We
seek to structure our operations to comply with all federal, state, provincial and local laws and regulations of each
jurisdiction in which we operate. Given varying and uncertain interpretations of these laws and regulations, and
because laws and regulations are enforced by the courts and regulatory authorities with broad discretion, we can make
no assurances we would be found to be in compliance in all jurisdictions, at all times. We also could be subject to
costs, including fines, penalties, or sanctions and third-party claims as a result of violations of, or liabilities under,
these laws and regulations.

**Competition**

- Warehouse clubs and other mass merchandisers;

- Grocery stores;

- Specialty pet supply stores;

- Veterinarians;

- General retailers;

- Farm and feed stores;

- E-commerce and catalog retailers; and

We believe the principal competitive factors influencing our business are product selection, services
offerings, quality of products and services, pricing, customer experience, brand awareness and loyalty, convenience
of store locations, store environment, and omni-channel capabilities, including the ability to deliver products and
services in the manner customers desire such as through buy-online pick-up in store, curbside pickup, online
reservations, and same day delivery. We seek to differentiate ourselves from our competitors by offering a superior
customer experience through our curated product selection, including private brands, services offerings, omni-channel
capabilities, and knowledgeable and caring associates who share a love for pets.

**DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS**

Below is a description of certain terms of the new term loan facility and the new ABL facility. This
description does not purport to be complete and is subject to, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, all of the
provisions of the agreements, including the definitions of certain terms therein that are not otherwise defined herein.

**_New Senior Secured Credit Facilities_**

Concurrently with the issuance of the notes, we expect that PetSmart will enter into, and the Corporate Coissuer will become a guarantor of, a new term loan facility with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as administrative agent
and collateral agent, and the financial institutions party thereto as lenders from time to time and a new ABL facility,
with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as administrative agent and collateral agent, and the financial institutions party
thereto as lenders from time to time. The terms of the credit agreements and related documentation for the new term
loan facility and the new ABL facility are under discussion and, accordingly, their definitive terms may vary from
those described below.

**New Term Loan Facility**

**_Overview_**

The new term loan facility is expected to provide for term loans in an aggregate principal amount of $2,300.0
million and provide PetSmart with the right to request incremental loans in an aggregate principal amount of up to the
sum of (a) the principal amount of certain voluntary prepayments of the term loans thereunder prior to such date and
(b) an additional amount subject to compliance with certain specified financial ratio incurrence tests. The lenders
under the new term loan facility will not be under any obligation to provide any such incremental commitments, and
the incurrence of any such incremental commitments will be subject to certain customary conditions precedent and
other provisions.

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

As of the closing date, at PetSmart’s election, the interest rate per annum applicable to loans issued under the
new term loan facility will be based on a fluctuating rate of interest determined by reference to either (i) a base rate
determined by reference to the higher of (a) the U.S. prime rate as quoted by The Wall Street Journal, (b) the federal
funds effective rate plus 0.50% per annum and (c) (x) the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) applicable for
an interest period of one month, plus (y) 1.00% per annum, in each case, plus an applicable margin or (ii) an adjusted
LIBOR rate determined by reference to the higher of (a) LIBOR and (b) a floor to be agreed, plus an applicable margin.

**_Amortization and Maturity_**

The new term loan facility is expected to amortize in equal quarterly installments in an aggregate annual
amount equal to 1.00% of the original principal amount of the new term loan facility, beginning with the second full
fiscal quarter ending after the closing date of the new term loan facility, with the balance being payable on the seventh
anniversary of the closing date, which is expected to be the maturity date of the new term loan facility.

**_Guarantee and Security_**

All obligations of PetSmart under the new term loan facility and any swap agreements and cash management
arrangements provided by any lender party to the new term loan facility or any of its affiliates are expected to be
unconditionally guaranteed by Holdings, the Corporate Co-issuer, the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor and each
existing and subsequently acquired or organized direct or indirect material wholly-owned domestic restricted
subsidiary of Holdings (other than PetSmart), subject to customary exceptions including, among other things, where
providing such guarantees is not permitted by law, regulation or contract or would result in material adverse tax
consequences.

138


-----

Subject to the intercreditor agreements, all obligations under the new term loan facility and any swap
agreements and cash management arrangements provided by any lender party to the senior secured credit facilities or
any of its affiliates, and the guarantees of such obligations, will be secured, subject to permitted liens and other
exceptions, by: (i) a perfected first-priority pledge of all the equity interests of PetSmart, the Pledged Chewy Stock
and each wholly-owned restricted subsidiary of PetSmart directly held by PetSmart or a subsidiary guarantor (limited
to 65% of voting capital stock of each direct foreign subsidiary owned by PetSmart or its domestic subsidiaries), (ii)
perfected first-priority security interests in substantially all of the tangible and intangible assets of PetSmart and the
subsidiary guarantors (but excluding the ABL collateral described below and subject to certain other exclusions) (the
foregoing clauses (i) and (ii), collectively, the “cash flow collateral”) and (iii) a perfected second-priority security
interest in the ABL collateral of PetSmart and the domestic guarantors under the new ABL facility described below.

**_Certain Covenants and Events of Default_**

The new term loan facility will contain a number of covenants that, among other things, restrict, subject to
certain exceptions, our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to:

    - incur additional indebtedness (including guarantee obligations);

    - create or incur liens;

    - engage in mergers or other fundamental changes;

    - sell, transfer or otherwise dispose of certain assets;

    - make investments, acquisitions or loans or advances;

    - pay dividends and distributions or repurchase capital stock;

    - prepay redeem, or repurchase certain indebtedness;

    - enter into agreements which limit our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to incur
liens on assets; and

    - enter into certain transactions with affiliates.

The new term loan facility will also contain certain customary affirmative covenants and events of default
for facilities of this type, including an event of default upon a change of control.

**New ABL Facility**

**_Overview_**

The new ABL facility is expected to provide a senior secured financing of up to $750.0 million, subject to
borrowing base restrictions, available in U.S. dollars and Canadian dollars and other currencies to be mutually agreed.

The new ABL facility will provide us the right to request incremental commitments in an aggregate principal
amount of up to $750.0 million. The lenders under the new ABL facility will not be under any obligation to provide
any such incremental commitments, and the incurrence of any such incremental commitments will be subject to certain
customary conditions precedent and other provisions.

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

Borrowings under the new ABL facility are expected to bear interest at a rate per annum equal to an applicable
margin, plus, at our option, either (a) a base rate, (b) a LIBOR rate or (c) certain other applicable rates. The applicable

139


-----

margin under the new ABL facility will be determined based on our average excess liquidity during the immediately
preceding fiscal quarter as a percentage of the maximum borrowing amount under the new ABL facility.

In addition to paying interest on outstanding principal under the new ABL facility, we will be required to pay
a commitment fee of 0.375% per annum to the lenders under the new ABL facility in respect of the unutilized
commitments thereunder. The commitment fee rate may be reduced to 0.25% if the average daily used portion of the
new ABL facility exceeds 50.0%. We must also pay customary letter of credit fees.

**_Amortization and Maturity_**

The new ABL facility will not amortize. The principal amounts outstanding under the new ABL facility are
expected to become due and payable in full at maturity, on the fifth anniversary of the closing date.

**_Guarantee and Security_**

All obligations of the borrowers under the new ABL facility and certain swap agreements and cash
management arrangements provided by any lender party to the new ABL facility or any of its affiliates are expected
to be unconditionally guaranteed by each guarantor under the new term loan facility (including the Chewy Stock
Affiliate Guarantor) and, with respect to obligations of PetSmart’s Canadian subsidiary (the “Canadian ABL
Borrower”), PetSmart and each other existing and subsequently acquired or organized direct or indirect material
wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart organized under the laws of the United States or any state thereof, with
customary exceptions including, among other things, where providing such guarantees is not permitted by law,
regulation or contract or would result in material adverse tax consequences.

Subject to the intercreditor agreements and certain exceptions and agreements with respect to obligations of
the Canadian ABL Borrower and the guarantees thereof, the obligations under the new ABL facility and certain swap
agreements and cash management arrangements provided by any lender party to the new ABL facility or any of its
affiliates, and the guarantees of such obligations, will be secured, subject to permitted liens and other exceptions, by:
(i) a perfected first-priority security interest in substantially all personal property of Holdings, the borrowers under the
new ABL facility and the subsidiary guarantors consisting of accounts receivables, inventory, cash, deposit accounts,
securities and commodity accounts, and documents and supporting obligations (but generally excluding intellectual
property) (the “ABL collateral”) and (ii) a perfected second-priority security interest in the cash flow collateral
described above.

**_Certain Covenants and Events of Default_**

The new ABL facility will contain a number of covenants that, among other things, restrict, subject to certain
exceptions, our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to:

    - incur additional indebtedness (including guarantee obligations);

    - create or incur liens;

    - engage in mergers or other fundamental changes;

    - sell, transfer or otherwise dispose of certain assets;

    - make investments, acquisitions or loans or advances;

    - pay dividends and distributions or repurchase capital stock;

    - prepay redeem, or repurchase certain indebtedness;

    - enter into agreements which limit our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to incur
liens on assets; and

140


-----

    - enter into certain transactions with affiliates.

In addition, the new ABL facility is expected to require us to maintain a minimum fixed charge coverage
ratio of 1.0:1.0 if excess liquidity (defined in the new ABL facility) is less than the greater of 10% of the maximum
borrowing amount and $70.0 million for a certain period of time.

The new ABL facility will also contain certain customary affirmative covenants and events of default for
facilities of this type, including an event of default upon a change of control.

**DESCRIPTION OF SENIOR FIRST LIEN NOTES**

**General**

Certain terms used in this description are defined under the subheading “Certain Definitions.” In this
description, (i) the terms “we,” “our” and “us” each refer to PetSmart, Inc. (“PetSmart”) and its consolidated
Subsidiaries taken together, (ii) the term “Issuer” refers only to PetSmart and not any of its Affiliates, (iii) the term
“Finance Issuer” refers to PetSmart Finance Corp., a Delaware corporation, and (iv) the term “Co-Issuers” refers to
PetSmart and Finance Issuer (and each of them a “Co-Issuer”). PetSmart is expected to be converted to a Delaware
limited liability company prior to consummation of this offering, which may occur through the merger of PetSmart
into a newly-formed limited liability company with PetSmart surviving such merger.

The Co-Issuers will issue $1,200,000,000 aggregate principal amount of    % senior secured notes due 2028
(the “Notes”) under an indenture to be dated as of       , 2021 (the “Indenture”) among the Co-Issuers, the
Guarantors, and U.S. Bank National Association, as trustee (the “Trustee”) and collateral agent (the “First Lien Notes
_Collateral Agent”)._

The Notes have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or under the securities laws of
any other jurisdiction and are subject to certain transfer restrictions. See “Transfer Restrictions” elsewhere in this
offering memorandum. The Indenture is not required to be and will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act.

The following description is only a summary of the material provisions of the Notes and the Indenture, does
not purport to be complete and is qualified in its entirety by reference to the provisions of the Notes and the Indenture,
including the definitions therein of certain terms used below. We urge you to read each of these documents because
they, and not this description, will define your rights as Holders.

**Brief Description of Notes**

The Notes will be:

     - senior secured obligations of the Co-Issuers;

     - _pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future Senior Indebtedness (including the New_
Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Unsecured Notes) of the Co-Issuers;

     - secured on a first-priority basis by the CF Debt Priority Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers and on
a second-priority basis by the ABL Priority Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers, in each case, subject
to certain Liens permitted under the Indenture;

     - equal in priority as to the CF Debt Priority Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers with respect to any
Obligations under any other First Lien Obligations of the Co-Issuers, including the New Term Loan
Credit Facility;

     - effectively senior to (i) all existing and future unsecured Indebtedness of the Co-Issuers (including

**Ranking**

The Indebtedness evidenced by the Notes and the Guarantees will be Senior Indebtedness of the Co-Issuers
or the applicable Guarantor, as the case may be, and will rank equal in right of payment with all existing and future
Senior Indebtedness of the Co-Issuers or such Guarantor, as the case may be, including the obligations under our New
Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Unsecured Notes. The Indebtedness evidenced by the Affiliate Guarantee will
be Senior Indebtedness of the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor, and will rank equal in right of payment with all
existing and future Senior Indebtedness of the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor, including the guarantee of the
obligations under our New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Unsecured Notes. The phrase “in right of payment”
refers to the contractual ranking of a particular Obligation, regardless of whether an Obligation is secured.

The Obligations under the Notes, the Indenture and the Guarantees will be secured on a first-priority basis
by the CF Debt Priority Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers and the Guarantors, subject to certain Liens permitted
under the Indenture, will be equal in priority as to the CF Debt Priority Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers and the
Guarantors with respect to any other First Lien Obligations of the Co-Issuers and the Guarantors, including under the
New Term Loan Credit Facility, will have a second-priority security interest with respect to the ABL Priority
Collateral and will be effectively senior to all existing and future unsecured Indebtedness of the Co-Issuers and the
Guarantors and any future Junior Lien Obligations of the Co-Issuers and the Guarantors to the extent of the value of
the Collateral owned by the Co-Issuers and the Guarantors (after giving effect to any other senior Lien on such
Collateral), and will be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness of the Co-Issuers and the
Guarantors that is secured by Liens on assets that do not constitute a part of the Collateral to the extent of the value of
such assets.

The Obligations under the Notes and the Affiliate Guarantee will be secured on a first-priority basis by the
Pledged Chewy Stock owned by the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor, subject to certain Permitted Encumbrances
under the Indenture, will be equal in priority as to the Pledged Chewy Stock owned by the Chewy Stock Affiliate
Guarantor with respect to any Obligations under any other First Lien Obligations of the Chewy Stock Affiliate
Guarantor, including the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor’s guarantee of the New Term Loan Credit Facility, and
will be effectively senior to (i) all existing and future unsecured Indebtedness of the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor
and any guarantee by the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor of any future Junior Lien Obligations of the Chewy Stock
Affiliate Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Pledged Chewy Stock (after giving effect to any senior Lien on
the Pledged Chewy Stock) and (ii) all existing and future guarantees of the Obligations of the Chewy Stock Affiliate
Guarantor under the ABL Credit Agreement to the extent of the value of the Pledged Chewy Stock.

Substantially all of the operations of the Issuer are conducted through the Issuer’s Subsidiaries. Not all of the
Subsidiaries of the Issuer will guarantee the Notes, and as described under “—Guarantees,” Guarantees may be
released under certain circumstances. In addition, some or all of the Issuer’s future Subsidiaries may not be required
to guarantee the Notes. Unless the Subsidiary is a Guarantor or a Co-Issuer, claims of creditors of such Subsidiaries,

**_First Lien Intercreditor Agreement_**

The First Lien Notes Collateral Agent and the Term Loan Collateral Agent will enter into an intercreditor
agreement (as the same may be amended from time to time, the “First Lien Intercreditor Agreement”) with respect to
the Collateral, which may be amended from time to time without the consent of the Holders to add other parties
holding First Lien Obligations permitted to be incurred under the Indenture, the New Term Loan Credit Facility and
the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement. The Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor will be party to the First Lien
Intercreditor Agreement and the Pledged Chewy Stock will be subject to the provisions thereof (with all references to
the Shared Collateral herein deemed to include the Pledged Chewy Stock, as applicable).

Under the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement, only the “Controlling Collateral Agent” will have the right to
act or refrain from acting with respect to any Shared Collateral. The Controlling Collateral Agent is the Term Loan
Collateral Agent and will remain the Term Loan Collateral Agent until the earlier of (1) the Discharge of the Term
Loan Credit Agreement Obligations and (2) the Non-Controlling Authorized Representative Enforcement Date (such
earlier date, the “Controlling Collateral Agent Change Date”). From and after the Controlling Collateral Agent
Change Date, the Controlling Collateral Agent will be the Additional First Lien Collateral Agent.

With respect to any Shared Collateral, no Non-Controlling Authorized Representative or other NonControlling Secured Party shall or shall instruct the Controlling Collateral Agent to, commence any judicial or
nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings with respect to, seek to have a trustee, receiver, liquidator or similar official
appointed for or over, attempt any action to take possession of, exercise any right, remedy or power with respect to,
or otherwise take any action to enforce its security interest in or realize upon, or take any other action available to it
in respect of, any Shared Collateral.

The “Non-Controlling Authorized Representative Enforcement Date” means, with respect to any NonControlling Authorized Representative, the date that is 180 days (throughout which 180-day period such NonControlling Authorized Representative was the Major Non-Controlling Authorized Representative) after the
occurrence of both (a) an event of default (under and as defined in the Additional First Lien Document under which
the Non-Controlling Authorized Representative is the Authorized Representative), and (b) each Collateral Agent’s
and each other Authorized Representative’s receipt of written notice from such Non-Controlling Authorized
Representative certifying that (i) such Non-Controlling Authorized Representative is the Major Non-Controlling

154


-----

Authorized Representative and that an event of default (under and as defined in the Additional First Lien Document
under which the Non-Controlling Authorized Representative is the Authorized Representative) has occurred and is
continuing and (ii) the Additional First Lien Obligations of the Series with respect to which such Non-Controlling
Authorized Representative is the Authorized Representative are currently due and payable in full (whether as a result
of acceleration thereof or otherwise) in accordance with the terms of the applicable Additional First Lien Document;
_provided that such event of default (under and as defined in the Additional First Lien Document under which such_
Non-Controlling Authorized Representative is the Major Non-Controlling Authorizing Representative) shall be
continuing at the end of such 180-day period; provided, further, that the Non-Controlling Authorized Representative
Enforcement Date will be stayed and will not occur and will be deemed not to have occurred with respect to any
Shared Collateral if (1) at any time the Controlling Collateral Agent has commenced and is diligently pursuing any
enforcement action (including delivery by the Controlling Collateral Agent of a notice to the ABL Collateral Agent
that commences an ABL Priority Standstill Period) with respect to a material portion of such Shared Collateral, (2) at
any time the Term Loan Collateral Agent is stayed under the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement from pursuing
enforcement actions with respect to such Shared Collateral or (3) at any time the Co-Issuer or the Guarantor that has
granted a security interest in such Shared Collateral is then a debtor under or with respect to (or otherwise subject to)
any insolvency or liquidation proceeding.

The Controlling Collateral Agent is the Term Loan Collateral Agent and the First Lien Notes Collateral Agent
will have no rights to take any action under the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement with respect to the Shared Collateral
unless and until it becomes the Controlling Collateral Agent.

Notwithstanding the equal priority of the Liens on the Shared Collateral securing each Series of First Lien
Obligations, the Controlling Collateral Agent may deal with the Shared Collateral as if the Controlling Collateral
Agent had a senior Lien on such Collateral. No Non-Controlling Authorized Representative or Non-Controlling
Secured Party will contest, protest or object to any foreclosure proceeding or action brought by the Controlling
Collateral Agent, the Applicable Authorized Representative or any Controlling Secured Party or any other exercise
by the Controlling Collateral Agent, the Applicable Authorized Representative or any Controlling Secured Party of
any rights and remedies relating to the Shared Collateral, or to cause the Controlling Collateral Agent to do so. Each
of the First Lien Secured Parties also will agree that it will not (and will waive any right to) question or contest or
support any other person in contesting, in any proceeding (including any insolvency or liquidation proceeding), the
perfection, priority, validity, attachment or enforceability of a Lien held by or on behalf of any of the First Lien
Secured Parties in all or any part of the Collateral, or the provisions of the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement. The
foregoing shall not be construed to limit the rights and priorities of any First Lien Secured Party, any Collateral Agent
or any Authorized Representative with respect to any Collateral not constituting Shared Collateral.

If an Event of Default or an event of default under any document governing a Series of First Lien Obligations
has occurred and is continuing and the Controlling Collateral Agent or any other First Lien Secured Party is taking
action to enforce rights in respect of any Shared Collateral, or any distribution (including any adequate protection

or the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor or any Guarantor or any First Lien Secured Party receives any payment

of the First Lien Obligations on a ratable basis, with such proceeds to be applied to the First Lien

for such Series; provided that following the commencement of any insolvency or liquidation

_Certain Limitations Applicable in Bankruptcy Proceedings_

If a Co-Issuer, any Guarantor or the Affiliate Guarantor becomes subject to any bankruptcy case, the First
Lien Intercreditor Agreement will provide that if a Co-Issuer, any Guarantor or the Affiliate Guarantor shall, as
debtor(s)-in-possession, move for approval of financing (“DIP Financing”) to be provided by one or more lenders
(the “DIP Lenders”) under Section 364 of the Bankruptcy Code or any equivalent provision of any other applicable
bankruptcy law or the use of cash collateral under Section 363 of the Bankruptcy Code (in each case, or under any
equivalent provision of any other applicable bankruptcy law), each First-Lien Secured Party (other than any
Controlling Secured Party or the Authorized Representative of any Controlling Secured Party) will agree not to object
to any such financing or to the Liens on the Shared Collateral securing the same (the “DIP Financing Liens”) or to
any use of cash collateral that constitutes Shared Collateral, unless the Controlling Collateral Agent (acting on the
instruction of the Applicable Authorized Representative) opposes or objects to such DIP Financing or such DIP
Financing Liens and/or use of cash collateral (and (i) to the extent that such DIP Financing Liens are senior to the
Liens on any such Shared Collateral for the benefit of the Controlling Secured Parties, each Non-Controlling Secured
Party will subordinate its Liens with respect to such Shared Collateral on the same terms as the Liens of the Controlling
Secured Parties (other than any Liens of any First Lien Secured Parties constituting DIP Financing Liens) are
subordinated thereto, and (ii) to the extent that such DIP Financing Liens rank pari passu with the Liens on any such
Shared Collateral granted to secure the First Lien Obligations of the Controlling Secured Parties, each Non-Controlling
Secured Party will confirm the priorities with respect to such Shared Collateral as set forth in the First Lien
Intercreditor Agreement), in each case so long as:

(A) the First Lien Secured Parties of each Series retain the benefit of their Liens on all such Shared
Collateral pledged to the DIP Lenders, including proceeds thereof arising after the commencement
of such proceeding, with the same priority vis-a-vis all the other First Lien Secured Parties (other
than any Liens of the First Lien Secured Parties constituting DIP Financing Liens) as existed prior
to the commencement of the bankruptcy case;

(B) the First Lien Secured Parties of each Series are granted Liens on any additional collateral pledged
to any First Lien Secured Parties as adequate protection or otherwise in connection with such DIP
Financing and/or use of cash collateral, with the same priority vis-a-vis the First Lien Secured
Parties as set forth in the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement (other than any Liens of the First Lien
Secured Parties constituting DIP Financing Liens);

(C) if any amount of such DIP Financing and/or cash collateral is applied to repay any of the First Lien
Obligations, such amount is applied pursuant to the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement; and

(D) if any First Lien Secured Parties are granted adequate protection, including in the form of periodic
payments, in connection with such DIP Financing and/or use of cash collateral, the proceeds of such
adequate protection are applied pursuant to the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement;

_provided that the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement shall not limit the right of the First Lien Secured Parties of each_
Series to object to the grant of a Lien to secure the DIP Financing over any Collateral subject to Liens in favor of the
First Lien Secured Parties of such Series or its representative that do not constitute Shared Collateral; and provided,
_further, that the First Lien Secured Parties receiving adequate protection shall not object to any other First Lien_
Secured Party receiving adequate protection comparable to any adequate protection granted to such First Lien Secured
Parties in connection with a DIP Financing and/or use of cash collateral.

The First Lien Secured Parties acknowledge that the First Lien Obligations of any Series may, subject to the
limitations set forth in the other First Lien Documents, be increased, extended, renewed, replaced, restated,
supplemented, restructured, repaid, refunded, refinanced (in whole or in part) or otherwise amended or modified from
time to time, in each case, without notice to, or the consent (except to the extent a consent is otherwise required to
permit the refinancing transaction under any First Lien Document) of any First Lien Secured Party of any other Series,

all without affecting the priority of claims and application of proceeds set forth in the First Lien Intercreditor
Agreement or the other provisions thereof defining the relative rights of the First Lien Secured Parties of any Series.

**_Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement_**

If a Co-Issuer or any of the Guarantors were to incur Indebtedness secured by the Collateral with a Junior
Lien Priority relative to the Notes, the Term Loan Collateral Agent, the First Lien Notes Collateral Agent and the
applicable Junior Lien Collateral Agent will enter into an intercreditor agreement substantially in the form attached to
the Indenture (as the same may be amended from time to time, the “Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement”). The Junior
Lien Intercreditor Agreement may be amended from time to time without the consent of the Holders to add other
parties holding Junior Lien Obligations and First Lien Obligations permitted to be incurred under the relevant
agreements, or their respective representatives. If the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor pledges the Pledged Chewy
Stock to secure any Junior Lien Obligations, it will also become a party to the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement
(with all references to the Shared Collateral herein deemed to include the Pledged Chewy Stock, as applicable).

Notwithstanding the date, time, manner or order of filing or recordation of any document or instrument or
grant, attachment or perfection of any Liens granted to the Junior Lien Collateral Agent or any Junior Lien Secured
Parties on the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) or of any Liens granted to any First Lien Secured Parties
on the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) (or any actual or alleged defect in any of the foregoing) and
notwithstanding any provision of the UCC, any applicable law, any Junior Lien Documents or any First Lien
Documents or any other circumstance whatsoever, the Junior Lien Collateral Agent and each other Junior Lien
Representative, in each case on behalf of itself and each Junior Lien Secured Party under its Junior Lien Documents,
will agree that any Lien on the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) securing any First Lien Obligations
now or hereafter held by or on behalf of any First Lien Secured Parties or any First Lien Representative or other agent
or trustee therefor, regardless of how acquired, whether by grant, statute, operation of law, subrogation or otherwise,
shall have priority over and be senior in all respects and prior to any Lien on the Collateral (including the Pledged
Chewy Stock) securing any Junior Lien Obligations.

Pursuant to the terms of the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement, prior to the Discharge of First Lien
Obligations, the Controlling Collateral Agent or any person authorized by it will have the exclusive right to exercise
any right or remedy with respect to the Collateral and will also have the exclusive right to determine and direct the
time, method and place for exercising such right or remedy or conducting any proceeding with respect thereto. - From
and after the Junior Enforcement Date, the designated Junior Representative may exercise or seek to exercise any
rights or remedies (including setoff) with respect to any Shared Collateral in respect of any Junior Lien Obligations,
or institute any action or proceeding with respect to such rights or remedies (including any action of foreclosure), but
only so long as (1) the Controlling Collateral Agent has not commenced and is not diligently pursuing any enforcement
action with respect to such Shared Collateral or (2) the Grantor, or the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor, which has
granted a security interest in such Shared Collateral is not then a debtor under or with respect to (or otherwise subject
to) any insolvency or liquidation proceeding. In exercising rights and remedies with respect to any collateral securing
both the First Lien Obligations and any Junior Lien Obligations, the Controlling Collateral Agent and the First Lien
Secured Parties may enforce the provisions of the First Lien Documents and exercise remedies thereunder, all in such
order and in such manner as they may determine in their sole discretion. Such exercise and enforcement shall include
the rights of an agent appointed by them to sell or otherwise dispose of Collateral upon foreclosure, to incur expenses
in connection with such sale or disposition and to exercise all the rights and remedies of a secured lender under the
Uniform Commercial Code of any applicable jurisdiction and of a secured creditor under bankruptcy laws of any
applicable jurisdiction.

The “Junior Enforcement Date” means, with respect to any Junior Lien Representative, the date which is 180
days after the occurrence of both (i) an event of default (under and as defined in the Junior Lien Document for which
such Junior Lien Representative has been named as representative) and (ii) the Controlling Collateral Agent’s and
each other representative’s receipt of written notice from such Junior Lien Representative that (x) such Junior Lien
Representative is the Junior Lien Representative and that an event of default (under and as defined in the Junior Lien
Document for which such Junior Lien Representative has been named as Representative) has occurred and is
continuing and (y) the Junior Lien Obligations of the Series with respect to which such Junior Lien Representative is
the Junior Lien Representative are currently due and payable in full (whether as a result of acceleration thereof or
otherwise) in accordance with the terms of the applicable Junior Lien Document; provided that the Junior Enforcement

158


-----

Date shall be stayed and shall not occur and shall be deemed not to have occurred with respect to any Shared Collateral
(1) at any time the Controlling Collateral Agent has commenced and is diligently pursuing any enforcement action
with respect to such Shared Collateral or (2) at any time the Co-Issuer, the Guarantor or the Chewy Stock Affiliate
Guarantor which has granted a security interest in such Shared Collateral is then a debtor under or with respect to (or
otherwise subject to) any Insolvency or Liquidation Proceeding.

The Junior Lien Collateral Agent, for itself and on behalf of each Junior Lien Secured Party, will agree
pursuant to the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement that it will not (and will waive any right to) take any action to,
contest or support any other Person in contesting, in any proceeding (including any insolvency or liquidation
proceeding), the validity, extent, perfection, priority or enforceability of a Lien securing any First Lien Obligations
held (or purported to be held) by or on behalf of the Controlling Collateral Agent or any of the First Lien Secured
Parties or any agent or trustee therefor in any Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) or other collateral
securing both the First Lien Obligations and any Junior Lien Obligations. The Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement
will provide for a reciprocal restriction on the ability of any Collateral Agent to contest or support any other Person in
contesting, in any proceeding (including any insolvency or liquidation proceeding), the validity, extent, perfection,
priority or enforceability of any Lien securing any Junior Lien Obligations held (or purported to be held) by or on
behalf of the Junior Lien Collateral Agent or any of the Junior Lien Secured Parties in the Collateral (including the
Pledged Chewy Stock) securing the Junior Lien Obligations.

Subject to the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement with respect to the ABL Priority Collateral, the
Collateral or proceeds thereof received in connection with the sale or other disposition of, or collection on, such
Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) upon the exercise of remedies will be applied to the First Lien
Obligations prior to application to any Junior Lien Obligations or the Pledged Chewy Stock in such order as specified
in the relevant First Lien Security Documents until the Discharge of First Lien Obligations has occurred.

In the event of a sale, transfer or other disposition of any or all of the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy
Stock) (including all or substantially all of the equity interests of any subsidiary of the Company), the Liens granted
to the Junior Lien Representatives and the Junior Lien Secured Parties upon such Collateral to secure Junior Lien
Obligations shall terminate and be released, automatically and without any further action, concurrently with the
termination and release of all Liens granted upon such Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) to secure First
Lien Obligations.

**_Certain Matters in Connection with Liquidation and Insolvency Proceedings under any Junior Lien Intercreditor_**
**_Agreement_**

_Debtor-in-Possession Financings_

The Junior Lien Collateral Agent and each other Junior Lien Secured Party will agree, among other things,
that if a Co-Issuer, any Guarantor or the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor is subject to any insolvency or liquidation
proceeding and the Controlling Collateral Agent or any other First Lien Secured Party desires to permit (or not object
to) the use of cash collateral or to permit a Co-Issuer, any Guarantor or the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor to obtain
DIP Financing to be secured by any collateral securing both the First Lien Obligations and any Junior Lien Obligations,
then each Junior Lien Representative, on behalf of itself and each applicable Junior Lien Secured Party, will not object
to such use of cash collateral or DIP Financing and will not request adequate protection or any other relief in
connection therewith (except to the extent permitted by the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement) and, to the extent
the Liens securing the First Lien Obligations are subordinated to or _pari passu_ with such DIP Financing, will
subordinate its Liens in the Collateral and any other collateral to such DIP Financing (and all Obligations relating
thereto), any adequate protection liens granted to the First Lien Secured Parties, and any “carve out” for professional
and United States Trustee fees agreed to by the Controlling Collateral Agent, on the same basis as they are
subordinated to the First Lien Obligations pursuant to the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement. The Junior Lien
Collateral Agent, for itself and on behalf of each Junior Lien Secured Party, will agree that notice received two
Business Days prior to the entry of an order approving such usage of cash or other collateral or approving such DIP
Financing shall be adequate notice.

159


-----

_Relief from Automatic Stay; Bankruptcy Sales; and Post-Petition Interest_

No Junior Lien Secured Party may (x) seek relief from the automatic stay with respect to any Collateral
without the prior written consent of the Controlling Collateral Agent, or object to any motion for relief from the
automatic stay with respect to the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) made by the Controlling Collateral
Agent, (y) object to any lawful exercise by any holder of First Lien Obligations of the right to credit bid such claims
under Section 363(k) of the Bankruptcy Code or any other similar provision of the Bankruptcy Code, or to any sale
or other disposition of any Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) that the Controlling Collateral Agent has
consented to, provided that in the case of such a sale, the parties’ respective liens will attach to the proceeds of such
sale on the same basis of priority as such liens existed on the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) pursuant
to the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement, or (z) object to any claim of any holder of First Lien Obligations for postpetition interest, fees, costs, expenses, and/or other charges under Section 506(b) of the Bankruptcy Code or otherwise
(for this purpose ignoring all claims and Liens held by the Junior Lien Secured Parties on the Collateral (including the
Pledged Chewy Stock)).

_Adequate Protection_

Each Junior Lien Representative, for itself and on behalf of each applicable Junior Lien Secured Party, will
agree that none of them (x) shall object to (a) any request by the Controlling Collateral Agent or the First Lien Secured
Parties for adequate protection in any form, (b) any objection by the Controlling Collateral Agent or the First Lien
Secured Parties to any motion, relief, action, or proceeding based on the Controlling Collateral Agent’s or the First
Lien Secured Parties’ claiming a lack of adequate protection, or (c) the allowance and payment of interest, fees,
expenses, or other amounts of the Controlling Collateral Agent or the First Lien Secured Parties as adequate protection
or otherwise under Section 506(b) or 506(c) of the Bankruptcy Code or any similar provision of any other bankruptcy
law, (y) assert or support any claim for costs or expenses of preserving or disposing of any Shared Collateral under
Section 506(c) of the Bankruptcy Code or any similar provision of any other bankruptcy law or (z) request any form
of adequate protection except as permitted by the following sentence. If the First Lien Secured Parties (or any subset
thereof) are granted adequate protection in the form of a Lien on additional or replacement collateral and/or a
superpriority administrative expense claim in connection with any DIP Financing or use of cash collateral under
Section 363 or 364 of the Bankruptcy Code or any similar provision of any other bankruptcy law, then each Junior
Lien Representative, for itself and on behalf of the applicable Junior Lien Secured Parties, may seek or request
adequate protection in the form of (as applicable) a Lien on such additional or replacement collateral and/or a
superpriority administrative expense claim, which Lien and/or superpriority administrative expense claim (as
applicable) will be subordinated to the Liens securing and claims with respect to the First Lien Obligations and such
DIP Financing (and all obligations relating thereto) on the same basis as the other Liens securing and claims with
respect to the Junior Lien Obligations are so subordinated to the Liens securing and claims with respect to the First
Lien Obligations under the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement; provided that each Junior Lien Representative, for
itself and on behalf of each other Junior Lien Secured Party under the applicable Junior Lien Debt, will waive its rights
under Section 1129(a)(9) of the Bankruptcy Code and consent and agree that such superpriority administrative claims
may be paid under a plan of reorganization in any form having a value on the effective date of such plan equal to the
allowed amount of such claims, and (ii) in the event any Junior Lien Representatives, for themselves and on behalf of
the applicable Junior Lien Secured Parties, seek or request adequate protection and such adequate protection is granted
in the form of (as applicable) a Lien on additional or replacement collateral and/or a superpriority administrative
expense claim, then such Junior Lien Representatives, for themselves and on behalf of the applicable Junior Lien
Secured Parties, agree that the First Lien Representatives shall also be granted (as applicable) a senior Lien on such
additional or replacement collateral as security for the First Lien Obligations and/or a senior superpriority
administrative expense claim, and that any Lien on such additional or replacement collateral securing the Junior Lien
Obligations and/or superpriority administrative expense claim shall be subordinated to the Liens on such collateral
securing and claims with respect to the First Lien Obligations and any such DIP Financing (and all obligations relating
thereto) and any other Liens and claims granted to the First Lien Secured Parties as adequate protection on the same
basis as the other Liens securing and claims with respect to the Junior Lien Obligations are so subordinated to such
Liens securing and claims with respect to First Lien Obligations under the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, to the extent that the First Lien Secured Parties are granted adequate protection in the
form of payments in the amount of current post-petition fees and expenses, and/or other cash payments, then the Junior
Lien Representatives shall not be prohibited from seeking adequate protection in the form of payments in the amount
of current post-petition fees and expenses, and/or other cash payments (as applicable), subject to the right of the First

160


-----

Lien Secured Parties to object to the reasonableness of the amounts of fees and expenses or other cash payments so
sought by the Junior Lien Secured Parties.

_Plans of Reorganization_

No Junior Lien Representative or any other Junior Lien Secured Party may support or vote in favor of any
plan of reorganization (and each shall be deemed to have voted to reject any plan of reorganization) that is inconsistent
with the terms of the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement.

If it is held that the claims of the First Lien Secured Parties and the Junior Lien Secured Parties in respect of
the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) constitute only one secured claim (rather than separate classes of
senior and junior secured claims) under a plan of reorganization, then each Junior Lien Representative, for itself and
on behalf of the applicable Junior Lien Secured Parties, will acknowledge and agree that all distributions from the
Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) shall be made as if there were separate classes of senior and junior
secured claims against the Co-Issuers, the Guarantors or the Chewy Stock Affiliate Guarantor in respect of the
Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) (with the effect being that, to the extent that the aggregate value of
the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) is sufficient (for this purpose ignoring all claims held by the Junior
Lien Secured Parties), the First Lien Secured Parties shall be entitled to receive, in addition to amounts distributed to
them in respect of principal, pre-petition interest and other claims, all amounts owing in respect of post-petition
interest, fees, and expenses (whether or not allowed or allowable in such insolvency or liquidation proceeding) before
any distribution is made from the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) in respect of the Junior Lien
Obligations, with each Junior Lien Representative, for itself and on behalf of each applicable Junior Lien Secured
Party, acknowledging and agreeing to turn over to the Controlling Collateral Agent amounts otherwise received or
receivable by them from the Collateral (including the Pledged Chewy Stock) to the extent necessary to effectuate the
intent of this sentence, even if such turnover has the effect of reducing the claim or recovery of the Junior Lien Secured
Parties).

**_ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement_**

The First Lien Notes Collateral Agent, the Term Loan Collateral Agent and the ABL Collateral Agent will
enter into an intercreditor agreement (as the same may be amended from time to time, the “ABL/Cash Flow
_Intercreditor Agreement”) that will set forth the relative priority of the Liens securing the ABL Obligations and the_
Liens securing the CF Debt Obligations, as well as certain other rights, priorities and interests of the holders of the CF
Debt Obligations and the holders of the ABL Obligations. The ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement may be
further amended from time to time without the consent of the Holders to add other parties holding ABL Obligations
and CF Debt Obligations permitted to be incurred under the relevant agreements, or their respective representatives.

_Lien Priority and Similar Liens_

Notwithstanding the time, order or method of creation, attachment or perfection of any Liens securing the
ABL Obligations or any Liens securing the CF Debt Obligations or any failure, defect or deficiency or alleged failure,
defect or deficiency in any of the foregoing, (i) the Liens securing the ABL Obligations on the ABL Priority Collateral
rank senior to any Liens securing the CF Debt Obligations on the ABL Priority Collateral and (ii) the Liens securing
the CF Debt Obligations on the CF Debt Priority Collateral rank senior to any Liens securing the ABL Obligations on
the CF Debt Priority Collateral.

_No Interference_

No holder of any CF Debt Obligations may contest the validity or enforceability of the ABL Obligations or
the Liens securing the ABL Obligations, and no holder of any ABL Obligations may contest the validity or
enforceability of the CF Debt Obligations or the Liens securing the CF Debt Obligations.

161


-----

_Exercise of Remedies_

Neither the CF Debt Agents nor the CF Debt Secured Parties may commence or instruct the CF Debt Agents
to commence any judicial or nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings with respect to, seek to have a trustee, receiver,
liquidator or similar official appointed for or over, attempt any action to take possession of, exercise any right, remedy
or power with respect to, or otherwise take any action to enforce its interest in or realize upon, or take any other action
available to it in respect of, the ABL Priority Collateral under any documents governing CF Debt Obligations,
applicable law or otherwise until the associated Discharge of the ABL Obligations (including, without limitation,
exercising any rights under any deposit account control agreement constituting ABL Priority Collateral), it being
agreed that only the ABL Collateral Agent or any Person authorized thereby, acting in accordance with the applicable
documents governing the ABL Obligations, shall be entitled to take any such actions or exercise any such remedies
prior to the associated Discharge of ABL Obligations; provided, however, that a CF Debt Agent (subject to the terms
of the First Lien Intercreditor Agreement and the Junior Lien Intercreditor Agreement, if any) may exercise any or all
such rights with respect to any ABL Priority Collateral (but not rights the exercise of which is otherwise prohibited
by the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement) after a period (the “ABL Priority Standstill Period”) of 180
consecutive days has elapsed from the date of delivery of written notice from the CF Debt Agent to the ABL Collateral
Agent stating that (i) an event of default (as defined under the indenture or other debt facility for such CF Debt
Obligations) has occurred and is continuing thereunder, (ii) the CF Debt Obligations under such indenture or other
debt facility are currently due and payable in full (whether as a result of acceleration thereof or otherwise) in
accordance with the terms of such documents, and (iii) such CF Debt Agent intends to exercise its rights to take such
actions; provided, further, that such CF Debt Agent shall not be entitled to exercise any such rights with respect to
any ABL Priority Collateral in the event (x) the ABL Collateral Agent or the ABL Secured Parties are then diligently
pursuing their rights and remedies with respect to all or a material portion of the ABL Priority Collateral or diligently
attempting to vacate any stay or prohibition against such exercise or (y) a Co-Issuer or any Guarantor is then a debtor
under or with respect to (or otherwise subject to ) any insolvency or liquidation proceeding.

Neither the ABL Collateral Agent nor the ABL Secured Parties may commence or instruct the ABL Collateral
Agent to commence any judicial or nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings with respect to, seek to have a trustee, receiver,
liquidator or similar official appointed for or over, attempt any action to take possession of, exercise any right, remedy
or power with respect to, or otherwise take any action to enforce its interest in or realize upon, or take any other action
available to it in respect of, the CF Debt Priority Collateral under any documents governing ABL Obligations,
applicable law or otherwise until the associated Discharge of the CF Debt Obligations (including, without limitation,
exercising any rights under any deposit account control agreement constituting CF Debt Priority Collateral), it being
agreed that only a CF Debt Agent or any Person authorized thereby, acting in accordance with the applicable
documents governing the CF Debt Obligations, shall be entitled to take any such actions or exercise any such remedies
prior to the associated Discharge of CF Debt Obligations; provided, however, that the ABL Collateral Agent may
exercise any or all such rights with respect to any CF Debt Priority Collateral (but not rights the exercise of which is
otherwise prohibited by the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement) after a period of 180 consecutive days has
elapsed from the date of delivery of written notice from the ABL Collateral Agent to each CF Debt Agent stating that
(i) an event of default (as defined under the documents governing the ABL Obligations) has occurred and is continuing
thereunder, (ii) the ABL Obligations are currently due and payable in full (whether as a result of acceleration thereof
or otherwise) in accordance with the terms of such documentation, and (iii) such ABL Collateral Agent intends to
exercise its rights to take such actions; _provided,_ _further, that such ABL Collateral Agent shall not be entitled to_
exercise any such rights with respect to any CF Debt Priority Collateral in the event (x) any CF Debt Agent or the CF
Debt Secured Parties are then diligently pursuing their rights and remedies with respect to all or a material portion of
the CF Debt Priority Collateral or diligently attempting to vacate any stay or prohibition against such exercise or (y)
a Co-Issuer or any Guarantor is then a debtor under or with respect to (or otherwise subject to ) any insolvency or
liquidation proceeding.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, the trustee or agent acting on behalf of any holders (or the holders themselves)
of obligations secured by junior-priority Liens on any Collateral may, subject to certain provisions of the ABL/Cash
Flow Intercreditor Agreement, take all such actions as it shall deem necessary to (i) perfect or continue the perfection
of its junior-priority Liens or (ii) to create, preserve or protect (but not enforce) the junior-priority Liens on any
Collateral. In addition, the trustee or agent acting on behalf of any holders (or the holders themselves) of obligations
secured by junior-priority Liens may, among other things, (i) file a claim or proof of claim or statement of interest,
_provided_ that an insolvency or bankruptcy proceeding has been commenced by or against a Co-Issuer or any

162


-----

Guarantor, (ii) file any necessary or appropriate responsive or defensive pleadings in opposition to any motion, claim,
adversary proceeding or other pleading made by any person objecting to or otherwise seeking the disallowance of its
claims or Liens, in each case in accordance with the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement, (iii) in accordance with
the provisions of the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement, file any pleadings, objections, motions or agreements
that assert rights or interests available to unsecured creditors, and (iv) vote on any plan of reorganization, file any
proof of claim, make other filings and make any arguments and motions that are, in each case, in accordance with the
terms of the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement.

_Release of Liens_

Upon any sale, transfer, or other disposition of any ABL Priority Collateral that results in the release of the
Lien securing the ABL Obligations on such item of ABL Priority Collateral that (A) is not prohibited by the documents
governing the CF Debt Obligations or (B) occurs in connection with the foreclosure upon or other exercise of rights
and remedies with respect to such ABL Priority Collateral, the Lien securing the CF Debt Obligations on such item
of ABL Priority Collateral will be automatically released; provided that such Lien securing the CF Debt Obligations
shall remain in place with respect to any proceeds of such sale, transfer or other disposition that remain after the
associated Discharge of ABL Obligations. Upon any sale, transfer, or other disposition of any CF Debt Priority
Collateral that results in the release of the Lien securing the CF Debt Obligations on such item of CF Debt Priority
Collateral that (A) is not prohibited by the documents governing the ABL Obligations or (B) occurs in connection
with the foreclosure upon or other exercise of rights and remedies with respect to such CF Debt Priority Collateral,
the Lien securing the ABL Obligations on such item of CF Debt Priority Collateral will be automatically released;
_provided that such Lien securing the ABL Obligations shall remain in place with respect to any proceeds of such sale,_
transfer or other disposition that remain after the associated Discharge of CF Debt Obligations.

_ABL Collateral Agent’s Access and Use Rights_

The CF Debt Secured Parties will (subject to certain exceptions) permit the ABL Collateral Agent to enter
upon and use the CF Debt Priority Collateral for a period not to exceed 180 days (subject to extension during periods
when the ABL Collateral Agent is stayed or otherwise prohibited by law from exercising such rights) following, the
date on which the ABL Collateral Agent takes any enforcement action with respect to the ABL Priority Collateral, for
purposes of (1) assembling and storing the ABL Priority Collateral and completing the processing of and turning into
finished goods of any ABL Priority Collateral consisting of work-in-process, (2) selling any or all of the ABL Priority
Collateral located on such CF Debt Priority Collateral, whether in bulk, in lots or to customers in the ordinary course
of business by liquidation, sale or otherwise, (3) removing any or all of the ABL Priority Collateral located on such
CF Debt Priority Collateral, or (4) taking reasonable actions to protect, secure and otherwise enforce the rights of the
ABL Secured Parties in and to the ABL Priority Collateral; provided, however, that nothing contained in the ABL/Cash
Flow Intercreditor Agreement will restrict the rights of any CF Debt Agent from selling, assigning or otherwise
transferring any such CF Debt Priority Collateral prior to the expiration of such 180-day period if the purchaser,
assignee or transferee thereof agrees to be bound by the applicable provisions of the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor
Agreement.

_Tracing of Collateral and Priorities in Proceeds_

Prior to the issuance of any Enforcement Notice by the ABL Collateral Agent or a CF Debt Agent or the
commencement of any insolvency or liquidation proceeding with respect to a Co-Issuer or a Guarantor, whether any
asset was acquired with “proceeds” (within the meaning of the Uniform Commercial Code) of ABL Priority Collateral
or CF Debt Priority Collateral will be disregarded for purposes of determining the relative priorities in the Collateral
that was so acquired. In addition, unless and until the Discharge of ABL Obligations occurs, the CF Debt Agents and
the CF Debt Secured Parties will each consent to the application, prior to the receipt by the ABL Collateral Agent of
an Enforcement Notice issued by any CF Debt Agent, of cash or other proceeds of Collateral, deposited under account
agreements to the repayment of ABL Obligations pursuant to the ABL Credit Agreement; _provided_ that after the
receipt by the ABL Collateral Agent of an Enforcement Notice from any CF Debt Agent, any identifiable proceeds of
the CF Debt Priority Collateral (whether or not deposited under account agreements with the ABL Agent) shall be
treated as CF Debt Priority Collateral.

163


-----

_Application of Proceeds and Turn-Over Provisions_

In connection with any enforcement action with respect to the Collateral or any insolvency or liquidation
proceeding with respect to a Co-Issuer or any Guarantor, all proceeds of (x) ABL Priority Collateral will first be
applied to the repayment in full of all outstanding ABL Obligations before being applied to any outstanding CF Debt
Obligations and (y) CF Debt Priority Collateral will first be applied to the repayment in full of all outstanding CF Debt
Obligations before being applied to any outstanding ABL Obligations. If any holder of a CF Debt Obligation or ABL
Obligation receives any proceeds of Collateral in contravention of the foregoing, such proceeds will be turned over to
the CF Debt Agent or ABL Collateral Agent, as applicable, for application in accordance with the foregoing.

_Amendment and Refinancings_

The ABL Obligations and the CF Debt Obligations may be amended or refinanced, in whole or in part, in
accordance with the ABL Credit Agreement and the documents governing the CF Debt Obligations, in each case,
without notice to, or consent of, any or all of the lenders, holders, trustee, or agents thereunder, and subject to
continuing rights and obligations of the holders of such refinancing Indebtedness under the ABL/Cash Flow
Intercreditor Agreement; provided that the holders of such refinancing debt, either directly or through an agent or
representative bind themselves to the ABL/Cash Flow Intercreditor Agreement.

**_Certain Matters in Connection with Liquidation and Insolvency Proceedings under the ABL Intercreditor_**
**_Agreement_**

_Debtor-in-Possession Financings_

In connection with any insolvency or liquidation proceeding of a Co-Issuer or any Guarantor, if the ABL
Collateral Agent or the holders of ABL Obligations do not oppose or object to certain debtor-in-possession financings
secured by a Lien on the ABL Priority Collateral or to the use of cash collateral constituting proceeds of ABL Priority
Collateral, no holder of a CF Debt Obligation shall be entitled to object to such use of cash collateral or debtor-inpossession financing to the extent the Liens securing such debtor-in-possession financing are senior to or rank equal
with the Liens of the ABL Collateral Agent on the ABL Priority Collateral. To the extent that the Liens to be provided
to the lenders providing such debtor-in-possession financing secured by a Lien on the ABL Priority Collateral are
senior to, or rank equal with, the Liens of the ABL Collateral Agent and the holders of ABL Obligations on such ABL
Priority Collateral, the Liens securing the CF Debt Obligations on such ABL Priority Collateral will be subordinated
to the Liens provided to the lenders under the debtor-in-possession financing thereon, to the Liens of the ABL
Collateral Agent on the ABL Priority Collateral and any adequate protection Liens granted to the ABL Collateral
Agent and the holders of the ABL Obligations thereon, and to any “carve-out” from the ABL Priority Collateral for
professional fees or United States Trustee fees agreed to by the ABL Collateral Agent, so long as the holders of CF
Debt Obligations retain their valid, perfected and unvoidable Liens on all the CF Debt Priority Collateral, including

Collateral. To the extent that the Liens to be provided to the lenders providing such debtor-in-possession financing

Agents, so long as the holders of ABL Obligations retain their valid, perfected and unvoidable Liens on all the ABL
