made by the purchasers of the notes as set forth under “—Purchaser Representations and Warranties” and the Issuers’
covenants and undertakings referred to below.

**Characterization of the Notes**

In certain circumstances (see e.g. See “Description of Senior First Lien Notes—Optional Redemption,”
“Description of Senior Unsecured Notes—Optional Redemption,” “Description of Senior First Lien Notes—Change
of Control Triggering Event” and “Description of Senior Unsecured Notes—Change of Control Triggering Event”),
we may be obligated to pay amounts in excess of stated principal on the notes. Our obligation to pay such excess
amounts may implicate the provisions of the Treasury regulations relating to “contingent payment debt instruments,”
in which case the timing and amount of income inclusions and the character of income recognized may be different
from the consequences discussed herein. Under these Treasury regulations, however, one or more contingencies will
not cause a debt instrument to be treated as a contingent payment debt instrument if, as of the issue date, such
contingencies in the aggregate are considered “remote” or “incidental.” Although the matter is not free from doubt,
we believe and intend to take the position that the foregoing contingencies should be treated as remote and/or
incidental, in the aggregate, within the meaning of the applicable Treasury regulations as of the date hereof, and thus
do not result in the notes being treated as contingent payment debt instruments under applicable Treasury regulations.
Our position is binding on a holder, unless the holder discloses in the proper manner to the IRS on its tax return for
the year during which it acquires the notes that it is taking a different position. However, this determination is not
binding on, and may be challenged by, the IRS. A successful challenge of this position by the IRS could affect the
timing and amount of a holder’s income and could cause the gain from the sale or other disposition of a note to be
treated as ordinary income, rather than capital gain, and a holder might be required to accrue income on the notes
based upon a “comparable yield” (as defined in the Treasury regulations) in excess of stated interest. This disclosure
assumes that the notes will not be considered contingent payment debt instruments. Holders are urged to consult their

own tax advisors regarding the potential application to the notes of the contingent payment debt instrument Treasury
regulations and the consequences thereof.

**U.S. Holders**

The following is a summary of certain United States federal income tax consequences that will apply to U.S.
holders of the notes.

**_Stated Interest_**

Stated interest on the notes will generally be taxable to you as ordinary income at the time it is received or
accrued, depending on your regular method of accounting for United States federal income tax purposes. It is expected,
and this discussion assumes, that the notes will be issued without original issue discount for United States federal
income tax purposes.

**_Sale, Exchange, Retirement, Redemption or Other Taxable Disposition of Notes_**

Upon the sale, exchange, retirement, redemption or other taxable disposition of a note, you generally will
recognize gain or loss equal to the difference between the amount realized upon the disposition (which does not include
an amount equal to any accrued and unpaid stated interest, which will be taxable as interest income as discussed above)
and the adjusted tax basis of the note. Your adjusted tax basis in a note will, in general, be your cost for that note. Any
gain or loss generally will be capital gain or loss. Capital gains of non-corporate U.S. holders (including individuals)
derived in respect of capital assets held for more than one year are eligible for reduced rates of taxation. The
deductibility of capital losses is subject to limitations.

**Non-U.S. Holders**

The following is a summary of certain United States federal income tax consequences that will apply to nonU.S. holders of the notes.

**_United States Federal Withholding Tax_**

Subject to the discussions of backup withholding and “FATCA” below, United States federal withholding
tax will not apply to any payment of interest on the notes under the “portfolio interest rule,” provided that:

- interest paid on the notes is not effectively connected with your conduct of a trade or business in the United
States;

- you do not actually (or constructively) own 10% or more of the total combined voting power of all classes of
voting stock of the regarded parent entity of any Issuer, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, within the
meaning of the Code and applicable United States Treasury regulations;

- you are not a controlled foreign corporation that is related to the Issuers through stock ownership;

- you are not a bank that is receiving the interest on an extension of credit made pursuant to a loan agreement
entered into in the ordinary course of its trade or business; and

- either (a) you provide your name and address on an applicable Internal Revenue Service (“IRS”) Form W-8,
and certify, under penalties of perjury, that you are not a United States person as defined under the Code or
(b) you hold your notes through certain foreign intermediaries and satisfy the certification requirements of
applicable United States Treasury regulations. Special certification rules apply to non-U.S. holders that are
pass-through entities rather than corporations or individuals.

385


-----

If you cannot satisfy the requirements described above, payments of interest made to you will be subject to
a 30% United States federal withholding tax, unless you provide the applicable withholding agent with a properly
executed:

- IRS Form W-8BEN or W-8BEN-E (or other applicable form) certifying an exemption from or reduction in
withholding under an applicable income tax treaty; or

- IRS Form W-8ECI (or other applicable form) certifying that interest paid on the notes is not subject to
withholding tax because it is effectively connected with your conduct of a trade or business in the United
States (as discussed below under “—United States Federal Income Tax”).

**_United States Federal Income Tax_**

If you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States and interest on the notes is effectively connected
with the conduct of that trade or business (and, if required by an applicable income tax treaty, is attributable to a
United States permanent establishment or fixed base), then you will be subject to United States federal income tax on
that interest on a net income basis (although you will be exempt from the 30% United States federal withholding tax,
provided the certification requirements discussed above in “—United States Federal Withholding Tax” are satisfied)
in generally the same manner as if you were a United States person as defined under the Code. In addition, if you are
a foreign corporation, you may be subject to a branch profits tax equal to 30% (or lower applicable income tax treaty
rate) of your effectively connected earnings and profits, subject to certain adjustments.

Subject to the discussions of backup withholding and “FATCA” below, any gain realized on the sale,
exchange, retirement, redemption or other taxable disposition of a note generally will not be subject to United States
federal income tax unless:

- the gain is effectively connected with your conduct of a trade or business in the United States (and, if required
by an applicable income tax treaty, is attributable to a United States permanent establishment or fixed base),
in which case you will be subject to United States federal income tax on such gain in the same manner as
described above with respect to effectively connected interest; or

- you are an individual who is present in the United States for 183 days or more in the taxable year of that
disposition, and certain other conditions are met, in which case you will be subject to United States federal
income tax at a rate of 30% (or a lower rate under an applicable income tax treaty) on such gain (net of certain
United States source losses).

**Information Reporting and Backup Withholding**

**_U.S. Holders_**

In general, information reporting requirements will apply to payments of stated interest on the notes and the
proceeds of the sale or other taxable disposition (including a retirement or redemption) of a note paid to you (unless
you are an exempt recipient). Backup withholding may apply to such payments (currently at a rate of 24%), unless the
holder (i) is an entity that is exempt from backup withholding (generally including corporations, tax-exempt
organizations and certain qualified nominees) and, when required, provides appropriate documentation to that effect
or (ii) provides the applicable withholding agent with its social security or other taxpayer identification number
(“TIN”) within a reasonable time after a request therefor, certifies that the TIN provided is correct and that the holder
has not been notified by the IRS that it is subject to backup withholding due to a prior underreporting of interest or
dividends, and otherwise complies with applicable requirements of the backup withholding rules. A U.S. holder who
does not provide the applicable withholding agent with its correct TIN may be subject to penalties imposed by the
IRS.

Backup withholding is not an additional tax and any amounts withheld under the backup withholding rules
will be allowed as a refund or a credit against your United States federal income tax liability, provided the required
information is timely furnished to the IRS.

**_Non-U.S. Holders_**

Interest paid to you and the amount of tax, if any, withheld with respect to those payments generally will be
reported to the IRS. Copies of the information returns reporting such interest payments and any withholding may also

tax treaty. In general, you will not be subject to backup withholding with respect to payments of interest on the notes

that you are a United States person as defined under the Code, and such withholding agent has received from you the

Information reporting and, depending on the circumstances, backup withholding (currently at a rate of 24%)

The proceeds of a disposition (including a retirement or redemption) effected outside the United States by a
non-U.S. holder of the notes to or through a foreign office of a broker generally will not be subject to backup
withholding or related information reporting. However, if that broker has certain types of relationships with the United
States described in Treasury regulations, such information reporting requirements will apply (but backup withholding
generally will not apply) unless that broker has documentary evidence in its files of such holder’s status as a non-U.S.
holder.

Backup withholding is not an additional tax and any amounts withheld under the backup withholding rules
will be allowed as a refund or a credit against your United States federal income tax liability, provided the required
information is timely furnished to the IRS.

**FATCA**

Sections 1471 through 1474 of the Code (such Sections commonly referred to as “FATCA”), may impose a
30% United States federal withholding tax on any interest income paid on the notes to (i) a “foreign financial
institution” (as specifically defined in the Code), unless such institution enters into an agreement with the U.S.
government to collect and provide to the U.S. tax authorities substantial information regarding U.S. account holders
of such institution (which would include certain equity and debt holders of such institution, as well as certain account
holders that are foreign entities with U.S. owners) and to withhold certain amounts, or (ii) a foreign entity that is not
a financial institution (as the beneficial owner or as an intermediary for the beneficial owner), unless such entity
provides the withholding agent with a certification identifying the substantial U.S. owners of the entity, which
generally includes any U.S. person who directly or indirectly owns more than 10% of the entity. If an interest payment
is both subject to withholding under FATCA and subject to the withholding tax discussed above under “—Non-U.S.
Holders—United States Federal Withholding Tax,” the withholding under FATCA may be credited against, and
therefore reduce, such other withholding tax.

An intergovernmental agreement between the U.S. and the applicable foreign country, or future Treasury
regulations or other guidance, may modify these requirements. In many cases, non-U.S. holders may be able to indicate
their exemption from, or compliance with, FATCA by providing a properly completed Form W-8BEN or W-8BENE to the applicable withholding agent certifying as to such status under FATCA; however, it is possible that additional
information and diligence requirements will apply in order for a holder to establish an exemption from withholding
under FATCA to the applicable withholding agent. Investors are encouraged to consult their own tax advisors
regarding the implications of FATCA with respect to their investment in our notes. You should consult your own tax
advisor regarding these rules and whether they may be relevant to your ownership and disposition of the notes.

FATCA withholding rules were previously scheduled to take effect on January 1, 2019, that would have
applied to payments of gross proceeds from the sale or other disposition of property of a type that can produce U.S.
source interest or dividends. However, such withholding has effectively been suspended under proposed Treasury
regulations that may be relied on until final regulations become effective. Nonetheless, there can be no assurance that

**CERTAIN ERISA CONSIDERATIONS**

The following is a summary of certain considerations associated with the purchase and holding of the notes
by employee benefit plans that are subject to Title I of the U.S. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974,
as amended (“ERISA”), plans, individual retirement accounts and other arrangements that are subject to Section 4975
of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the “Code”) or provisions under any other federal, state,
local, non-U.S. or other laws or regulations that are similar to such provisions of the Code or ERISA (collectively,
“Similar Laws”), and entities or accounts whose underlying assets are considered to include “plan assets” of any such
plan, account or arrangement (each, a “Plan”).

**_General Fiduciary Matters_**

ERISA and the Code impose certain duties on persons who are fiduciaries of a Plan subject to Part 4 of Title
I of ERISA or Section 4975 of the Code (an “ERISA Plan”) and prohibit certain transactions involving the assets of
an ERISA Plan and its fiduciaries or other interested parties. Under ERISA and the Code, any person who exercises
any discretionary authority or control over the administration of such an ERISA Plan or the management or disposition
of the assets of such an ERISA Plan, or who renders investment advice for a fee or other compensation to such an
ERISA Plan, is generally considered to be a fiduciary of the ERISA Plan.

In considering an investment in the notes of a portion of the assets of any Plan, a fiduciary should determine
whether the investment is in accordance with the documents and instruments governing the Plan and the applicable
provisions of ERISA, the Code or any Similar Law relating to a fiduciary’s duties to the Plan including, without
limitation, the prudence, diversification, delegation of control and prohibited transaction provisions of ERISA, the
Code and any other applicable Similar Laws.

**_Prohibited Transaction Issues_**

Section 406 of ERISA and Section 4975 of the Code prohibit ERISA Plans from engaging in specified
transactions involving plan assets with persons or entities who are “parties in interest,” within the meaning of ERISA,
or “disqualified persons,” within the meaning of Section 4975 of the Code, unless an exemption is available. A party
in interest or disqualified person who engaged in a non-exempt prohibited transaction may be subject to excise taxes
and other penalties and liabilities under ERISA and the Code. In addition, the fiduciary of the ERISA Plan that engaged
in such a non-exempt prohibited transaction may be subject to penalties and liabilities under ERISA and the Code.
The acquisition and/or holding of notes by an ERISA Plan with respect to which any Issuer, a guarantor or an initial
purchaser is considered a party in interest or a disqualified person may constitute or result in a direct or indirect
prohibited transaction under Section 406 of ERISA and/or Section 4975 of the Code, unless the investment is acquired
and is held in accordance with an applicable statutory, class or individual prohibited transaction exemption. In this
regard, the U.S. Department of Labor has issued prohibited transaction class exemptions, or “PTCEs,” that may apply
to the acquisition and holding of the notes. These class exemptions include, without limitation, PTCE 84-14 respecting
transactions determined by independent qualified professional asset managers, PTCE 90-1 respecting insurance
company pooled separate accounts, PTCE 91-38 respecting bank collective investment funds, PTCE 95-60 respecting
life insurance company general accounts and PTCE 96-23 respecting transactions determined by in-house asset
managers. In addition, Section 408(b)(17) of ERISA and Section 4975(d)(20) of the Code provide relief from the
prohibited transaction provisions of ERISA and Section 4975 of the Code for certain transactions, provided that neither
the issuer of the securities nor any of its affiliates (directly or indirectly) have or exercise any discretionary authority
or control or render any investment advice with respect to the assets of any ERISA Plan involved in the transaction
and provided further that the ERISA Plan receives no less, nor pays no more, than adequate consideration in
connection with the transaction. Each of the above-noted exemptions contains conditions and limitations on its
application. Fiduciaries of Plans considering acquiring and/or holdings the notes in reliance of these or any other
exemption should carefully review the exemption to assure it is applicable. There can be no assurance that all of the
conditions of any such exemptions will be satisfied.

Because of the foregoing, the notes should not be purchased or held by any person investing “plan assets” of
any Plan, unless such purchase and holding will not constitute a non-exempt prohibited transaction under ERISA and
the Code or similar violation of any applicable Similar Laws.

389

**_Representation_**

Accordingly, by acceptance of a note, each purchaser and subsequent transferee of a note will be deemed to
have represented and warranted that either (i) no portion of the assets used by such purchaser or transferee to acquire
or hold the notes (or any interest therein) constitutes assets of any Plan or (ii) the purchase and holding of the notes
(or any interest therein) by such purchaser or transferee will not constitute a non-exempt prohibited transaction under
Section 406 of ERISA or Section 4975 of the Code or a similar violation under any applicable Similar Laws.

The foregoing discussion is general in nature and is not intended to be all inclusive nor should it be construed
as legal advice. Due to the complexity of these rules and the penalties that may be imposed upon persons involved in
non-exempt prohibited transactions, it is particularly important that fiduciaries, or other persons considering
purchasing the notes on behalf of, or with the assets of, any Plan, consult with their counsel regarding the potential
applicability of ERISA, Section 4975 of the Code and any Similar Laws to such investment and whether an exemption
would be applicable to the purchase and holding of the notes. Purchasers have exclusive responsibility for ensuring
that their purchase and holding of the Notes do not violate the fiduciary responsibility or prohibited transaction rules
of ERISA, the Code, or any applicable Similar Laws. Except as otherwise stated herein, the sale of any notes to a Plan
is in no respect a representation by the Issuers, an initial purchaser, or any of their respective affiliates or
representatives that such an investment meets all legal requirements with respect to such investments by any such Plan
generally or any particular Plan, or that such investment is appropriate for such Plans generally or any particular Plan.

**Management’s Responsibility for the Consolidated Financial Statements**

Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of these consolidated financial
statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America; this includes
the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of
consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

**Auditors’ Responsibility**

Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America.
Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the
consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement.

An audit involves performing procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the
consolidated financial statements. The procedures selected depend on the auditor’s judgment, including the assessment
of the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making
those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the Company’s preparation and fair
presentation of the consolidated financial statements in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the
circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company’s internal control.
Accordingly, we express no such opinion. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies
used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall
presentation of the consolidated financial statements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient
and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.

**Opinion**

In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects,
the financial position of the Company as of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, and the results of their operations
and their cash flows for the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018, in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.

**Note 1 — The Company and its Significant Accounting Policies**

**_Business_**

PetSmart, Inc., including its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries that we control (herein
collectively referred to as the “Company,” “we,” “our,” or “us,” unless the context requires otherwise), is a leading
specialty provider of products, services and solutions for the lifetime needs of pets. We offer a broad assortment of
products for all the life stages of pets, as well as various services, including professional grooming and boarding for
cats and dogs, and training and day camp for dogs. We also offer pet products through our e-commerce websites
(PetSmart.com, Chewy.com and OnlyNaturalPet.com) and maintain the content site PetMD.com. As of February 2,
2020, we operated 1,660 stores and had full-service veterinary hospitals, owned and operated by third-parties, in 848
of our stores.

On December 14, 2014, we entered into an Agreement and Plan of Merger with Argos Holdings Inc. (“Argos
Holdings”) and Argos Merger Sub Inc. (“Merger Sub”), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Argos Holdings. Argos
Holdings is indirectly controlled by Argos Intermediate Holdco I Inc. (“Intermediate Holdco I”), which is directly
controlled by a consortium including funds advised by BC Partners, Inc., La Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec,
affiliates of GIC Special Investments Pte Ltd, affiliates of StepStone Group LP, and Longview Asset Management,
LLC (collectively, the “Sponsors”). The transaction closed on March 11, 2015 (the “Transaction Date”). At closing,
Merger Sub was merged with and into PetSmart, Inc. (the “Merger”), with PetSmart, Inc. continuing as the surviving
corporation as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Argos Holdings. Argos Holdings has no operating activity, and its sole
asset is its 100% ownership of PetSmart, Inc. We refer to the Merger on March 11, 2015 as the “Argos Transaction.”

The Company pays an aggregate of $4.0 million in annual management fees to select Sponsors, which are
related parties, under a service agreement entered into with the Sponsors on the Transaction Date, which are recorded
in operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive
Loss. The Company is subject to a termination fee equal to the net present value of the annual management fees that
would have been payable with respect to the period from the termination date through the twelfth (12th) anniversary
of the Transaction Date, or, if terminated following the twelfth (12th) anniversary of the Transaction Date, through
the first anniversary of the Transaction Date occurring after the termination date.

On April 17, 2017, we entered into an Agreement of Merger (the “Chewy Merger Agreement”) with Citrus
Merger Corp. (“Chewy Merger Sub”), a wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc., and Chewy, Inc. On May 31,
2017 (the “Acquisition Date”), the transaction closed and as contemplated by the Chewy Merger Agreement, Chewy
Merger Sub merged with and into Chewy, Inc. (the “Chewy Merger”), with Chewy, Inc. surviving as a wholly-owned
subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. We refer to the Chewy Merger and the acquisition of Chewy, Inc. by the Company on
May 31, 2017 herein as the “Chewy Acquisition.”

On July 2, 2018, we transitioned our online pet pharmacy business from PetSmart.com to Chewy.com. While
a portion of the online pet pharmacy activity legally resides within a wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. (the
“Pharmacy Subsidiary”) outside of Chewy, Inc., we have combined the financial results of the Pharmacy Subsidiary
with the financial results of Chewy, Inc. beginning on July 2, 2018 since Chewy, Inc. began to operate the online pet
pharmacy business, including the Pharmacy Subsidiary, at that time. We refer to Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries from
the Acquisition Date through July 2, 2018, and Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries plus the Pharmacy Subsidiary starting
on July 2, 2018, collectively as “Chewy.” The Pharmacy Subsidiary and Chewy, Inc. are also parties to a services
agreement that provides for the payment of a management fee by the Pharmacy Subsidiary to Chewy, Inc. for services
Chewy, Inc. provides to the Pharmacy Subsidiary. Pursuant to the terms of that agreement, Chewy, Inc. is entitled to
receive an amount equal to 25% of the Pharmacy Subsidiary’s net sales as fees for the services that it provides to the
Pharmacy Subsidiary. This management fee is eliminated in the combined Chewy financial results as well as the
consolidated results of the Company herein. We refer to our consolidated results, excluding Chewy, herein as
“PetSmart.”

On June 1, 2018, the board of directors of the Company declared and made a dividend in the form of 20.0%

On June 18, 2019, Chewy, Inc. completed an initial public offering (“IPO”) of shares of Class A common
stock. A wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. sold 47,875,000 shares at $22.00 per share, including 6,975,000
shares sold upon exercise by the underwriters of the IPO of their option to purchase additional shares (“Shares Sold”).
The Company received net proceeds of $1,000.6 million from the sale of these shares after deducting underwriting

Prior to completion of the IPO, Chewy, Inc.’s outstanding common stock was reclassified into Class B

identical, except with respect to voting, conversion and transfer rights. Each share of Class A common stock is entitled
to one vote. Each share of Class B common stock is entitled to ten votes and is convertible at any time (and upon the
occurrence of certain events) into one share of Class A common stock. We refer to the IPO of Chewy, Inc. which was
completed on June 18, 2019 as the “Chewy IPO.”

On December 20, 2019, a wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. converted 6,352,546 shares of Chewy,
Inc. Class B common stock into Class A common stock and sold these shares at $27.95 per share pursuant to Rule

PetSmart, Inc. converted 3,850,000 shares of Chewy, Inc. Class B common stock into Class A common stock and sold
these shares at $28.75 per share also pursuant to Rule 144 of the Act (collectively, the “Rule 144 Transactions”). The
Company received net proceeds of $288.1 million from the Rule 144 Transactions after deducting commissions and
fees.

As of February 2, 2020, as a result of the Chewy IPO, the Rule 144 Transactions, and the vesting of restricted
stock units under the Chewy Omnibus Incentive Plan (refer to Note 7), the Company, through its wholly-owned

own an additional 19.6% of Chewy, Inc. outstanding common stock, which is held by an entity outside of the

owned by wholly-owned subsidiaries of the Company represented 75.0% of the combined voting power of Chewy,
Inc. common stock, and therefore, we continue to consolidate the financial results of Chewy, Inc.

**_Principles of Consolidation_**

Our consolidated financial statements include the Company’s accounts and those of its wholly-owned and
majority-owned subsidiaries that we control. We have eliminated all intercompany accounts and transactions.

**_Fiscal Year_**

Our fiscal years consist of 52 or 53-weeks and end on the Sunday nearest to January 31st. Fiscal year 2019,
which ended on February 2, 2020, was a 52-week year. Fiscal year 2018, which ended on February 3, 2019, was a 53week year. Fiscal year 2017, which ended on January 28, 2018, was a 52-week year. Unless otherwise specified, all
references to years in these consolidated financial statements are to fiscal years.

**_Use of Estimates_**

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States of America (“GAAP”) requires management to make certain estimates, judgments, and assumptions
that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of
the consolidated financial statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses for the reporting period.
Management bases their estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that they believe to be
reasonable under the circumstances. These estimates form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values
of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Under different assumptions or conditions,
actual results could differ from these estimates.

**_Financial Instruments_**

Our short-term financial instruments consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash,
receivables, accounts payable, accrued payroll, bonus, and employee benefits, and accrued occupancy expenses. These
balances, as presented in the consolidated financial statements as of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019,
approximate fair value because of their short-term nature. Our long-term financial instruments consist primarily of
long-term debt, and are carried at historical cost as detailed in Note 10.

Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an
orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. As such, fair value is a market-based
measurement that should be determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset
or a liability. Accounting guidance prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value into three levels and bases the
categorization within the hierarchy upon the lowest level of input that is available and significant to the fair value
measurement:

Level 1 – Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.

Level 2 – Inputs that are based upon quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets, quoted prices
for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active, and model-based valuation techniques for which all
significant inputs are observable in the market or can be derived from observable market data.

Level 3 – Inputs that cannot be corroborated by observable market data and reflect the use of significant
management judgment. Valuation techniques could include the use of discounted cash flow models and similar
techniques.

In instances where the determination of the fair value measurement is based on inputs from different levels
of the fair value hierarchy, the level in the fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety
is classified is based on the lowest level input that is significant to the fair value measurement in its entirety. Our
assessment of the significance of a particular input to the fair value measurement in its entirety requires judgment and
considers factors specific to the asset or liability.

**_Cash and Cash Equivalents_**

We consider any liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents. Included
in cash and cash equivalents are credit and debit card receivables from banks, which typically settle within five
business days, of $130.8 million and $112.2 million as of February 2, 2020, and February 3, 2019, respectively. Cash
equivalents also consist of institutional money market funds and are carried at cost, which approximates fair value.

Under our cash management system, a book overdraft balance exists for our primary disbursement accounts.
This overdraft represents uncleared checks in excess of cash balances in the related bank accounts. Our funds are
transferred on an as-needed basis to pay for clearing checks. As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, book
overdrafts of $28.1 million and $4.6 million, respectively, were included in accounts payable and book overdraft on
the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

**_Vendor Allowances_**

We receive vendor allowances from agreements made with certain merchandise suppliers in the form of
percentage or volume rebates. Additionally, certain vendors provide funding for discounts relating to our online autoship subscription program which are passed on to our customers. Rebates are generally determined using agreed upon
percentages. However, certain of our vendor rebates are dependent upon reaching minimum purchase thresholds. In
these instances, we evaluate the likelihood of reaching purchase thresholds using past experience and current forecasts.
When volume rebates can be reasonably estimated and it is probable that minimum purchase thresholds will be met,
we record a portion of the rebate as we make progress toward the purchase threshold. Generally, rebates received from
vendors are recorded as a reduction of the carrying value of our inventory, and therefore, such amounts are ultimately
recognized as a reduction to cost of merchandise sales on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss when the inventory is sold.

Prior to fiscal year 2018, we also received vendor allowances in the form of temporary price reductions.
Temporary price reductions were typically 4-5 week promotional periods during which we agreed to reduce the retail
price of certain merchandise, and vendors reimbursed us at a price per unit for actual units sold during the period.
Temporary price reductions were recorded as direct reductions to cost of merchandise sales on the Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss when the inventory was sold.

We also receive vendor allowances in the form of advertising funding agreements. Beginning in fiscal year
2018, in connection with our annual vendor negotiations, we made changes to certain merchandise vendor contracts
which allow us greater flexibility in the way we use certain vendor allowances. As a result of these changes, these
vendor allowances are recorded as a reduction to the carrying value of our inventory and, therefore, are ultimately
recognized as a reduction to cost of merchandise sales on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss when the inventory is sold. Under our vendor contracts prior to fiscal year 2018, advertising
vendor allowances were either related to specifically identifiable advertising costs incurred to promote and sell vendor
products or allowed for general marketing activities. Vendor allowances for specifically identifiable advertising costs
were recorded as a direct reduction to operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated Statements
of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. Vendor allowances for general marketing were recorded as a direct reduction
to cost of merchandise sales on the Consolidated Statement of Operations and Comprehensive Loss.

Additionally, we receive vendor allowances as reimbursements of costs incurred for certain fixtures used to
display and sell our suppliers’ products. Vendor allowances for fixtures are recorded as a reduction to operating,
general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. Finally,
we receive allowances for defective products and non-compliance with our shipping standards which are recorded as
reductions to cost of merchandise sales on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss.

**_Merchandise Inventories and Valuation Reserves_**

Merchandise inventories represent finished goods and are recorded at the lower of cost or net realizable value.
We use a combination of the moving average cost method and the first-in first-out (FIFO) method when determining
the value of inventory. Inventory balances include inbound freight and customs fees on imported products.

We have established reserves for estimated inventory shrinkage between physical inventories. Physical
inventory counts are taken on a regular basis in our stores and inventory is adjusted accordingly. Stores generally
perform physical inventories at least once per year and count certain inventory items between physical inventories.
Distribution and fulfillment centers perform cycle counts on a regular basis. For each reporting period presented, we
estimate the inventory shrinkage based on historical trends. Changes in shrink results or market conditions could cause
actual results to vary from estimates used to establish the reserves.

We also have reserves for estimated inventory obsolescence and to reduce merchandise inventory to the lower
of cost or net realizable value. We evaluate inventory for excess, obsolescence, or other factors that may render
inventories unmarketable at historical cost. Factors used in determining obsolescence reserves, which are recorded to
reflect approximate net realizable value of our inventories, include current and anticipated demand, customer
preferences, age of merchandise, seasonal trends, and decisions to discontinue certain products. If assumptions about

**_Property and Equipment_**

Property and equipment are recorded at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization. Depreciation is
provided on furniture, fixtures, equipment, computer software and buildings using the straight-line method over the
estimated useful lives of the related assets. Leasehold improvements and finance right-of-use assets are amortized
using the straight-line method over the shorter of the lease term or the estimated useful lives of the related assets.
Computer software consists primarily of third-party software purchased for internal use. Costs associated with the
preliminary stage of a project are expensed as incurred. In the development phase, qualifying external and internal
costs, such as payroll and payroll-related costs of employees, external consulting, and internal labor costs directly
associated with developing significant computer software applications for internal use are capitalized. Training costs,
data conversion costs, and maintenance costs are expensed as incurred. Maintenance and repairs to furniture, fixtures,
and equipment are expensed as incurred.

We review property and equipment for impairment based on undiscounted cash flows on a quarterly basis
and whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be
recoverable. If this review indicates that the carrying amount of the property and equipment is not recoverable, we
recognize an impairment loss, which is determined by calculating the fair value of the assets using estimated
discounted cash flows. We recognized impairment charges for property and equipment of $13.0 million, $4.8 million,
and $5.5 million related to under-performing stores, stores that were scheduled to be closed, and natural disasters for
the year ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018, respectively.

Our property and equipment are depreciated using the following typical estimated useful lives:

Furniture, fixtures, and equipment ....................................... 2 to 10 years
Leasehold improvements ..................................................... 1 to 20 years
Computer software .............................................................. 3 to 7 years

The Company performs its review for potential impairment of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets
annually during the fourth quarter unless a triggering event occurs which would require that the review be performed
earlier. In performing the annual goodwill impairment review, we determined the consolidated reporting entity to have
the following two operating units which also represent two separate reporting units: PetSmart and Chewy. We may
elect to assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of our reporting
units is less than the carrying amount prior to performing a quantitative impairment test. If this is the case, a
quantitative impairment test is required. If it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of the reporting unit is not less
than its carrying amount, a quantitative impairment test is not required. If a quantitative impairment test is required,
or if we choose to bypass the optional qualitative assessment, the fair value of the reporting unit is compared to its
carrying amount (including goodwill). If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then a
goodwill impairment charge is recognized for the amount by which the reporting unit’s carrying amount exceeds its
fair value. The fair value of a reporting unit under the quantitative impairment test is determined using a combination
of valuation methodologies, including a discounted cash flow analysis, a guideline public company analysis, and a
guideline transaction analysis.

When evaluating indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment, we may first perform a qualitative
assessment to determine whether it is more likely than not that an intangible asset group is impaired. In performing
this qualitative assessment, we evaluate if changes in events or circumstances have occurred that indicate that
impairment may exist. If we do not perform a qualitative impairment assessment or if changes in events and
circumstances indicate that a quantitative assessment should be performed, we are required to calculate the fair value
of the intangible asset group.

Refer to Note 3 and Note 4 for further discussion regarding goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets.

**_Definite-Lived Intangible Assets_**

As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, we had $336.4 million and $406.9 million of definite-lived
intangible assets, respectively, net of amortization, primarily associated with the Chewy Acquisition and the Argos
Transaction. Intangible assets determined to have definite-lives are amortized over their estimated useful lives, ranging
from 2 to 12 years, or the remaining assumed lease term for below market leasehold positions. Below market leasehold
positions and related accumulated amortization were reclassified to operating right-of-use assets, net, on the
Consolidated Balance Sheets upon our adoption of Accounting Standards Update (“ASU”) 2016-02, Leases (Topic
_842), as of the first day of fiscal year 2019._

We review definite-lived intangible assets for impairment on a quarterly basis and whenever events or
changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. If this review
indicates that the carrying amount of the definite-lived intangible assets is not recoverable, we recognize an
impairment loss, which is measured at fair value using estimated discounted cash flows.

Refer to Note 4 for further discussion regarding definite-lived intangible assets.

**_Insurance Liabilities and Reserves_**

We maintain workers’ compensation, general liability, product liability, property insurance and other types
of insurance policies related to our operations, properties, and leasehold interests. For some associates, we maintain
full coverage health insurance plans. For all other eligible associates, we maintain self-insured health plans. Workers’
compensation policies generally carry a $1.0 million per occurrence deductible exposure. Our general liability policies
specify a $1.0 million per occurrence self-insured retention. We establish reserves for claims under workers’
compensation and general liability plans based on periodic actuarial estimates of the amount of loss for all pending
claims, including estimates for claims that have been incurred but not reported. Our loss estimates rely on actuarial
observations of ultimate loss experience for similar historical events, and changes in such assumptions could result in
an adjustment, favorable or adverse, to our reserves. As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, we had

**_Income Taxes_**

Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized for temporary differences between the financial
statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their corresponding tax bases. Deferred taxes are
measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the assets or liabilities are expected to be realized.
Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance for any portion that is not more likely than not to be realized.

The Company records a liability for unrecognized tax benefits resulting from uncertain tax positions taken
or expected to be taken in a tax return. The Company records interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits
as income tax expense.

On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to
as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (“Tax Act”). The Tax Act made significant changes to the U.S. tax code. In the period
ended January 28, 2018, we recorded a provisional discrete net tax benefit associated with the Tax Act and related
matters. For the year ended February 3, 2019, we finalized our accounting for the Tax Act in accordance with
Securities and Exchange Commission guidance under Staff Accounting Bulletin 118, and the impact recorded was not
material.

As of February 3, 2019, we finalized our policy and have elected to use the period cost method for global
intangible low-tax income provisions and therefore have not adjusted any of the deferred tax assets or liabilities of our
foreign subsidiaries for the new tax.

Refer to Note 8 for further discussion regarding income taxes.

**_Revenue Recognition_**

Revenue is recognized net of applicable sales tax on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss. We record the sales tax liability in other current liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
We recognize revenue for store merchandise sales when the customer receives and pays for the merchandise at the
register. We recognize revenue from professional grooming, boarding, and dog training when the services are
performed. Ship-to-home internet sales are recognized once an online order has shipped from one of our fulfillment
centers and delivered to the carrier. Amounts related to shipping and handling that are billed to customers are reflected
in merchandise sales, and the related costs are reflected in cost of merchandise sales. Buy-online, pick-up in store
sales are recognized once the customer has picked up their order from our store.

F 14


-----

**PetSmart, Inc. and Subsidiaries**
**Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)**

To encourage customers to purchase our products and services, we periodically provide incentive offers.
Generally, these promotions include current discount offers, such as percentage discounts off current purchases and
other similar offers. These offers, when accepted by the customer, are treated as a reduction to the purchase price of
the related transaction. These offers are included in net sales on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss.

We record deferred revenue for the sale of gift cards and recognize this revenue in net sales when cards are
redeemed. Gift card breakage income is recognized over two years based upon historical redemption patterns and
represents the balance of gift cards for which we believe the likelihood of redemption by the customer is remote.
We recognized $2.7 million, $2.6 million, and $3.2 million of gift card breakage income for the years ended
February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018, respectively.

We record allowances for estimated returns based on historical return patterns. These allowances were not
material as of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019.

In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (“FASB”) issued ASU 2014-09, _Revenue from_
_Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which was further clarified and amended. The standard creates a_
comprehensive and converged standard on revenue recognition that supersedes revenue recognition requirements in
Topic 605 and most industry-specific guidance. The core principle is that an entity should recognize revenue to depict
the transfer of promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity
expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. For public companies, as well as certain nonprofit
entities and employee benefit plans, this standard was effective for years beginning after December 15, 2017, and
interim periods within those years. For private companies, the standard was effective for years beginning after
December 15, 2018, and interim periods within those years. In each case, early adoption was permitted.

We adopted the standard on the first day of fiscal year 2018 using the modified retrospective transition
method. As a result of our adoption of the standard, gift card breakage, which was previously recorded as a reduction
to operating, general, and administrative expenses in our Consolidated Statements of Operations and Other
Comprehensive Loss, is now recorded in other revenue. In addition, the balance sheet presentation of our sales return
reserve has changed to present a separate return asset and liability, instead of the net presentation in prior periods as
commonly used under previous GAAP. The return asset and liability are included in prepaid expenses and other
current assets and other current liabilities, respectively, on the Consolidated Balance Sheets. Finally, under the
standard, we defer revenue related to certain promotional offers that are determined to represent a material right to the
customer. We recognize this revenue in net sales at the earlier of when the promotional offer is redeemed or expires.
None of the changes as a result of the standard required us to make a cumulative effect adjustment to the opening
balance of our accumulated deficit under the modified retrospective transition method, and none of the changes had a
material impact on our consolidated financial statements.

Our net sales amount represents total revenue recognized from purchases of products and services by
customers, with the exception of sublease income and reimbursements for specific operating expenses charged to
third-party veterinary offices located within many of our stores under our agreements with them, which are included
in other revenue on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. We recognized sublease
income and reimbursements for specific operating costs from third-party veterinary offices of $42.7 million,
$43.3 million, and $44.6 million for the years ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018,
respectively. The related costs are included in cost of other revenue on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss.

**_Customer Loyalty Program_**

During 2018, we implemented a customer loyalty program, PetSmart Treats, in which members earn points
primarily based on purchases in our stores and on PetSmart.com. Points earned by members are valid for at least one
year and may be redeemed against purchases of merchandise or services in our stores or on PetSmart.com. The
PetSmart Treats loyalty program represents a contract with each member that creates enforceable rights and
obligations. In exchange for the member’s consideration, the member is granted the right to a specified number of
loyalty points. The points earned are a distinct promise from the original purchase that can be exchanged for future

F 15


-----

**PetSmart, Inc. and Subsidiaries**
**Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)**

goods or services, which creates a performance obligation for the Company to provide goods or services until those
points are redeemed or expire.

The Company allocates revenue to points earned on qualifying purchases and defers recognition until the
points are redeemed. The amount of revenue deferred is based on the relative stand-alone selling price method, which
includes an estimate for points not expected to be redeemed. The estimated redemption rate is based on historical
experience and other assumptions. The Company defers the value of points earned that are estimated to be redeemed
at the time of the initial purchase in other current liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets until the points are
redeemed. As of February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, deferred revenue related to the PetSmart Treats program was
$29.5 million and $19.9 million, respectively. Revenue recognized for redeemed points was $115.8 million and $14.4
million for the years ended February 2, 2020 and February 3, 2019, respectively.

**_Cost of Merchandise Sales_**

Cost of merchandise sales includes the following types of expenses:

- Purchase price of inventory sold;

- Transportation costs associated with inventory;

- Inventory shrinkage costs and valuation adjustments;

- Costs associated with operating our distribution network, including payroll and benefit costs, occupancy costs, utilities
costs, and depreciation;

- Costs associated with storage and handling of inventory;

- Store occupancy costs, including rent, common area maintenance, real estate taxes, utilities, and depreciation of
leasehold improvements and finance lease assets; and

- Reductions for vendor funded promotions, discounts, rebates, temporary price reductions, defective products, noncompliance and general marketing activities.

**_Cost of Services Sales_**

Cost of services sales primarily relates to payroll and benefit expenses for PetSmart-employed groomers,
trainers, and PetsHotel associates. Also included in cost of services sales are services-related costs for supplies and
repairs, as well as professional fees for the training of groomers, trainers, and PetsHotel associates.

**_Cost of Other Revenue_**

Cost of other revenue includes the costs related to license fees and specific operating expenses charged to
third-party veterinary offices located within many of our stores.

**_Vendor Concentration Risk_**

We purchase merchandise inventories from several hundred vendors worldwide. Sales of products from our
three largest vendors represented approximately 32.2%, 32.5%, and 30.9% of our merchandise sales for the years
ended February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018, respectively.

**_Leases_**

In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842), which was subsequently modified
through several additional ASUs (collectively, the “Lease Standard”). The Lease Standard is intended to increase

F 16


-----

**PetSmart, Inc. and Subsidiaries**
**Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)**

transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance
sheet for those leases classified as operating leases under prior GAAP. The Lease Standard requires that a lessee
should recognize a liability to make lease payments and a right-of-use (“ROU”) asset representing its right to use the
underlying asset for the lease term on the balance sheet. We adopted the Lease Standard by recognizing a cumulative
effect adjustment as of the first day of fiscal year 2019, and as a result, we did not adjust prior periods. We elected the
package of practical expedients permitted under the transition guidance which allowed us not to reassess the
identification, classification and initial direct costs of existing leases as of the adoption date. Additionally, as of the
adoption date, we adjusted the carrying value of the lease liability for cumulative prepaid or accrued lease payments,
deferred lease incentives, unamortized initial direct costs, and above and below market leasehold positions, to arrive
at the ROU asset. The adoption of the Lease Standard resulted in the recognition of operating ROU assets and operating
lease liabilities of $1,849.0 million and $1,860.9 million, respectively. In addition, we recorded a decrease to
accumulated deficit of $15.2 million, less taxes of $3.6 million, as of February 4, 2019, primarily due to the
reassessment of our build-to-suit leases under the Lease Standard. For build-to-suit leases that were determined to be
operating leases under the Lease Standard, we derecognized the capital lease asset and liability and recorded the
difference to accumulated deficit. There was not a material net impact on our Consolidated Statements of Operations
and Comprehensive Loss or Statements of Cash Flows.

We lease the vast majority of our stores, distribution and fulfillment centers, customer service centers, and
corporate offices generally under noncancelable operating and finance leases. For accounting purposes, the lease term
begins at the earlier of the date we become legally obligated for the rent payments or when we take possession of the
rental space. Generally, real estate leases require additional payments for property taxes, utilities, common area
maintenance, and insurance. Additionally, certain real estate leases contain provisions for future rent increases, rent
abatements, other incentives, or rental payments adjusted periodically for inflation. We also lease certain equipment
under operating and finance leases. Our leases may involve significant assumptions and judgments to identify the
underlying real estate space or equipment subject to the lease and the discount rate used to calculate the present value
of remaining fixed lease payments over the lease term. The Company’s leases generally do not provide an implicit
rate. Therefore, the Company uses its incremental borrowing rate, determined on a collateralized basis, in determining
the present value of future lease payments based on information available at the lease commencement date.

We record operating and finance lease ROU assets on the Consolidated Balance Sheets based on the sum of
the initial measurement of the lease liability adjusted for initial direct costs and lease incentives. We measure the
operating and finance lease obligations based on the present value of the future lease payments over the lease term at
the commencement date. The initial measurement of the ROU assets and lease obligations include fixed payments
included in our lease agreements. The Company generally does not include renewal options in its determination of the
lease term unless the renewals are deemed to be reasonably assured at lease commencement. We elected the practical
expedient to account for each separate lease component and non-lease component associated with our leases as a
single lease component for real estate leases. Rental payments are recognized as a reduction of the operating and
finance lease obligations on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

Operating lease expense is recorded on a straight-line basis over the lease term on the Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. We depreciate finance lease ROU assets over the term of the lease
and recognize interest expense on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. We have other
short-term leases with terms less than one-year. We elected not to apply the recognition requirements of the Lease
Standard to short-term leases, and as such, we recognize lease payments of short-term leases on a straight-line basis
over the lease term. Adjustments to lease payments due to inflation subsequent to lease commencement are recognized
in the period in which the obligation for those payments was incurred on the Consolidated Statements of Operations
and Comprehensive Loss.

Refer to Note 11 for further discussion regarding leases.

**_Equity Compensation_**

We recognize equity compensation based on the fair value of awards from the Company’s equity plans.
Equity awards are amortized using the graded amortization method over the vesting period, net of estimated
forfeitures. Equity compensation expense is classified within operating, general, and administrative expenses on the
Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss.

In June 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-07, Stock Compensation; Improvements to Nonemployee Share_Based Payment Accounting (Topic 718). The amendments in this ASU expand the scope of Topic 718 to include_
share-based payment awards to be issued to non-employees in exchange for acquiring goods and services. The ASU
aligned the accounting for awards issued to non-employees to be similar to employee awards. This standard was
effective for interim periods in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018 with early adoption permitted. We
adopted the provisions in this ASU on the first day of fiscal year 2019, which did not have a material impact on our
consolidated financial statements.

Refer to Note 7 for further discussion regarding equity compensation.

**_Noncontrolling Interests_**

Noncontrolling interests in our consolidated financial statements represents the percentage of ownership
interests in Chewy, Inc. held by parties outside of PetSmart, Inc. As of February 3, 2019, noncontrolling interests
represented a 20.0% ownership in Chewy, Inc. that was owned by a related-party entity controlled by our Sponsors.
During the year ended February 2, 2020, the noncontrolling interests percentage of Chewy, Inc. changed due to shares
of Class A common stock sold during the Chewy IPO and the Rule 144 Transactions as well as settlement of restricted
stock units under the Chewy Omnibus Incentive Plan (refer to Note 7). As of February 2, 2020, noncontrolling interests
represented a 36.1% ownership interest in Chewy, Inc. held by parties outside of PetSmart, Inc., including 19.6%
owned by a related-party entity controlled by our Sponsors. Since the Company retained a controlling interest in
Chewy, Inc., the financial results of Chewy, Inc. are included in our consolidated financial statements. Changes in the
ownership interest in Chewy, Inc. that do not cause the Company to lose its controlling interest of Chewy, Inc. are
accounted for as equity transactions which adjust noncontrolling interests and additional paid-in capital.

The Company presents noncontrolling interests as a component of stockholders’ equity on its Consolidated
Balance Sheets and reports the portion of loss for noncontrolling interests as net loss attributable to noncontrolling
interests on the Consolidated Statement of Operations and Comprehensive Loss. During the year ended February 2,
2020, the noncontrolling interests percentages before and after the completion of the Chewy IPO, the Rule 144
Transactions and the settlement of restricted stock units under the Chewy Omnibus Incentive Plan were used to
calculate the net loss attributable to noncontrolling interests on the Consolidated Statement of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss.

Refer to Note 6 for further discussion regarding noncontrolling interests.

**_Concentration of Credit Risk_**

Financial instruments that potentially subject the Company to significant concentrations of credit risk consist
principally of cash and cash equivalents and accounts receivable. The Company places its cash and cash equivalents
in highly rated financial institutions and amounts may exceed federally insured limits. Concentration of credit risk on
accounts receivable is limited due to the nature of the Company’s receivables.

**_Foreign Currency_**

The local currency of the country in which a subsidiary operates is designated as the functional currency for
all of our subsidiaries. We translate assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency into United States dollars at
the current rate of exchange at period-end and translate revenues and expenses at the average exchange rate for the
period. Foreign currency translation adjustments are included in other comprehensive (loss) income and are reported
in equity on the Consolidated Balance Sheets. Transaction gains and losses are included in net loss on the Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss and were not material for the years ended February 2, 2020,
February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018, respectively.

**Note 3 — Acquisitions and Goodwill**

**_Chewy Acquisition_**

As discussed in Note 1, we completed the Chewy Acquisition on May 31, 2017, and as contemplated by the
Chewy Merger Agreement, Chewy Merger Sub merged with and into Chewy, Inc., with Chewy, Inc. surviving as a
wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. Total consideration for the Merger was comprised of: (i) $3,000.0 million
aggregate purchase price for all outstanding shares of Chewy, Inc.’s capital stock (including options and restricted
shares), and (ii) fees and expenses related to the Chewy Acquisition to be assumed by PetSmart, Inc., subject to
adjustments as set forth in the Chewy Merger Agreement, including adjustments to reflect closing date debt and cash
of Chewy, Inc., the aggregate exercise price of outstanding options under Chewy, Inc.’s equity award plan, and fees
and expenses of Chewy, Inc.’s professional advisors related to the Chewy Acquisition in excess of $25.0 million, as
well as post-closing working capital adjustments (collectively, “Acquisition Consideration”). Of the total cash
consideration, $15.5 million was deposited into escrow as a hold-back subject to the determination of post-closing
working capital and other adjustments. During the year ended January 28, 2018, the $15.5 million was released from
escrow, with $11.2 million being paid to the former shareholders of Chewy, Inc. net of a working capital deficit
adjustment which was returned to PetSmart, Inc.

Pursuant to the Chewy Merger Agreement, each share of capital stock of Chewy, Inc. outstanding
immediately prior to the Acquisition Date was converted to a right to receive a proportionate share of the aggregate
Acquisition Consideration payable by PetSmart, Inc. All unvested options outstanding immediately prior to the
Acquisition Date under Chewy, Inc.’s equity award plan were deemed fully vested, and all outstanding and
unexercised options were converted into the right to receive a portion of the aggregate Acquisition Consideration, net
of the exercise price. All unvested restricted stock awards outstanding immediately prior to the Acquisition Date under
Chewy, Inc.’s equity award plan were deemed fully vested. Restricted stock awards were treated as shares of capital
stock of Chewy, Inc. and converted into the right to receive a proportionate share of the aggregate Acquisition
Consideration. A portion of the proceeds related to the accelerated outstanding options and restricted stock awards
was deposited into escrow subject to a six-month service period requirement. The total fair value of the consideration
deposited into escrow was $33.9 million, which was amortized over the six-month post-acquisition service period
within operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss during the year ended January 28, 2018.

The Chewy Acquisition was financed through (i) the issuance of $1,350.0 million in aggregate principal
amount of 5.875% senior first lien notes due 2025, (ii) the issuance of $650.0 million in aggregate principal amount
of 8.875% senior unsecured notes due 2025, (iii) $1,000.0 million of Sponsors’ cash equity contributions, and (iv) cash
on hand. Refer to Note 10 for further discussion on the 5.875% senior first lien notes due 2025 and the 8.875% senior
unsecured notes due 2025.

**Note 7 — Equity Compensation**

**_Chewy Omnibus Incentive Plan_**

In June 2019, Chewy, Inc.’s board of directors adopted and approved the 2019 Omnibus Incentive Plan
(the “Chewy 2019 Plan”). The Chewy 2019 Plan became effective on June 13, 2019 and provides for the issuance of
up to 31,864,865 shares of Class A common stock. No awards may be granted under the Chewy 2019 Plan after June
2029.

The Chewy 2019 Plan provides for the grant of stock options, including incentive stock options, non-qualified
stock options, restricted stock, dividend equivalents, stock payments, RSUs, performance shares, other incentive
awards, stock appreciation rights, and cash awards (collectively, the “Chewy Awards”). The Chewy Awards may be
granted to employees of Chewy, Inc., consultants, and directors, and the employees and consultants of Chewy, Inc.’s
affiliates and subsidiaries.

_Restricted Stock Units_

In connection with the consummation of the Chewy IPO, Chewy, Inc. granted RSUs under the Chewy 2019
Plan. Certain of the RSUs vest upon satisfaction of both a service-based vesting condition (the “Service Condition”)
and a performance-based vesting condition (the “Share Price Condition”) as described below.

The Service Condition will be satisfied with respect to 25% of an employee’s RSUs on the first anniversary
of the Chewy 2019 Plan’s registration date and then with respect to 12.5% of an employee’s RSUs at the end of each
six-month period thereafter, subject to the employee’s continued employment with Chewy, Inc. through the applicable
vesting date.

The Share Price Condition shall be satisfied with respect to a percentage of an employee’s RSUs, as and
when the price per share of Class A common stock specified (each, a “Share Price Hurdle”) is achieved, on a volume
adjusted weighted-average basis, on every trading day during a consecutive 45-trading day period completed prior to
the fifth anniversary of the Chewy 2019 Plan’s effective date subject to the employee’s continued employment with
Chewy, Inc. through the applicable vesting date.

**_Tracking Units_**

In connection with the Chewy IPO, on June 13, 2019 (“Grant Date”), certain participants of the Argos Profits
Interest Plan exchanged 50% of their Argos Profit Interest Units into a specified number of tracking units (the
“Tracking Units”). Once exchanged, the participant has no further rights with respect to the applicable Argos Profit
Interest Units which were canceled. The Tracking Units awarded consist of Initial Award Units and Service Award
Units. The Initial Award Units vested upon the closing of the Chewy IPO whereas the Service Award Units vest over
four years with 25% of the Service Award Units vesting each year beginning on the first anniversary of the Grant
Date. The Tracking Units are transferable under certain conditions and unvested Service Award Units are subject to
forfeiture upon termination of employment. Once vested, each Tracking Unit may be settled indirectly with one share
of Chewy, Inc. Class A common stock (“Chewy Shares”), or cash equal to the closing price of an equivalent number
of Chewy Shares on the last trading day prior to the settlement date, at the option of the general partner of the Argos
Partnership.

The cancellation of the Argos Profit Interest Units accompanied by the concurrent grant of Tracking Units
are accounted for as replacement awards and modification of terms. No incremental compensation cost was recognized
related to the modification because the fair value on the cancellation date of the awards granted was less than the fair
value of the awards canceled. The unrecognized compensation cost of $0.5 million will be recognized over the new
remaining service period. During the year ended February 2, 2020, 716,838 Tracking Units were granted with a fair
value of $22.00 per unit which represents the offering price of Class A common stock in the Chewy IPO.

During the year ended February 2, 2020, the general partner of the Argos Partnership elected to indirectly
settle the Initial Award Units in cash. The cash settlement was equal to the closing price of the Chewy Shares on
December 10, 2019, the last trading day prior to the settlement date, of $25.50 per share for the 143,368 Initial Award
Units that had vested upon the closing of the Chewy IPO. PetSmart distributed a cash dividend of $3.7 million to our
parent, Argos Holdings, to fund the settlement of the Initial Award Units. As of February 2, 2020, 536,287 Service
Award Units were unvested and 37,183 Tracking Units had been forfeited.

**_Long-Term Incentive Award Program_**

During the year ended February 2, 2020, the Company’s board of directors approved a new cash based longterm incentive program primarily for certain eligible PetSmart employees that joined the Company after the Chewy
IPO (“LTIP Awards”). In addition to a service condition, the LTIP Awards contain a performance condition that is
fulfilled upon a change of control or IPO of the Company as defined in the individual LTIP Award agreements. The
final value payable upon satisfaction of the performance condition is based on the enterprise value of the Company,
less the value of any direct or indirect ownership in Chewy, Inc., implied by the change of control or IPO and varies
between a minimum and maximum payout amount based on such enterprise value. The LTIP Awards vest 20% after
each year of service with full vesting occurring upon the first to occur of five years of service or a change of control,
subject to an employee’s continued employment through such change of control. The LTIP Awards are nontransferable and are subject to forfeiture under certain conditions. The LTIP Awards expire if neither a change of
control nor an IPO occurs prior to January 1, 2025. The LTIP Awards are to be settled in cash, unless the board of
directors of the Company, at its sole discretion, elects that they be settled in securities of the Company or its affiliates.

As of February 2, 2020, no equity compensation expense had been recognized for outstanding LTIP Awards
due to the uncertainty of the occurrence of a change of control or an IPO of the Company prior to January 1, 2025.
Upon the occurrence of a change of control or IPO before January 1, 2025, the value of the LTIP Awards will be
calculated, as set forth in the LTIP Award agreements, based on the enterprise value implied by the change of control
or IPO. In the event of an IPO, a cumulative effect adjustment to equity compensation will be recognized for the period
of service provided and the unrecognized equity compensation expense, if any, will be recognized over the remaining
service period. In the event of a change of control, a cumulative effect adjustment to equity compensation will be
recognized for the entire value of the LTIP Awards. As of February 2, 2020, outstanding LTIP Awards would settle
