**Note 10 — Financing Arrangements**

**_PetSmart ABL Facility_**

On March 11, 2015, in connection with the Argos Transaction, we entered into an asset-backed revolving
loan credit agreement that originally provided for a $750.0 million asset-backed revolving credit loan (the “PetSmart
ABL Facility”) with Citibank, N.A., as administrative agent, Barclays Bank PLC, as syndication agent, Natixis, New

F 31


-----

**PetSmart, Inc. and Subsidiaries**
**Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)**

York Branch, as co-manager, Wells Fargo Bank, National Association, as senior managing agent, and other lending
parties thereto.

The PetSmart ABL Facility originally provided for a five-year senior secured revolving credit facility of up
to $750.0 million, subject to a borrowing base, available in U.S. dollars and Canadian dollars, with a letter of credit
sub-limit of $300.0 million and an accordion feature allowing us to increase the revolving commitment by up to $350.0
million subject to specified conditions. On May 15, 2018, we entered into Amendment No. 1 to the PetSmart ABL
Facility (“ABL Amendment 1”). ABL Amendment 1 extended the maturity of $545.0 million of the PetSmart ABL
Facility and established an incremental commitment under the PetSmart ABL Facility’s accordion feature of $205.0
million (collectively, “Tranche 2”). The $750.0 million in total commitments of Tranche 2 matures on December 10,
2021. The remaining $205.0 million of the original PetSmart ABL Facility continued to mature on March 11, 2020
(“Tranche 1”). No other significant terms of the PetSmart ABL Facility were changed as a result of ABL Amendment
1. We incurred issuance costs of $3.5 million related to ABL Amendment 1.

On June 18, 2019, Tranche 1 of the PetSmart ABL Facility was terminated. Additionally, Chewy, Inc. and
its subsidiaries were released from their obligations under the PetSmart ABL Facility in accordance with its terms.
Accordingly, assets of Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries are no longer included in the borrowing base under the
PetSmart ABL Facility. The Company also entered into Amendment No. 2 to the PetSmart ABL Facility in order to,
among other things, permit Chewy, Inc. and its wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries to enter into its own asset-backed
credit facility.

Issuance costs are amortized over the life of the PetSmart ABL Facility using the straight-line method. The
unamortized portion of deferred issuance costs related to the PetSmart ABL Facility is presented in other noncurrent
assets on the Consolidated Balance Sheets. We wrote off $0.4 million of unamortized deferred issuance costs as a
result of the termination of Tranche 1, which is included in loss on extinguishment of debt on our Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss during the year ended February 2, 2020.

The PetSmart ABL Facility allows us to borrow various types of revolving loans that bear interest, at our
option, at LIBOR or a base rate, plus the Applicable Rate for U.S. borrowings, and the Canadian Prime Rate or the
Canadian BA Rate plus the Applicable Rate for Canadian borrowings. The Applicable Rate varies based on Average

**_Chewy ABL Facility_**

On June 18, 2019, Chewy, Inc. and its wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries entered into a new five-year
senior secured asset-backed credit facility (the “Chewy ABL Facility”). The Chewy ABL Facility provides for nonamortizing revolving loans in an aggregate principal amount of up to $300.0 million, subject to a borrowing base
comprised of, among other things, inventory and sales receivables (subject to certain reserves). The Chewy ABL
Facility provides Chewy, Inc. the right to request incremental commitments and add incremental asset-based revolving
loan facilities in an aggregate principal amount of up to $100.0 million, subject to customary conditions.

Borrowings under the Chewy ABL Facility bear interest at a rate per annum equal to, at Chewy, Inc.’s option,
either a base rate or a LIBOR rate, plus an applicable margin. The applicable margin is generally determined based on
the average excess liquidity during the immediately preceding fiscal quarter as a percentage of the maximum
borrowing amount under the Chewy ABL Facility and is between 0.25% and 0.75% for base rate loans and between
1.25% and 1.75% for LIBOR loans. Chewy, Inc. is required to pay a commitment fee of between 0.25% and 0.375%
with respect to the undrawn portion of the commitments, which is generally based on average daily usage of the
facility.

Chewy, Inc. incurred $1.5 million of issuance costs related to the Chewy ABL Facility which are amortized
over the life of the Chewy ABL Facility using the straight-line method. The unamortized portion of deferred issuance
costs related to the Chewy ABL Facility is presented in other noncurrent assets on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

We had no borrowings under the Chewy ABL Facility as of or during the year ended February 2, 2020.

**_Term Loan_**

On March 11, 2015, in connection with the Argos Transaction, we also entered into a seven-year credit
agreement (“Credit Agreement”) that provides for a senior secured term loan in the aggregate principal amount of
$4,300.0 million (the “Term Loan”) with Citibank, N.A., as administrative and collateral agent (the “Original Agent”),
Barclays Bank PLC, as syndication agent, Natixis, New York Branch, as co-manager, and other lending parties thereto.

The Term Loan requires quarterly principal payments until maturity in 2022 and allows for incremental
borrowings subject to a prescribed leverage ratio, pursuant to an accordion feature subject to certain restrictions.
Beginning in the year ended January 29, 2017, the Term Loan also requires additional annual principal payments from
our excess cash flow (as defined by the Credit Agreement) if we exceed a prescribed leverage ratio. No additional
principal payments were required as a result of our leverage ratio and excess cash flow level for the years ended
February 2, 2020, February 3, 2019, and January 28, 2018.

On April 2, 2019, we received unconditional consents from Term Loan lenders holding loans representing
$3,861.3 million aggregate principal amount, or 93.3% (“Consenting Term Loans”), of Term Loans outstanding on
such date to Amendment No. 3 (“Amendment 3”) to the Term Loan Credit Agreement. On April 17, 2019, we entered
into Amendment 3, which increased the interest spread on Consenting Term Loans to 3.25% for ABR Borrowings
and 4.25% for Eurocurrency Borrowings.

The interest rate spread on Consenting Term Loans is subject to adjustments as described below.
The weighted-average interest rate on all borrowings under the Term Loan was 5.6% as of February 2, 2020.

Amendment 3 also amended the Term Loan Credit Agreement to require the Company to make prepayments
of Consenting Term Loans, at par, in an aggregate amount of $250.0 million within twelve months of the effective
date of Amendment 3. On June 21, 2019, we used a portion of the after-income tax net proceeds received from the
Chewy IPO to make a principal prepayment of Consenting Term Loans, at par, in an aggregate amount of
$625.0 million, which satisfied the prepayment requirement of Amendment 3. The prepayment was first applied to
the quarterly principal payments for Consenting Term Loans, and then to the maturity payment for Consenting Term
Loans. In accordance with Amendment 3, on June 21, 2019, upon satisfaction of the $250.0 million prepayment
requirement, the interest rate spread for Consenting Term Loans was reduced to 3.0% and 4.0% for ABR Borrowings
and Eurocurrency Borrowings, respectively. The interest rate spread on Consenting Term Loans can be further reduced
based on the Company meeting certain first lien leverage ratios as prescribed by Amendment 3. The interest spread
and quarterly principal payments for non-consenting Term Loan lenders did not change as a result of Amendment 3.

As the Term Loan was a loan syndication immediately before and after Amendment 3 and lenders
participated in both credit facilities, we evaluated the accounting for unamortized debt discounts and issuance fees
resulting from the original Term Loan and previous amendments, as well as additional costs paid for Amendment 3,
on a lender by lender basis. We paid consent fees to Consenting Term Loan lenders for Amendment 3 of $19.3 million,
or 0.5%, of the outstanding Consenting Term Loans balance, and $22.1 million of third-party costs incurred by lenders
in connection with Amendment 3. As Amendment 3 was treated as a modification of debt, rather than an
extinguishment of debt, for all syndicates, we did not write-off any of the unamortized debt discounts and issuance
fees resulting from the original Term Loan and previous amendments, and we capitalized and treated as additional
debt discounts the consent fees paid to lenders as well as the amounts paid by us for third-party costs incurred by
lenders. All other third-party costs in connection with Amendment 3 were expensed as incurred within operating,
general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss for the
year ended February 2, 2020.

The principal prepayment made to Consenting Term Loans on June 21, 2019 was treated as a partial
extinguishment of debt. As such, we wrote off $12.9 million of debt discounts and deferred issuance costs associated
with the portion of the Consenting Term Loans that were extinguished which is included in loss on extinguishment of
debt on our Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss during the year ended February 2, 2020.

Additionally, on January 6, 2020 and January 9, 2020, we used a portion of the after-income tax net proceeds
received from the Rule 144 Transactions to make principal prepayments of Consenting Term Loans, at par, in an
aggregate amount of $117.0 million and $73.0 million, respectively, which were treated as a partial extinguishment
of debt. As such, we wrote off $3.2 million of debt discounts and deferred issuance costs associated with the portion
of the Consenting Term Loans that were extinguished which is included in loss on extinguishment of debt on our
Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss during the year ended February 2, 2020.

On February 10, 2020, after the end of the fiscal year, we used the remaining portion of the Additional Tender
Cap (defined below) that was not validly tendered by holders of our 5.875% senior first lien notes due 2025 to make
an additional principal prepayment of Consenting Term Loans, at par, in an aggregate amount of $58.6 million
(exclusive of accrued and unpaid interest). See additional discussion below under the heading “5.875% Senior First

**_Guarantees and Security_**

On June 18, 2019, Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries were released from their obligations under the PetSmart
ABL Facility. As such, the PetSmart ABL Facility is currently secured by a first-priority security interest in PetSmart,
Inc. and its subsidiaries’ inventory and credit card receivables (excluding the assets of Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries
and our unrestricted subsidiaries), less reserves (the “PetSmart ABL Collateral”), and a second-priority security
interest in all of the other assets of the Company and its current subsidiaries (excluding the assets of Chewy, Inc. and
its subsidiaries and our unrestricted subsidiaries). As a result of the 20% dividend of the outstanding stock of Chewy,
Inc. on June 1, 2018 as discussed in Note 1, which caused Chewy, Inc. to no longer be a wholly-owned subsidiary of
PetSmart, Inc. Chewy, Inc.’s guarantee of the obligations under the Term Loan were automatically released and
terminated. The release and termination of Chewy, Inc.’s guarantee of the obligations under the Term Loan also caused
its guarantee under the indentures governing the senior notes to be released and terminated.

The Term Loan and the 5.875% Notes are secured by a first-priority security interest in all assets of PetSmart,
Inc. and its current subsidiaries (excluding the assets of Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries, the assets of our unrestricted
subsidiaries, and the PetSmart ABL Collateral) and a second-priority security interest in the PetSmart ABL Collateral
(which, after June 18, 2019, excludes the assets of Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries). The 7.125% Notes and the 8.875%
Notes are general unsecured obligations effectively subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future secured
debt to the extent of the value of collateral securing such secured debt, are equal in right of payment with all existing
and future senior debt, and senior in right of payment to any future subordinate debt.

All obligations under the Chewy ABL Facility are guaranteed on a senior secured first-lien basis by Chewy,
Inc.’s wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions, and secured, subject to permitted liens and
other exceptions, by a perfected first-priority security interest in substantially all of Chewy, Inc.’s and its whollyowned domestic subsidiaries’ assets.

Following the completion of the dividend and contribution transactions involving common stock of Chewy,
Inc. on June 1, 2018 as described in Note 1 (collectively, the “Transactions”), the Original Agent under the Term Loan
did not comply with the Company’s request to evidence the release and termination of certain guarantees and security
interests as a result of the Transactions. On June 26, 2018, we commenced an action against the Original Agent in the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Action”). The Action requested a judgment,
among other things, directing the Original Agent to perform its obligations under the Term Loan, including the
execution and delivery of all documents necessary to evidence the release and termination of the Chewy, Inc.
guarantees and security interests, and declaring that no event of default occurred under the Term Loan as a result of
the Transactions. On August 16, 2018, we entered into an Agency Assignment Agreement in which the Original Agent
resigned as administrative and collateral agent under the Term Loan, and Wilmington Trust, National Association was
assigned as the successor administrative and collateral agent (“Successor Agent”). Simultaneously, the Successor
Agent was substituted for the Original Agent in the Action. On September 6, 2018, the Successor Agent filed its
answer to our complaint, together with a number of counterclaims against the Company and certain of its affiliates,
challenging the Transactions.

As previously discussed, on April 17, 2019, we entered into Amendment 3 to the Term Loan Credit
Agreement. Amendment 3 provided for, among other things, a direction from Consenting Term Loan lenders to the
Successor Agent to settle the Action. In exchange, Amendment 3 amended the Term Loan Credit Agreement to tighten
certain restrictive covenants, and improve certain economic terms for Consenting Term Loans, including an increase
in the applicable interest rate spread for Consenting Term Loans, requiring that the Company pay a consent fee to
Consenting Term Loan lenders, and requiring that the Company prepay Consenting Term Loans within twelve months
of the effective date of Amendment 3, at par, in an aggregate amount of at least $250.0 million. As discussed above,
the Consenting Term Loans prepayment requirement was satisfied with our principal prepayment of $625.0 million
of Consenting Term Loans made on June 21, 2019.

Also on April 17, 2019, we entered into a Settlement Agreement and Mutual Release (the “Settlement
Agreement”), which caused the provisions of Amendment 3 to become effective. Upon the effective date of the
Settlement Agreement and Amendment 3, (1) the Successor Agent was directed to (a) withdraw and dismiss, with
prejudice, any causes of action alleged in its answer and counterclaim in the Action and (b) evidence the release and

**_Representations, Warranties, Covenants, and Restricted/Unrestricted Subsidiaries_**

The PetSmart ABL Facility, the Chewy ABL Facility, the Term Loan, the 7.125% Notes, the 5.875% Notes,
and the 8.875% Notes (collectively referred to as “Credit Facilities”) contain customary representations, warranties,
affirmative and negative covenants, and events of default and cross-default. The negative covenants include
restrictions on our ability to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay dividends, create liens, make
investments, give guarantees, sell assets, merge, or consolidate. Under the PetSmart ABL Facility and the Term Loan,
we are subject to financial covenants, including certain leverage ratios, interest coverage ratios, and fixed charges
coverage ratios. These financial covenant ratios are only applicable in the event of future material events of the
Company. In addition, the Chewy ABL Facility requires Chewy, Inc. to maintain a minimum fixed charge coverage
ratio depending on the excess availability under the facility. We were in compliance with all covenants as of February
2, 2020.

Chewy, Inc. remains a restricted subsidiary under the agreements governing the PetSmart ABL Facility and
the Term Loan as well as the indentures governing PetSmart, Inc.’s senior notes. Two of our wholly-owned
subsidiaries, one of which holds 100% ownership of the other subsidiary, the sole asset of which is its ownership of
16.2% of the outstanding common stock of Chewy, Inc., are unrestricted subsidiaries under the credit agreements and
the indentures governing PetSmart, Inc.’s senior notes. The unrestricted subsidiary accounts for its ownership of
16.2% of the outstanding common stock of Chewy, Inc. using the equity method of accounting.

**Note 12 — Commitments and Contingencies**

**_Advertising Purchase Commitments_**

As of February 2, 2020, we had obligations to purchase $30.0 million of advertising in fiscal year 2020 and
$5.7 million in fiscal year 2021.

**_Product and Services Purchase Commitments_**

As of February 2, 2020, we had various commitments to purchase merchandise and services from certain
vendors, including $28.9 million in fiscal year 2020, $20.3 million in fiscal year 2021, $9.2 million in fiscal year 2022,
$6.0 million in fiscal year 2023, and $1.2 million in fiscal year 2024.

**_Sales Tax Liability_**

The Company collects and remits sales tax in jurisdictions in which it has a physical presence or it believes
nexus exists. The Company continually evaluates whether it may have nexus in new jurisdictions with respect to sales
tax. The Company has recorded an estimated liability for potential exposure in states where there is uncertainty about
the point in time at which the Company established a sufficient in-state business presence to create nexus and the
Company did not collect sales tax. Changes in management’s assumptions may occur in the future as the Company
obtains new information, which can result in adjustments to the recorded liability. Increases and decreases to the
liability for uncollected sales tax are included in operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss.

**_Litigation and Settlements_**

In the normal course of our business, we are subject to actual and threatened legal actions and proceedings,
including those related to alleged violations of labor and employment laws, intellectual property rights, consumer
protection laws, premises liability, contract disputes, and other laws and regulations.

While we currently do not expect that the ultimate outcome of the proceedings and claims pending or
threatened against us will have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial statements, the outcome of any
litigation is inherently uncertain, and if decided adversely to us, or if we determine that settlement of particular
litigation is appropriate, we may be subject to liability that could have a material adverse effect on our consolidated
financial position, results of operations, or cash flows for a particular period.

**Note 13 — Subsequent Events**

The Company has evaluated subsequent events from the balance sheet date through April 6, 2020, the date
at which the consolidated financial statements were available to be issued (“Filing Date”), and determined the
following items required additional disclosure.

As discussed in Note 10, on February 10, 2020, we repurchased $3.4 million of our 5.875% Notes and made
an additional principal prepayment of $58.6 million toward Consenting Term Loans.

On March 11, 2020, the recent outbreak of the coronavirus, or COVID-19, was declared a global pandemic
by the World Health Organization, which has led to volatile impacts on the U.S. and global economies. While the petrelated industry continues to be viewed as essential, the pandemic has created uncertainty regarding potential impacts
to our supply chain, operations, and customer demand. The pandemic has impacted and could further impact our
operations and the operations of our suppliers and vendors as a result of quarantines, facility closures, and travel and
logistics restrictions.

**PetSmart, Inc. and Subsidiaries**

As a result of the uncertainty of this pandemic, the Company took precautionary action to enhance our
financial flexibility. As discussed in Note 10, on March 18, 2020, we borrowed $300.0 million under the PetSmart
ABL Facility.

Effective March 21, 2020, we elected to temporarily suspend all grooming services and temporarily restricted
most training services for a period of approximately two weeks in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. On April 6,
2020, following an evaluation of our grooming business and several changes to our processes, we reopened our
grooming operations in the majority of our markets. We have continued to restrict pet training services to one-on-one
programs. The majority of our PetsHotels remained open as these provide essential services for many of our customers.
As of the Filing Date, the vast majority of our stores remained open in the U.S., Canada and Puerto Rico. However,
we reduced hours of operation for all of our stores.

On March 27, 2020, the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) was enacted.
This law has far reaching implications to businesses including PetSmart. The Company has not yet estimated the law’s
impact to the Company’s financial position, results of operations, and cash flows in fiscal year 2020.

**Note 1 — The Company and Basis of Presentation**

**_Business_**

PetSmart, Inc., including its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries that we control (herein
collectively referred to as the “Company,” “we,” “our,” or “us,” unless the context requires otherwise), is a leading
specialty provider of products, services and solutions for the lifetime needs of pets. We offer a broad assortment of
products for all the life stages of pets, as well as various services, including professional grooming and boarding for
cats and dogs, and training and day camp for dogs. We also offer pet products through our e-commerce websites
(PetSmart.com, Chewy.com and OnlyNaturalPet.com) and maintain the content site PetMD.com. As of November 1,
2020, we operated 1,650 stores and had full-service veterinary hospitals, owned and operated by third-parties, in 809
of our stores.

On March 11, 2015 (“Transaction Date”), PetSmart, Inc. became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Argos
Holdings Inc. (“Argos Holdings”). Argos Holdings is indirectly controlled by Argos Intermediate Holdco I Inc.
(“Intermediate Holdco I”), which is directly controlled by a consortium including funds advised by BC Partners, Inc.,
La Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, affiliates of GIC Special Investments Pte Ltd, affiliates of StepStone
Group LP, and Longview Asset Management, LLC (collectively, the “Sponsors”). Argos Holdings has no operating
activity, and its sole asset is its 100% ownership of PetSmart, Inc.

The Company pays an aggregate of $4.0 million in annual management fees to select Sponsors, which are
related parties, under a service agreement entered into with the Sponsors on the Transaction Date, which are recorded
in operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations and
Comprehensive Loss. The Company is subject to a termination fee under the services agreement equal to the net
present value of the annual management fees that would have been payable with respect to the period from the
termination date through the twelfth (12th) anniversary of the Transaction Date, or, if terminated following the twelfth
(12th) anniversary of the Transaction Date, through the first anniversary of the Transaction Date occurring after the
termination date.

On May 31, 2017, the Company closed on the acquisition of Chewy, Inc. (“Chewy Acquisition”). On June
1, 2018, the board of directors of PetSmart, Inc. declared and made a dividend in the form of 20.0% of the outstanding
common stock of Chewy, Inc. to its parent company, Argos Holdings. Also, on June 1, 2018, the board of directors
of Argos Holdings declared and made a dividend of this Chewy, Inc. common stock to its parent company. Separately,
on June 1, 2018, PetSmart, Inc. invested 16.5% of the outstanding common stock of Chewy, Inc. in the form of a
capital contribution to a wholly-owned unrestricted subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. These transactions were each
approved by special committees of disinterested directors of PetSmart and Argos Holdings, as applicable, each of
which was advised by its own legal and financial advisors.

On June 18, 2019, Chewy, Inc. completed an initial public offering (“IPO”) of shares of Class A common
stock. A wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. sold 47,875,000 shares at $22.00 per share, including 6,975,000
shares sold upon exercise by the underwriters of the IPO of their option to purchase additional shares (“Shares Sold”).
The Company received net proceeds of $1,000.6 million from the sale of these shares after deducting underwriting
discounts and commissions of $52.7 million. In addition, Chewy, Inc. sold 5,600,000 shares (“New Shares”) in the
IPO at $22.00 per share. Chewy, Inc. received net proceeds of $117.0 million from the New Shares after deducting
underwriting discounts and commissions of $6.2 million.

Prior to completion of the IPO, Chewy, Inc.’s outstanding common stock was reclassified into Class B
common stock. The rights of the holders of Chewy, Inc. Class A common stock and Class B common stock are
identical, except with respect to voting, conversion and transfer rights. Each share of Class A common stock is entitled
to one vote. Each share of Class B common stock is entitled to ten votes and is convertible at any time (and upon the
occurrence of certain events) into one share of Class A common stock. We refer to the IPO of Chewy, Inc. which was
completed on June 18, 2019 as the “Chewy IPO.”

On December 20, 2019, a wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. converted 6,352,546 shares of Chewy,
Inc. Class B common stock into Class A common stock and sold these shares at $27.95 per share pursuant to Rule

On September 21, 2020, Chewy, Inc. issued and sold 5,100,000 shares of Class A common stock in an

As of November 1, 2020, as a result of the Chewy IPO, the Rule 144 Transactions, the vesting of restricted

of Chewy, Inc. Class B common stock, which represented 62.2% of the total outstanding shares of Chewy, Inc.
common stock. This included 4.3% in Class A common stock of Chewy, Inc. owned by Buddy Chester Sub LLC, a
wholly-owned, unrestricted subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc., 11.5% in Class B common stock of Chewy, Inc. owned by
Buddy Chester Corp., a wholly-owned, unrestricted subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc., and 46.4% in Class B common stock
of Chewy, Inc. owned by PetSmart Buddy Holdings Corp., a wholly-owned, restricted subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc.
Our Sponsors own an additional 19.0% in Class B common stock of Chewy, Inc., which is held by an entity outside
of the Company, and the remaining 18.8% is Class A common stock owned primarily by third-party investors. As of
November 1, 2020, the shares owned by wholly-owned subsidiaries of the Company represented 73.6% of the
combined voting power of Chewy, Inc. common stock, and therefore, we continue to consolidate the financial results
of Chewy, Inc.

Due to the seasonal nature of our business and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the results of

are 52-weeks. Unless otherwise specified, all references to years in these condensed consolidated financial statements
are to fiscal years.

**Note 4 — Equity Compensation**

**_Chewy Omnibus Incentive Plan_**

In June 2019, Chewy, Inc.’s board of directors adopted and approved the 2019 Omnibus Incentive Plan (the
“Chewy 2019 Plan”). The Chewy 2019 Plan became effective on June 13, 2019 and provides for the issuance of up to
31,864,865 shares of Class A common stock. No awards may be granted under the Chewy 2019 Plan after June 2029.

The Chewy 2019 Plan provides for the grant of stock options, including incentive stock options, non-qualified
stock options, restricted stock, dividend equivalents, stock payments, restricted stock units, performance shares, other
incentive awards, stock appreciation rights, and cash awards (collectively, the “Chewy Awards”). The Chewy Awards
may be granted to employees of Chewy, Inc., consultants, and directors, and the employees and consultants of Chewy,
Inc.’s affiliates and subsidiaries.

_Service and Performance-Based Awards_

Beginning in June 2019, Chewy, Inc. granted restricted stock units that vest upon satisfaction of both a
service-based vesting condition and a performance-based vesting condition (“PRSUs”) as described below.

The service-based vesting condition was or will be satisfied with respect to 25% of an employee’s PRSUs on
either (i) the first anniversary of the registration date (as defined in the Chewy 2019 Plan) or (ii) the first anniversary
of the vesting commencement date, and will then be satisfied with respect to 12.5% of an employee’s PRSUs at the
end of each six month period thereafter, subject to the employee’s continued employment with Chewy, Inc. through
the applicable vesting date.

The performance-based vesting condition shall be satisfied with respect to a percentage of an employee’s
PRSUs, as and when the price per share of Class A common stock specified is achieved, on a volume adjusted
weighted-average basis, on every trading day during a consecutive 45-trading day period completed prior to the fifth
anniversary of the Chewy 2019 Plan’s effective date subject to the employee’s continued employment with Chewy,
Inc. through the applicable vesting date. As of June 13, 2020, the performance-based vesting condition was fully
satisfied.

_Service-Based Awards_

During the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020, Chewy, Inc. granted restricted stock units with a
service-based vesting condition (“RSUs”). The service-based vesting condition for employees will be satisfied with
respect to 25% of an employee’s RSUs on the one-year anniversary of the vesting commencement date and 12.5% of

**_Profits Interest Plans_**

_Argos Profits Interest Plan_

Argos Holdings L.P. (the “Argos Partnership”), an indirect parent of Argos Holdings, granted equity interests
in the Argos Partnership to certain employees in the form of Special Class A-2 Units, which fully vested upon grant,
as well as profits interest units under the Argos Profits Interest Plan (“Argos Profits Interest Units”). These grants are
subject to the terms of the limited partnership agreement of the Argos Partnership. The grants are non-transferable and
are subject to forfeiture under certain conditions. In addition, the Argos Partnership has the right to repurchase all or
a portion of the vested equity interests after termination of a grantee’s employment.

Argos Profits Interest Units are generally subject to time-based vesting. These awards typically vest 20%
after one year of service and 1.667% per month thereafter with full vesting occurring upon five years of service. The
Argos Profits Interest Plan expires in 2025. During the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020, the Argos
Partnership granted 49,251 Argos Profits Interest Units. There were no Argos Profits Interest Units granted during the
thirteen weeks ended November 1, 2020. We do not expect the Argos Partnership to grant additional Argos Profits
Interest Units in the future.

There were no Argos Profits Interest Units granted during the thirteen and thirty-nine weeks ended
November 3, 2019. During the thirty-nine weeks ended November 3, 2019, 84,292 Argos Profits Interest Units were
canceled and exchanged for tracking units as discussed below.

_Citrus Profits Interest Plan_

Subsequent to the Chewy Acquisition, Citrus Intermediate Holdings L.P. (the “Citrus Partnership”), an
affiliate of the Argos Partnership, granted profits interest units to certain employees of Chewy under the Citrus Profits
Interest Plan (“Citrus Profits Interest Units”). These grants were subject to the terms of the limited partnership
agreement of the Citrus Partnership. The grants were non-transferable and were subject to forfeiture and repurchase
under certain conditions.

Citrus Profits Interest Units were generally subject to time-based vesting with 20% vested after one year of
service and 1.667% per month thereafter with full vesting occurring upon five years of service. During the thirty-nine
weeks ended November 3, 2019, prior to the Chewy IPO, the Citrus Partnership granted 228,435 Citrus Profits Interest
Units. There were no Citrus Profits Interest Units granted during the thirteen weeks ended November 3, 2019. The
Citrus Partnership ceased issuing Citrus Profits Interest Units at the time of the Chewy IPO and in connection with
the adoption of the Chewy 2019 Plan.

**_Tracking Units_**

In connection with the Chewy IPO, on June 13, 2019 (“Grant Date”), certain participants of the Argos Profits
Interest Plan exchanged 50% of their Argos Profits Interest Units into a specified number of tracking units (the
“Tracking Units”). Once exchanged, the participant has no further rights with respect to the applicable Argos Profits
Interest Units which were canceled. The Tracking Units awarded consist of Initial Award Units and Service Award
Units. The Initial Award Units vested upon the closing of the Chewy IPO whereas the Service Award Units vest over
four years with 25% of the Service Award Units vesting each year beginning on the first anniversary of the Grant
Date. The Tracking Units are transferable under certain conditions and unvested Service Award Units are subject to
forfeiture upon termination of employment. Once vested, each Tracking Unit may be settled indirectly with one share
of Chewy, Inc. Class A common stock (“Chewy Shares”), or cash equal to the closing price of an equivalent number
of Chewy Shares on the last trading day prior to the settlement date, at the option of the general partner of the Argos
Partnership (“Argos General Partner”).

The cancellation of the Argos Profits Interest Units accompanied by the concurrent grant of Tracking Units
represented replacement awards and modification of terms and were initially accounted for as equity awards. No
incremental compensation cost was recognized related to the modification because the fair value on the cancellation
date of the awards granted was less than the fair value of the awards canceled. During the thirty-nine weeks ended

**_Long-Term Incentive Award Program_**

In December 2019, the Company’s board of directors approved a new cash based long-term incentive
program primarily for certain eligible PetSmart employees that joined the Company after the Chewy IPO (“LTIP
Awards”). In addition to a service condition, the LTIP Awards contain a performance condition that is fulfilled upon
a change of control or IPO of the Company as defined in the individual LTIP Award agreements. The final value
payable upon satisfaction of the performance condition is based on the enterprise value of the Company, less the value
of any direct or indirect ownership in Chewy, Inc., implied by the change of control or IPO and varies between a
minimum and maximum payout amount based on such enterprise value. The LTIP Awards vest 20% after each year
of service with full vesting occurring upon the first to occur of five years of service or a change of control, subject to
an employee’s continued employment through such change of control. The LTIP Awards are non-transferable and are
subject to forfeiture under certain conditions. The LTIP Awards expire if neither a change of control nor an IPO occurs
prior to January 1, 2025. The LTIP Awards are to be settled in cash, unless the board of directors of the Company, at
its sole discretion, elects that they be settled in securities of the Company or its affiliates.

There was no equity compensation expense recognized for outstanding LTIP Awards as of or during the
thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020 due to the uncertainty of the occurrence of a change of control or an IPO
of the Company prior to January 1, 2025. Upon the occurrence of a change of control or IPO before January 1, 2025,
the value of the LTIP Awards will be calculated, as set forth in the LTIP Award agreements, based on the enterprise
value implied by the change of control or IPO. In the event of an IPO, a cumulative effect adjustment to equity
compensation will be recognized for the period of service provided and the unrecognized equity compensation
expense, if any, will be recognized over the remaining service period. In the event of a change of control, a cumulative
effect adjustment to equity compensation will be recognized for the entire value of the LTIP Awards. As of
November 1, 2020, outstanding LTIP Awards would settle between a total of $6.3 million and $31.7 million
depending on the enterprise value implied by a change of control or IPO and assuming all service conditions had been
met in the case of an IPO.

**Note 5 — Income Taxes**

At the end of each interim period, we estimate the annual effective tax rate and apply that rate to our quarterly
earnings. The tax expense or benefit related to significant, unusual, or extraordinary items is recognized in the interim
period in which those items occur. In addition, the effect of changes in enacted tax laws, rates, or tax status is
recognized in the interim period in which the change occurs. The accounting estimates used to compute the provision
for income taxes may change as new events occur, additional information is obtained, or the tax environment changes.

On March 27, 2020, the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (“CARES Act”) was enacted.
The CARES Act includes numerous tax provisions and other stimulus measures, including temporary changes
regarding the prior and future utilization of net operating losses, temporary changes to the prior and future limitations
on interest deductions, temporary suspension of certain payment requirements for the employer’s portion of Social
Security taxes, technical corrections from prior tax legislation for tax depreciation of certain qualified improvement
property and net operating losses, and the creation of certain refundable employee retention credits. The Company
continues to assess the impact of these new tax provisions but has preliminarily recorded income tax benefits of $7.4
million and a deferral of the employer’s portion of Social Security taxes of $72.4 million, which can be paid back in
two equal installments on December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2022, if not paid back earlier.

In connection with the Forward Contract (defined and discussed in Note 7), we determined during the thirteen
weeks ended November 1, 2020 that Chewy, Inc. will no longer be included in the consolidated federal income tax
return of the Company for fiscal year 2020.

**Note 6— Financing Arrangements**

**_PetSmart ABL Facility_**

On March 11, 2015, we entered into an asset-backed revolving loan credit agreement (the “PetSmart ABL
Facility”) with Citibank, N.A., as administrative agent, Barclays Bank PLC, as syndication agent, Natixis, New York
Branch, as co-manager, Wells Fargo Bank, National Association, as senior managing agent, and other lending parties
thereto.

The PetSmart ABL Facility originally provided for a five-year senior secured revolving credit facility of up
to $750.0 million, subject to a borrowing base, available in U.S. dollars and Canadian dollars, with a letter of credit
sub-limit of $300.0 million and an accordion feature allowing us to increase the revolving commitment by up to $350.0
million subject to specified conditions. On May 15, 2018, we entered into Amendment No. 1 to the PetSmart ABL
Facility (“ABL Amendment 1”). ABL Amendment 1 extended the maturity of $545.0 million of the PetSmart ABL
Facility and established an incremental commitment under the PetSmart ABL Facility’s accordion feature of $205.0
million (collectively, “Tranche 2”). The $750.0 million in total commitments of Tranche 2 matures on December 10,
2021. The remaining $205.0 million of the original PetSmart ABL Facility matured on March 11, 2020 (“Tranche 1”).
No other significant terms of the PetSmart ABL Facility were changed as a result of ABL Amendment 1.

**_Chewy ABL Facility_**

On June 18, 2019 Chewy, Inc. and its wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries entered into a new five-year senior
secured asset-backed credit facility (the “Chewy ABL Facility”). The Chewy ABL Facility provides for nonamortizing revolving loans in an aggregate principal amount of up to $300.0 million, subject to a borrowing base
comprised of, among other things, inventory and sales receivables (subject to certain reserves). The Chewy ABL
Facility provides Chewy, Inc. the right to request incremental commitments and add incremental asset-based revolving
loan facilities in an aggregate principal amount of up to $100.0 million, subject to customary conditions.

Borrowings under the Chewy ABL Facility bear interest at a rate per annum equal to, at Chewy, Inc.’s option,
either a base rate or a LIBOR rate, plus an applicable margin. The applicable margin is generally determined based on
the average excess liquidity during the immediately preceding fiscal quarter as a percentage of the maximum
borrowing amount under the Chewy ABL Facility and is between 0.25% and 0.75% for base rate loans and between
1.25% and 1.75% for LIBOR loans. Chewy, Inc. is required to a pay commitment fee of between 0.25% and 0.375%
with respect to the undrawn portion of the commitments, which is generally based on average daily usage of the
facility.

Chewy, Inc. incurred $1.5 million of issuance costs related to the Chewy ABL Facility which are amortized
over the life of the Chewy ABL Facility using the straight-line method. The unamortized portion of deferred issuance
costs related to the Chewy ABL Facility is presented in other noncurrent assets on the Condensed Consolidated
Balance Sheets.

We had no borrowings under the Chewy ABL Facility as of or during the thirty-nine weeks ended November
1, 2020 or November 3, 2019.

Notes were entitled to a pro rata share of the Tender Cap at the Total Consideration, plus accrued and unpaid interest.
The Tender Cap of $205.0 million, plus accrued and unpaid interest, was paid to holders of the 5.875% Notes on July
19, 2019 and the repurchased 5.875% Notes were canceled. As a result, we wrote off $4.0 million of deferred issuance
fees associated with the portion of the 5.875% Notes being extinguished which is included in loss on extinguishment
of debt on our Condensed Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss during the thirty-nine
weeks ended November 3, 2019.

On January 9, 2020, we commenced an additional cash tender offer (the “Additional Offer”) to purchase an
aggregate principal amount (exclusive of accrued and unpaid interest) of up to $62.0 million (“Additional Tender
Cap”) of our outstanding 5.875% Notes. The Additional Offer, which expired on February 6, 2020, provided for the
repurchase of the 5.875% Notes, at par, using a portion of the estimated after-income tax net proceeds received from
the Rule 144 Transactions. The principal amount of the 5.875% Notes that was validly tendered as of February 6,
2020 was $3.4 million. On February 10, 2020, we paid holders of the 5.875% Notes $3.4 million, plus accrued and
unpaid interest, and the repurchased 5.875% Notes were canceled and treated as a partial extinguishment of debt. As
such, we wrote off $0.1 million of discount and deferred issuance costs associated with the portion of the 5.875%
Notes that were extinguished which was included in loss on extinguishment of debt on our Condensed Consolidated
Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss during the thirty-nine weeks ended November 1, 2020. The
remaining $58.6 million not validly tendered was used to make a prepayment of the Consenting Term Loans, at par,
as discussed above under the heading “Term Loan.”

We amortize discount and deferred issuance costs over the contractual term of the 5.875% Notes using the
effective interest method. The 5.875% Notes are presented on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets, net of the
unamortized discount and deferred issuance costs, in long-term debt, less current portion.

Inc. and its subsidiaries’ inventory and credit card receivables (excluding the assets of Chewy, Inc. and its subsidiaries
and our unrestricted subsidiaries), less reserves (the “PetSmart ABL Collateral”), and a second-priority security
interest in all of the other assets of the Company and its current subsidiaries (excluding the assets of Chewy, Inc. and

The Term Loan and the 5.875% Notes are secured by a first-priority security interest in all assets of PetSmart,

Notes are general unsecured obligations effectively subordinated in right of payment to any existing and future secured

and future senior debt, and senior in right of payment to any future subordinate debt.

All obligations under the Chewy ABL Facility are guaranteed on a senior secured first-lien basis by Chewy,
Inc.’s wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions, and secured, subject to permitted liens and
other exceptions, by a perfected first-priority security interest in substantially all of Chewy, Inc.’s and its whollyowned domestic subsidiaries’ assets.

Following the completion of the dividend and contribution transactions involving common shares of Chewy,
Inc. on June 1, 2018 as described in Note 1 (collectively, the “Transactions”), the Original Agent under the Term Loan
did not comply with the Company’s request to evidence the release and termination of certain guarantees and security
interests as a result of the Transactions. On June 26, 2018, we commenced an action against the Original Agent in the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (the “Action”). The Action requested a judgment,
among other things, directing the Original Agent to perform its obligations under the Term Loan, including the
execution and delivery of all documents necessary to evidence the release and termination of the Chewy, Inc.
guarantees and security interests, and declaring that no event of default occurred under the Term Loan as a result of
the Transactions. On August 16, 2018, we entered into an Agency Assignment Agreement in which the Original Agent
resigned as administrative and collateral agent under the Term Loan, and Wilmington Trust, National Association was
assigned as the successor administrative and collateral agent (“Successor Agent”). Simultaneously, the Successor
Agent was substituted for the Original Agent in the Action. On September 6, 2018, the Successor Agent filed its
answer to our complaint, together with a number of counterclaims against the Company and certain of its affiliates,
challenging the Transactions.

As previously discussed, on April 17, 2019, we entered into Amendment 3 to the Term Loan Credit
Agreement. Amendment 3 provided for, among other things, a direction from Consenting Term Loan lenders to the
Successor Agent to settle the Action. In exchange, Amendment 3 amended the Term Loan Credit Agreement to tighten
certain restrictive covenants, and improve certain economic terms for Consenting Term Loans, including an increase
in the applicable interest rate spread for Consenting Term Loans, requiring that the Company pay a consent fee to
Consenting Term Loan lenders, and requiring that the Company prepay Consenting Term Loans within twelve months
of the effective date of Amendment 3, at par, in an aggregate amount of at least $250.0 million. As discussed above,
the Consenting Term Loans prepayment requirement was satisfied with our principal prepayment of $625.0 million
of Consenting Term Loans made on June 21, 2019.

Also on April 17, 2019, we entered into a Settlement Agreement and Mutual Release (the “Settlement
Agreement”), which caused the provisions of Amendment 3 to become effective. Upon the effective date of the
Settlement Agreement and Amendment 3, (1) the Successor Agent was directed to (a) withdraw and dismiss, with
prejudice, any causes of action alleged in its answer and counterclaim in the Action and (b) evidence the release and
termination of the applicable guarantees and security interests as a result of the Transactions and (2) each consenting
lender (a) acknowledged and agreed that the Transactions were permitted under the Term Loan Credit Agreement, (b)
ratified the Transactions, and (c) provided customary releases with respect to the Transactions.

On April 17, 2019, a Stipulation of Voluntary Dismissal was filed dismissing the Action as well as the
counterclaims asserted by the Successor Agent against the Company and certain of its affiliates.

**_Representations, Warranties, Covenants, and Restricted/Unrestricted Subsidiaries_**

The PetSmart ABL Facility, the Chewy ABL Facility, the Term Loan, the 7.125% Notes, the 5.875% Notes,
and the 8.875% Notes (collectively referred to as “Credit Facilities”) contain customary representations, warranties,
affirmative and negative covenants, and events of default and cross-default. The negative covenants include
restrictions on our ability to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay dividends, create liens, make
investments, give guarantees, sell assets, merge, or consolidate. Under the PetSmart ABL Facility and the Term Loan,
we are subject to financial covenants, including certain leverage ratios, interest coverage ratios, and fixed charges
coverage ratios. These financial covenant ratios are only applicable in the event of future material events of the
Company. In addition, the Chewy ABL Facility requires Chewy, Inc. to maintain a minimum fixed charge coverage
ratio depending on the excess availability under the facility. We were in compliance with all covenants as of
November 1, 2020.

Chewy, Inc. remains a restricted subsidiary under the agreements governing the PetSmart ABL Facility and
the Term Loan as well as the indentures governing PetSmart, Inc.’s senior notes. Two of our wholly-owned
subsidiaries, Buddy Chester Corp. and Buddy Chester Sub LLC, are unrestricted subsidiaries under the credit
agreements and the indentures governing PetSmart, Inc.’s senior notes. Buddy Chester Corp.’s assets are comprised
of its ownership of 47,260,902 shares of Class B common stock of Chewy, Inc. (11.5% of the total outstanding shares
of Chewy, Inc. common stock) and its 100% ownership in Buddy Chester Sub LLC. Buddy Chester Sub LLC’s
primary asset is its ownership of 17,584,098 shares of Class A common stock of Chewy, Inc. (4.3% of the total
outstanding shares of Chewy, Inc. common stock), which are pledged as collateral to secure its obligations under the
Forward Contract as discussed in Note 7.

**Note 7 — Forward Purchase Agreement**

On May 11, 2020, the 2020 Mandatory Exchangeable Trust, a third-party Delaware statutory trust (the
“Trust”), closed the offering of 690,000 of its 2020 Mandatory Exchangeable Trust Securities (the “Trust Securities”)
exchangeable into Class A common stock of Chewy, Inc. in a private placement to investors for an aggregate purchase
price of $690.0 million before discounts.

On the same day, the Trust entered into a forward purchase agreement (the “Forward Contract”) with Buddy
Chester Sub LLC (the “Seller”), a wholly-owned subsidiary of PetSmart, Inc. The Forward Contract obligates the
Seller to deliver up to 17,584,098 shares of Class A common stock of Chewy, Inc. (or, at the Seller’s election, an
equivalent amount of cash based on the market price of the Class A common stock at that time) to the Trust on May
16, 2023 (the “Exchange Date”). Under certain circumstances, the Trust Securities may be exchanged prior to the
Exchange Date. On May 11, 2020, the Seller received $535.2 million from the Trust (“Net Proceeds”), which
represented proceeds from the sale of the Trust Securities, excluding an initial purchasers’ discount and amounts
withheld by the Trust to pay for expenses and to purchase U.S. Treasury securities, which will fund quarterly
distributions on the Trust Securities.

On May 13, 2020, the Company used the Net Proceeds, net of expenses incurred by the Seller in connection
with the Forward Contract, to make a principal prepayment of Consenting Term Loans, at par, in an aggregate amount
of $534.0 million.

In connection with the offering of the Trust Securities, on May 8, 2020, the Seller converted 17,584,098
shares of Class B common stock of Chewy, Inc. into Class A common stock of Chewy, Inc. On May 11, 2020, these
shares of Class A common stock were pledged by the Seller to secure its obligations under the Forward Contract. The
number of shares of Class A common stock to ultimately be delivered to the Trust under the Forward Contract will be
equal to the number of Trust Securities outstanding multiplied by a conversion rate, which will be between 21.2368
and 25.4842 and will be determined by reference to the volume-weighted average trading price of the Class A common
stock of Chewy, Inc. during the 20-trading day observation period beginning on, and including, the 24th scheduled
trading day immediately preceding the Exchange Date (the “Daily VWAP”).

The conversion rate will be determined over the 20-trading day observation period as follows for each trading
day during the period: (a) if the Daily VWAP is equal to or greater than $47.09 (the “Threshold Appreciation Price”),
the conversion rate will be equal to 21.2368 divided by 20; (b) if the Daily VWAP is equal to or less than the Threshold
Appreciation Price but greater than or equal to the last reported sale price per share of the Class A common stock on
the New York Stock Exchange as of May 4, 2020, which was $39.24 (the “Initial Price”), the conversion rate will be
between 21.2368 and 25.4842 divided by 20; and (c) if the Daily VWAP is equal to or less than the Initial Price, the
conversion rate will be 25.4842 divided by 20.

**Note 8— Leases**

We lease the vast majority of our stores, distribution and fulfillment centers, customer service centers, and
corporate offices under noncancelable operating and finance leases. The terms of our real estate leases generally range
from 10 to 20 years and typically allow us to renew for up to four additional 5-year terms. Store leases, including
exercised renewal options, expire at various dates through 2033. Distribution and fulfillment center, customer service
center, and corporate office leases, including exercised renewal options, expire at various dates through 2037.
Generally, our real estate leases require us to pay variable lease costs of property taxes, utilities, common area
maintenance, and insurance. We also lease certain equipment under operating and finance leases. Finance lease rightof-use assets, net of accumulated depreciation, are included in property and equipment, net, on the Condensed
Consolidated Balance Sheets.

In April 2020, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued guidance allowing entities to make a policy
election whether to account for lease concessions related to the COVID-19 pandemic as lease modifications. The
election applies to any lessor-provided lease concession related to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, provided

**Note 9 — Commitments and Contingencies**

**_Advertising Purchase Commitments_**

As of November 1, 2020, we had obligations to purchase $12.2 million of advertising through the remainder
of fiscal year 2020 and $14.0 million in fiscal year 2021.

**_Product and Services Purchase Commitments_**

As of November 1, 2020, we had various commitments to purchase merchandise and services from certain
vendors, including $8.6 million through the remainder of fiscal year 2020, $39.4 million in fiscal year 2021, $26.1
million in fiscal year 2022, $12.2 million in fiscal year 2023, $3.7 million in fiscal year 2024, and $1.2 million
thereafter.

**_Sales Tax Liability_**

The Company collects and remits sales tax in jurisdictions in which it has a physical presence or it believes
a nexus exists. The Company continually evaluates whether it may have a nexus in new jurisdictions with respect to
sales tax. The Company has recorded an estimated liability for potential exposure in states where there is uncertainty
about the point in time at which the Company established a sufficient in-state business presence to create a nexus and
the Company did not collect sales tax. Changes in management’s assumptions may occur in the future as the Company
obtains new information, which can result in adjustments to the recorded liability. Increases and decreases to the
liability for uncollected sales tax are included in operating, general, and administrative expenses on the Condensed
Consolidated Statements of Operations and Comprehensive Loss.

**_Litigation and Settlements_**

In the normal course of our business, we are subject to actual and threatened legal actions and proceedings,
including those related to alleged violations of labor and employment laws, intellectual property rights, consumer
protection laws, premises liability, contract disputes, and other laws and regulations.

While we currently do not expect that the ultimate outcome of the proceedings and claims pending or
threatened against us will have a material adverse effect on our condensed consolidated financial statements, the
outcome of any litigation is inherently uncertain, and if decided adversely to us, or if we determine that settlement of
particular litigation is appropriate, we may be subject to liability that could have a material adverse effect on our
condensed consolidated financial position, results of operations, or cash flows for a particular period.
